title: STEM Research Academy at City College
description: “The CCNY College Now STEM Research Academy is designed to provide high school students with an opportunity to develop the essential skills to be strong scientific thinkers by engaging in authentic, inquiry-based, and research activities. Selected students will be enrolled in a Spring 2025 course in an area of research science. Upon successful completion of the research science course, students will have the opportunity to participate in a Summer Research Internship – students are partnered with a City University of New York (CUNY) or City College of New York (CCNY) faculty member and will pursue a research topic of interest.” Students who successfully complete the program receive a $1,575 stipend.
eligible: Sophomores and juniors with an average GPA of 80

title: UA3 Youth Employment Program
description: “Our year-round after-school program is designed to provide invaluable career development opportunities and equip young individuals with the essential knowledge and skills to thrive in school and future careers. These engaging sessions are packed with opportunities to learn from guest speakers on topics like academic study skills, public speaking, environmental justice, nutrition and healthy eating, and financial literacy. You can network with leaders from government, the private sector, and nonprofit organizations, earning community service hours and Grow with Google Certificates. You can also participate in field visits to exciting locations, including Morgan Stanley, Apex for Youth, the High Line, and Governor's Island.”

title: Futures and Options Summer Internship
description: “The Futures and Options Internship Program is a paid mentored business internship program, and applications for the summer program will open on January 6th and close on January 24th. Internships may be a mix of virtual, in person and hybrid opportunities. We anticipate a larger than usual number of applications this year and will therefore prioritize graduating seniors and students who have not had an internship opportunity previously – but junioirs may apply as well. We strongly recommend that students submit their applications as soon as possible to ensure they are considered. Please also note that if students submitted a school year application this past fall, they do not need to reapply. Their application will be considered for the summer. A letter of recommendation and interview is required.”
date: July to mid-August (6 weeks, 100-150 hours total)

title: Justice for All After School Program
description: “This program is a (free) 12-session course taught by federal judges and practicing lawyers that exposes students to a range of exciting and relevant legal topics, and helps students to develop public speaking and advocacy skills. One session will include a field trip to a law firm. Family members are invited to attend the final session on Thursday, May 1, 2025 at the federal courthouse to watch the students participate in a moot court competition. A sampling of topics that will be covered throughout the elective include the First Amendment and student speech, the Fifth Amendment and student privacy, the Constitution and national security, and improving fairness in the criminal justice system. Students will have the opportunity to meet and speak with federal judges and practicing lawyers during the sessions and learn about careers in the law.”
location: Thurgood Marshall U.S. Courthouse (Manhattan, 40 Foley Square)

title: Brooklyn District Attorney Office Vacation Internships
description: “Selected students will participate in workshops, conversations, and presentations regarding law enforcement. The program is open to students who live and/or attend school in Brooklyn. Applicants will be selected for Winter break OR Spring break and must be able to commit to the entire duration of the internship. Winter internship will run from February 18 through February 21 (Tuesday through Friday), from 10:00am- 3pm. Spring internship will run from April 14 through April 18 (Monday through Friday). Students will receive a $150 stipend.”

title: Studio Institute Teen Apprenticeship Program (TAP)
description: “TAP is an innovative way to explore careers in the arts and education, while learning how to lead younger children in art-making classes and enhancing your own creativity and art-making skills. During the spring, students will gain expertise in the fundamentals of art, learn how to instruct young children in basic art lessons, and learn about the expectations of the workplace. Students may be invited to visit museums and galleries to learn more about the world of art around them. *Successful completion of the spring apprenticeship leads to a paid in-person summer internship as an art instructor at a summer camp for up to 25 hours weekly at an hourly pay rate of $16. There is no prior experience necessary.”
eligible: Students who are at least 16 years old

title: National High School Design Competition
description: Cooper Hewitt, the Smithsonian Design Museum, invites all students to create & submit original designs on the topic of “What would you design to help everyone feel at home in your community?” You can enter as an individual or as a team of up to three people.

title: STEM Research Academy at City College
description: “The CCNY College Now STEM Research Academy is designed to provide high school students with an opportunity to develop the essential skills to be strong scientific thinkers by engaging in authentic, inquiry-based, and research activities. Selected students will be enrolled in a Spring 2025 course in an area of research science. Upon successful completion of the research science course, students will have the opportunity to participate in a Summer Research Internship – students are partnered with a City University of New York (CUNY) or City College of New York (CCNY) faculty member and will pursue a research topic of interest.” Students who successfully complete the program receive a $1,575 stipend.
eligible: Sophomores and juniors with an average GPA of 80

title: Alley Pond Environmental Center Spring & Summer Internships
description: “Students are eligible to apply for field biology internships at the Alley Pond Environmental Center in Queens. Participants practice field observations & learn about urban ecology. Interns will learn how to study the biodiversity of various ecosystems, as well as how to identify some of the local birds, invertebrates, and plants of NYC. All materials and research equipment are provided by APEC each week; we may utilize tools such as field guides, microscopes, seining nets, chest waders, and environmental testing equipment. Recommendation letters may be requested at the end of the internship to apply for university/college, jobs or other internships/programs.” Please contact Erica Chow at echow@alleypond.org for more information or questions regarding the internship.
eligible: All students (priority to sophomores, juniors, and seniors)
date: Spring Term: Saturday mornings from March 15 – May 3; There is also a
deadline: Spring term - February 1 ; Summer term – June 1

title: Weill Cornell Medicine Meyer Cancer Center Summer Program
description: “Weill Cornell Medicine's Englander Institute for Precision Medicine and Meyer Cancer Center are committed to WCM’s mission to teach. This 7-week program will provide high school and college students with hands-on mentored experiential research experiences related to cancer and precision medicine with the goal to encourage the pursuit of STEM careers. We anticipate that this program will be held in-person 1-3 days per week, (dependent on mentor availability) on the Upper East Side campus (70th & York Avenue). During the summer program, students will actively participate in a range of seminars and program-specific didactics related to cancer biology, precision medicine, cancer epidemiology, health disparities, academic research, computational biomedicine, journal clubs, professional development courses and regular lectures, and will have the opportunity to interact with WCM faculty, staff and peers.”
eligible: Current juniors and seniors; priority to students from under-represented or
location: In-person at Weill Medical College, 70th Street & York Avenue Manhattan

title: Hutton Junior Fisheries Biology Program
description: “The Hutton Junior Fisheries Biology Program is an eight week, paid, full time summer internship and mentoring program for high school students sponsored by the American Fisheries Society (AFS). Selected students, known as Hutton Scholars, are matched and mentored by a fisheries and aquatic science professional in their local area to enjoy a hands-on fisheries science experience in a marine and/or freshwater setting. Hutton Scholars receive a stipend over the course of their internship as well as valuable work experience in an exciting and rewarding field. Each student must complete biweekly time sheets, a mid-summer report, and a final report in order to successfully complete the program.

title: Japan Center Essay Competition (JCSB)
description: “The aim of the JCSB essay competition is to provide young Americans with an opportunity to think creatively and critically about their lives by relating them to some aspect of Japan to help them broaden their horizons and develop global citizenship. Winners will receive cash prizes of up to $3,000 and a Canon camera.”

title: Japan Center Essay Competition (JCSB)
description: “The aim of the JCSB essay competition is to provide young Americans with an opportunity to think creatively and critically about their lives by relating them to some aspect of Japan to help them broaden their horizons and develop global citizenship. Winners will receive cash prizes of up to $3,000 and a Canon camera.”

title: Asian Pacific American Heritage Scholarship
description: “The Asian Pacific American (APA) Legacy Public Service Announcement (PSA) scholarship is a celebration of APA Heritage Month. The scholarship ($250 top prize) is open to any high school or college student of APA descent in the United States. What does being APA mean to you? The intention of the Heritage Series’ APA Legacy PSA scholarship is to allow APAs to create fun and interesting 60-90 second video vignettes. The videos must convey what it means to you to be an APA. Why do you feel it's important to recognize and celebrate your cultural heritage? Videos can be about the customs or traditions you practice, the types of foods you eat, or what you do with your family and friends. They can be clever, silly and/or serious. It's totally up to you, however, the contestant must share a little bit about themselves too. You must use the #APALegacy2023 hashtag when posting.”

title: Event Approaching: Girls Write Now Audio/Podcasting Career Chat
description: “Join us for an exciting and interactive introductory podcast workshop with performer, producer, and current Girls Write Now mentor, Kylie Holloway. Learn the essentials to podcasting by developing your technical audio production skills and practicing writing for audio platforms.”

title: Northfield Mount Hermon Summer Programs
description: “Northfield Mount Hermon is a student-centered learning community that opens its doors in the summer to welcome students from across the globe who, like you, want to make the most of their break. Ignite your passion, build lifelong skills, explore new passions, prepare to thrive at college, and create lasting memories and friendships. We are offering the following programs: Summer Scholars and English – Language Immersion, Summer Explorers, and Summer Enthusiasts.”
location: One Lamplighter Way, Mount Hermon, MA 01354

title: BMCC College Now Programs
description: The CUNY College Now Program at campuses throughout the city offers free college-level science, math, & humanities classes to current juniors & seniors, and, in some programs, sophomores.

title: STEP Program at Fordham University
description: “Fordham STEP scholars will receive the following services: Academic enrichment for the math and science classes students are currently taking in school; Exposure to STEM-related (science, technology, engineering, and math), health, and other licensed professions; Mentoring and tutoring from Fordham undergraduate students; Advising and preparation for the academic and social rigors of high school and college life; and opportunities to interact and build community with other STEP scholars.”
eligible: All economically disadvantaged students and/or under-represented (African

title: Opens Jan. 8: WPI College Credit Jumpstart for High Schoolers
description: “College Credit Jumpstart for High Schoolers is a pre-college summer program designed for high school students who are interested in earning college credit and experiencing an academically fulfilling WPI college course. WPI’s five-week online pre-college summer programs will allow students to explore STEM curriculum alongside WPI’s world-renowned faculty. Students will have access to WPI tutoring to ensure they are able to receive their college credit.”

title: Summer Discovery Pre-College Summer Programs
description: “With over 300 courses across 12 fields of study to choose from, Summer Discovery is the leader in delivering pre-college summer academic enrichment programs for students from around the world. Courses are designed to be engaging and hands-on, putting the student experience at the center of the course, taught by passionate and accredited instructors hand-selected by the university. Our courses deliver dedicated outcomes including a certificate of completion and a letter of recognition that students may use to boost their college or academic portfolio.”

title: Clemson University ESTEEMED Scholars Program
description: “The NIH-funded Call Me Doctor - ESTEEMED (Enhancing Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math Educational Diversity) Scholars Program helps underrepresented freshmen and sophomore-level trainees develop as scholars and scientists. It lays strong foundations through academic enrichment, financial support, faculty and peer mentoring, and training in Clemson biomedical research laboratories. It will also guide the ESTEEMED Scholars into an elite extramural summer program, advanced upper division undergraduate research training at Clemson, and eventually a Ph.D. or M.D./Ph.D. program in biomedical sciences.” (Freshmen will receive $5,000 per semester).
eligible: Seniors who are planning to pursue STEM and are from a disadvantaged or

title: National Student Leadership Conference (NSLC) Programs
description: “The NSLC, or National Student Leadership Conference, is an organization that offers interactive pre-college summer programs designed for high school students. Since its founding in 1989, NSLC has provided students with the opportunity to explore various career paths and develop leadership skills before heading off to college. Their summer programs are mainly held in many top universities from Yale and Georgetown to UCLA and Duke, which include hands-on simulations, guest speakers, trips & tours, and leadership training.”
cost: Various (depends on location); some scholarship aid may be available

title: LaunchX Entrepreneurship Summer Program
description: “LaunchX is a program designed to ignite the entrepreneurial spirit in high school students with both online and in-person summer camps aimed at fostering innovation and entrepreneurship in its students. LaunchX emphasizes hands-on learning, fostering a collaborative environment where students can connect with like-minded peers and industry professionals. The program offers diverse tracks, allowing students to explore various aspects of entrepreneurship, from technology to social impact.”

title: DOROT GENuine Connections Internship
description: “DOROT’S GENuine Connections is a virtual volunteer program for teens and adults 65+! DOROT's mission is to create a community where older adults can thrive, connect with others, and maintain their independence. Participate in weekly, small- group workshops over Zoom to talk and participate in activities like creative writing, chess, art, current events and so much more. New workshops begin every few weeks and require a commitment of 3-6 weeks!”
location: Hybrid (In-Person in Upper East or West Side, Manhattan)

title: Deadline Approaching:
description: College Passport at University Settlement 2025 SAT Prep Course “This course is designed to provide you with the knowledge and skills needed to succeed on the SAT exam. The course covers all sections of the exam, including reading and math, and includes practice tests and personalized feedback to help you identify areas that need improvement. With the guidance of experienced instructors, you'll learn test-taking strategies, time management skills, and how to approach different types of questions. By completing this course, you'll be better prepared for the exam and increase your chances of achieving your desired scores.”
location: East Side Community High School, 420 East 12th Street, Manhattan

title: The OppNet Fellows Program for Sophomores: Information Sessions
description: “During this six-year program, Student Fellows are able to gain skills in networking, academic habits, professional know-how, interviewing, and self-advocacy. Through a unique program structure integrating college guidance, transition, and success with professional exposure, career development, and five summers of paid internships or enrichment experiences, Fellows leave OppNet with robust resumes and lifelong networks of support ready to drive their personal and professional success forward.” Information sessions are being held on January 16 and 30 from 5 to 6 pm.
eligible: Current sophomores who identify as low-income (household income <

title: Junior Belford V. Lawson Oratorial Contest
description: “The Belford V. Lawson Oratorical Contest allows high school students to demonstrate their oratorical skills in a competitive but educational format. The purpose of the Belford V. Lawson Oratorical Contest is to identify problems or special topics of interest within society and determine how the problem or topic relates to the goals and objectives of Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity. The topic this year is ‘Keeping The Dream Alive in the 21st Century’.”
location: Alpha Phi Alpha Senior Citizen Center, 220-01 Linden Blvd Cambria

title: Griptape Learning Challenge
description: “The GripTape Learning Challenge provides you with up to $250 to pursue an interest or learn something you’re passionate about. In addition to funding, GripTape pairs you with a Champion to support you throughout your 10-week Learning Challenge. A Champion is a person who believes in you no matter what and is genuinely curious about you and your interests. And they help you think by asking great questions while never telling you what you should do.”
eligible: All students who are at least 14 years old

title: Youth for Understanding International Programs
description: “As a YFU student, you'll become part of a host family, appreciate the nuances of a foreign language, and test your confidence in new situations. YFU’s study abroad programs transform who you are and permanently change the way you see the world. Choose from a year, semester, summer program, or classroom excursion that allow you to immerse yourself in another culture, learn a new language, and live with a host family who will open their home and hearts to you.”
eligible: All students who are at least 15 years old (age requirements vary across

title: Sino-US Bridge Program (SUBP)
description: “The Sino-U.S. Bridge Program (SUBP) is dedicated to bridging the knowledge gap between American students and modern China. Our mission is to enhance future leaders’ competitiveness, empower students by exposing them to excellence worldwide, overcome barriers, and motivate students to transcend language, cost, and political obstacles when considering studying in China. Students will travel across China in cities such as: Beijing, the capital, Shanghai, the financial center, Hangzhou, the e-commerce capital, and Shenzhen, the Silicon Valley of China, to explore top universities and technology companies and gain insights into China’s significant advancements in key fields.”
location: Virtual and a trip to China

title: UChicago Parrhesia Ambassador Program
description: “The one-week Parrhesia Ambassador Program aims to introduce pre-college students to the fundamental principles and practices that prepare students to communicate in a variety of contexts. Rooted in the University of Chicago’s Principles of Free Expression, the Parrhesia Program offers an innovative curriculum in the theory and practice of public discourse and deliberation. Course assignments and exercises actively engage students in the rhetorical process of argument construction and presentation preparation and delivery. Selected participants will be tasked with serving as ambassadors and changemakers by sharing the principles of discourse and freedom of expression in communities.”

title: Event Approaching:
description: Brown Environmental Leadership Labs (BELL) Info Session “The Brown Environmental Leadership Lab (BELL) combines concepts in environmental studies, ecology, and leadership, with a mission of developing socially responsible leaders. At BELL, you’ll embark on a journey of learning and reflection while building community with fellow student environmentalists in your program. This info session will provide an overview of our BELL programs, the unique learning opportunities of each location, and a typical day in the life.”

title: STEP Program at Fordham University
description: “Fordham STEP scholars will receive the following services: Academic enrichment for the math and science classes students are currently taking in school; Exposure to STEM-related (science, technology, engineering, and math), health, and other licensed professions; Mentoring and tutoring from Fordham undergraduate students; Advising and preparation for the academic and social rigors of high school and college life; and opportunities to interact and build community with other STEP scholars.”
eligible: All economically disadvantaged students and/or under-represented (African

title: Onondaga Community College Pre-College Semiconductor Program
description: “Onondaga Community College's five-week Pre-college Semiconductor Summer Program offers high school students an opportunity to be exposed to the Electromechanical Technology or Engineering Science fields and other related fields. During the summer program, students will be given the chance to earn six to seven college-level credits depending on their career interests, participate in tutorial sessions, and go on field trips to meet educators and professionals from various pertinent fields. All students accepted will receive a scholarship covering tuition, room and board, books, and field trips. They will also receive stipends totaling $1,000 throughout the program to cover incidentals.”
location: Onondaga Community College, Syracuse, New York

title: Perry Initiative Experience at Albert Einstein College of Medicine
description: “The Perry Outreach Program is a free, one-day, hands-on experience to encourage women to pursue careers in medicine and engineering. Students will hear from women leaders in these fields and try it for themselves by performing mock orthopaedic surgeries and biomechanics experiments.”
eligible: Current Sophomores and older; focus on female students but all may apply
location: Albert Einstein College of Medicine, the Bronx

title: Event Approaching: Girls Write Now Audio/Podcasting Career Chat
description: “Join us for an exciting and interactive introductory podcast workshop with performer, producer, and current Girls Write Now mentor, Kylie Holloway. Learn the essentials to podcasting by developing your technical audio production skills and practicing writing for audio platforms.”

title: The Moth Story Lab Program
description: “Story Lab Virtual is a storytelling workshop series. High school students from all over the country meet to practice and perform Moth stories weekly for 8 weeks. The program ends with a performance that may be open to friends, and family.”
date: February 17 – 21 (Midwinter Break Story Lab) or March – May (Story Lab)

title: Princeton Prize in Race Relations
description: “Princeton University sponsors the Princeton Prize in Race Relations for high school students, with prices up to $2,500 awards to students who are working to help their schools or communities in this field. Recipients are also invited to participate in an all- expenses paid weekend trip to the Symposium on Race, during which they will have the opportunity to meet and learn from other winners.”

title: Princeton Prize in Race Relations
description: “Princeton University sponsors the Princeton Prize in Race Relations for high school students, with prices up to $2,500 awards to students who are working to help their schools or communities in this field. Recipients are also invited to participate in an all- expenses paid weekend trip to the Symposium on Race, during which they will have the opportunity to meet and learn from other winners.”

title: Return2College (R2C) Scholarship
description: “We know the essay requirement does not allow for many words. We want you to focus on the most important reason for getting your degree. Nevertheless, we realize that some of you may want to say more. Therefore, you may submit more than one entry. We will judge all completed entries. The first-place award is a $1,000 scholarship which will be paid directly to the applicant or designated school.”

title: The various military services offer Reserve Officers Training Corps (ROTC)
Cathay Bank Foundation Scholarship
description: “Cathay Bank Foundation is committed to supporting youth residing in its business service territories to fulfill their dreams of obtaining a higher education. It offers $2,500 scholarships to high school seniors, planning to attend college as a full-time, degree-seeking student in the fall of 2025.”

title: Dragon Hearts Foundation College Scholarship
description: “The Dragon Hearts Foundation College Scholarship Fund is committed to supporting exceptional female students facing financial challenges, in particular those pursuing Business or STEM degrees. It offers $5,000 Scholarships for female high school seniors, planning to attend college as a full-time, degree-seeking student in the fall of 2025.”
eligible: Current Seniors who identify as female pursuing Business or STEM

title: Kao Kalia Yang Scholarship
description: “The Robin-Hwajin Yoon Kim Foundation, which supports education, the underprivileged, and positive social impact initiatives has established the “Kao Kalia Yang Scholarship” to help economically-challenged Hmong American youth fulfill their dreams of obtaining higher education. It offers $5,000 scholarships to high school seniors, planning to attend college as a full-time, degree-seeking student in the fall of 2025.”
eligible: Current Seniors who identify as Hmong

title: Preferred Bank Scholarship
description: “Preferred Bank is committed to supporting economically challenged youth residing in its business service territories to fulfill their dreams of obtaining a higher education. It offers $2,000 scholarships to high school seniors, planning to attend college as a full-time, degree-seeking student in the fall of 2025.”
eligible: Current Seniors who meet low-income level requirements

title: Royal Business Bank Scholarship
description: “Royal Business Bank is committed to supporting youth residing in its business service territories to fulfill their dreams of obtaining a higher education. It offers $1,000 scholarships to high school seniors, planning to attend college as a full-time, degree-seeking student in the fall of 2025.”
eligible: Current Seniors who meet low-income level requirements

title: Taiwanese American Scholarship
description: “The Taiwanese American Scholarship Fund is focused on helping economically challenged Taiwanese American youth fulfill their dreams of obtaining higher education. It offers 10 – $7,500 Renewable Scholarships (per year for 4 years) to high school seniors, planning to attend college as a full-time, degree-seeking student in the fall of 2025.”
eligible: Current Seniors who identify as Taiwanese and/or directly related to a

title: Girls in Science & Engineering Day 2025: NASA Explore!
description: “This annual festival celebrates girls and young people actively engaging in STEM. This year the event is part of NASA Explore Day which encourages youth and their families to explore and connect with NASA missions through Museum-related content and NASA-generated educational activities. ”
eligible: Focus on female students but all are welcome to attend; Students under 16
location: Intrepid Museum, Pier 86 at West 46th Street

title: Youth Communication Immigrant Youth Webinar
description: “Migrant and immigrant youth face unique anxieties about their future, their families, and their communities. In this session, we’ll read a moving story by a Youth Communication teen writer who reflects on overhearing a family discussion about deportation. Together, we’ll explore the profound questions raised by this story and discuss actionable strategies for creating safe and supportive environments for immigrant and migrant youth.”

title: NYPL College Acceptance Letters and Paying for College Session
description: “Springtime is when colleges start sending acceptance letters. This virtual info session with staff from The New School's ‘Understanding FAFSA’ program will show high school students and their families tools they can use to evaluate various financial aid packages. We will also talk about scholarships, loans, work study programs and tips on how to appeal for more financial assistance.”

title: Stevens Institute of Technology Pre-College Summer Programs
description: “Stevens Institute of Technology Pre-College Summer Program allows students to explore their passions in an inspiring academic setting that embraces visionary thinkers. Through this program, students will engage with state-of-the-art technology, explore a potential major, learn in a cutting-edge facility, collaborate with exceptional faculty, and develop problem-solving skills from hand-on projects. Some programs include Cybersecurity: Beginner & Advanced, Pre-Med Biomedical Engineering, Business Explorer, and Data Science for Social Policy.”

title: St. John’s College Summer Academy
description: “St. John’s Summer Academy in Maryland or New Mexico is a college summer program for high school students (ages 15 to 18), modeled after St. John’s discussion- based, interdisciplinary method of teaching great books. A genuine introduction to college life, Summer Academy helps students hone their reading, critical thinking, and discussion skills in classes led by St. John’s faculty. Our goal with the Summer Academy is to introduce high school students to the world of critical thinking and discussion while reading great books on subjects like philosophy, literature, psychology, history, religion, economics, science, astronomy, language, and more. Summer Academy is perfect for students who want to immerse themselves in books, ideas, and a community that loves learning as much as you do.”
location: Virtual OR in-person at Annapolis, Maryland, or Santa Fe, New Mexico

title: Vanderbilt Programs for Talented Youth Summer
description: “VSA programs provide the perfect balance of an intensive academic environment combined with a community-driven residential experience at one of the leading universities in the nation. At VSA, students join peers from around the world stretching their intellectual boundaries through choice-based classes. Together, students enjoy learning and connecting with peers and engage in on-campus and community activities in the heart of Music City.”

title: Stuyvesant Business Clubs Meeting
description: “Finance Club Collaboration Event- Hosted by Rock The Street Wall Street Interested in business or finance and everything in between? Join us for a fun tri-series event for $$ where we will dive into the various business-orientedclubs offered at Stuyvesant. This is the perfect opportunity to get exposed to our amazing offerings, find our what is right for you and participate in our investment game competition for a fun, friendly battle for the GRAND PRIZE! Join us if you are someone who is ambitious and no worries if this is your first exposure to business- all are welcome!”

title: New Settlement College Explorers Workshops –Information Sessions
description: “This program is designed to assist high school juniors during the spring term, helping them learn about the college application process through workshops, explore financial aid options, engage in social activities, and participate in an overnight college trip. Interested students must attend at least one upcoming information session”
date: Tuesdays & Thursdays (4:30 – 6:30) from March 4 – May 23; Information
location: In-person at 1563 Walton Avenue, the Bronx

title: NYPL College Acceptance Letters and Paying for College Session
description: “Springtime is when colleges start sending acceptance letters. This virtual info session with staff from The New School's ‘Understanding FAFSA’ program will show high school students and their families tools they can use to evaluate various financial aid packages. We will also talk about scholarships, loans, work study programs and tips on how to appeal for more financial assistance.”

title: Information Session Approaching:
description: NYU Wagner Democracy Scholars Program – Summer & Fall “The Democracy Scholars Program at NYU Wagner School of Public Service offers current high school juniors the chance to reside at NYU for 3 weeks over the summer, learn from NYU professors in a discussion-based seminar, receive guided college application support from professors and Democracy Scholar Writing Mentors, and work in teams on a civic engagement project throughout the 2025-26 academic year. While residing at NYU in July, students participate in small discussion-based seminars led by NYU professors, and gain experience in college-level reading, writing and critical thinking. Additionally, students receive mentoring and support throughout the college application process from professors and Democracy Scholar Writing Mentors.”
eligible: Current Juniors (Priority Given to First-Generation Students)
location: NYU Wagner School of Public Service, 295 Lafayette St., Manhattan

title: Deadline Approaching:
description: Factory Farming Awareness Coalition National High School Mentoring Program “The FFAC National High School Mentorship program is an online summer program with the Factory Farming Awareness Coalition (FFAC) for a nine-week time commitment. Students from around the US will learn more about the impacts of factory farming, engage in active discussion, and participate in a variety of social change-making projects and nonprofit work.”

title: Women in Law Career Information Event @ the NY State Supreme Court
description: “Female judges, attorneys, and other legal professionals will discuss many aspects of the legal profession, along with their career paths. Interested students may register individually via the link below –just fill in the first 4 lines - school name, their name (Contact Name), their email address, and their phone #; (ignore the following lines on the application).
eligible: Focus on female students, all may apply; limited spots, first come, first

title: NYC Students Demand Action March Meeting
Trip of a Lifetime
description: “The Trip of a Lifetime program is an opportunity for free overseas trips and service opportunities to current 9th - 11th graders who qualify for free/reduced lunch. Participants are immersed in the local culture of their selected destination.”
eligible: All freshmen, sophomores, and juniors who qualify for a federal assistance

title: Justin Brannan Comptroller Campaign Internship
description: “Justin Brannan’s campaign for New York City Comptroller is accepting applications for talented and motivated interns. This high-stakes, high-profile race will be contested in every neighborhood of NYC. Interns on this campaign will have a unique opportunity to work with seasoned political operatives, gaining the skills to make their mark on local politics - and beyond. Previous campaign experience is not required; what is required is a serious work ethic, willingness to learn, and a passion for our city. As an intern you would work 10 hours a week on the front lines of voter contact as we win votes and collect signatures to get Justin on the ballot.”

title: Outer Coast Programs in Alaska
description: “Outer Coast students are intellectually curious, community-minded, and driven to create positive change in their lives and communities. Outer Coast seeks to serve a student body that is national and international in breadth and diverse in many ways, including racial, ethnic, cultural, and gender identities, and socioeconomic status. Outer Coast emphasizes reaching students from across Alaska, particularly Alaska Natives and rural Alaskans, as well as other high-potential students from backgrounds underrepresented and underserved in American higher education. Admissions at Outer Coast are need-blind.”
eligible: Current sophomores and juniors (Summer Seminar), Current seniors
cost: Varies based on demonstrated financial need (full scholarships available)

title: Justice For All - Summer Justice Institute Program
description: “New York City high school students are invited to participate in a one-week summer program at a federal courthouse in New York – “Crime. The Constitution, and the Courts.” The program will consist of several components that will allow the students to learn about the legal system, including careers within that system. The students will hear presentations from federal judges, FBI agents, Deputy U.S. Marshals, a U.S. Secret Service agent, federal prosecutors, criminal defense lawyers and others about their respective roles within the court system. The students will also observe real court proceedings in the federal courthouse and be taught basic advocacy skills in several sessions by experienced lawyers. With the assistance of law students, they will participate in a mock trial competition against other high school students at the end of the week.”
location: Southern District Federal Courthouse (Manhattan, 40 Foley Square) OR

title: The Project Lotus Youth Team
description: “Through educating and empowering today’s Asian-American communities, Project Lotus advances the movement of Asian-Americans blossoming and addressing mental health stigma, shame, and overall perception and care of mental health. The team is looking for new members to join their team and all are welcome to apply if interested. Positions such as illustrator, projects assistants, writer/researcher, videos, and finance are offered.”

title: Brooklyn Museum Teen Gallery/Studio Program
description: “The Gallery/Studio Program offers fun, challenging studio art courses. Be inspired by professional teaching artists and spend time discussing artworks from our exhibitions, learn new skills and techniques, and create your own art using both new and traditional materials. Classes are available for children, teens, and adults. All levels of experience welcome! The course offered for Spring 2024 is Painting and Mixed Media: Beyond the Brush.”

title: Museum of Arts and Design (MAD) Artslife Internship
description: “Artslife is a paid summer internship program for rising sophomores and juniors enrolled in New York City public and charter high schools. The internship combines art and design with leadership training, museum studies, and community engagement. Participants are introduced to careers in all sectors of the museum: Curatorial, Education, Development, Communications and Marketing, Visitor Services, Security, and Registrar. The first week of Artslife is dedicated to team bonding and introducing the interns to the Museum. During the remaining five weeks, participants work on collaborative projects with Museum staff, local designers, and arts professionals who act as mentors.”
location: Museum of Arts and Design, 2 Columbus Circle

title: Deadline Approaching:
description: Prospect Park Alliance Paid Youth Employment Programs Prospect Park Alliance offers two youth employment programs. 1- Woodlands Youth Crew “Woodlands Youth Crew members engage in a variety of projects to help sustain and restore Prospect Park’s 250 acres of woodlands. Projects can include trail maintenance and the creation of new rustic woodland pathways, planting native species of flora to create a thriving forest, and removing invasive weeds that impact the health of the woodlands and its waterways. Throughout the sessions, Woodlands Youth Crew members are able to see the areas they work on transform into healthier, more resilient ecosystems and, in turn, come to understand the importance of their individual contribution to the health and longevity of Prospect Park. Members will work outdoors from 9 am to 4:30 pm and will be paid $16.50/hour.” 2- Park Youth Representatives “Park Youth Representatives are trained to engage our community in learning about environmental stewardship and wildlife. Park Youth Representatives lead nature walks, actively engage our community of park goers in nature education activities at the Prospect Park Audubon Center and at pop-up locations throughout the park, and care for the Audubon Center’s live animal collection including a snake, aquatic and terrestrial turtles, fish and insects. Throughout the year, Park Youth Representatives are able to connect with our community across the park and deepen their knowledge of our park environment, wildlife, stewardship and sharing this knowledge with the public.”

title: Environmental Studies Summer Youth Institute (ESSYI)
description: “The Environmental Studies Summer Youth Institute (ESSYI) is a two-week, college- level interdisciplinary summer program for talented high-school students. ESSYI introduces students to environmental issues and interdisciplinary techniques for addressing environmental problems. Students make new intellectual and emotional connections as they explore current environmental challenges through scientific, social, economic, philosophical, ethical, and political perspectives.”

title: Engineering Summer Program at the University of Wisconsin-Madison
description: “ESP is designed for rising high school juniors and seniors to engage in a free, three- week residential program with interactive programming similar to a first year engineering experience at UW-Madison. Students will participate in handson workshops, visit industry sites, go on field trips, and receive mentoring from faculty.”
eligible: Current sophomores and juniors with a minimum GPA of 3.0; All may apply

title: All Star Code 2025 Summer Intensive
description: “All Star Code's Summer Intensive is a trans­form­ative experience designed to equip students with vital technical and professional skills. Choose between the accelerated 3-week Tech Sprint or the comprehensive 6-week Tech Marathon, both offering live instruction, personalized support, and a collaborative community for students to jumpstart their journey in technology and innovation. The programs feature intense coding instruction in HTML, CSS, and JavaScript and workshops on problem-solving, critical thinking, and tailored engagements with tech professionals and guest speakers.”
eligible: All students who identify as male or non-binary

title: CDC Museum Public Health Academy Online Summer Course
description: “The CDC Museum Public Health Academy Online Summer Course is a web-based course with both synchronous and asynchronous components. The course reflects the museum’s mission of educating the public about CDC’s work. Topics vary course to course, but may include: public health interventions, global health, infectious disease, chronic disease, injury prevention, data analysis, surveys, school wellness programs, violence prevention, birth defects, mental health, environmental health, emergency preparedness, outbreaks, scientific communication, laboratory technology, disease surveillance, epidemiology, and public health law.”
eligible: Current sophomores and juniors who are at least 17

title: Columbia University SBI Synthetic Biology Workshop
description: “Each year, Columbia SBI hosts a free workshop series, in which students learn the critical techniques used within synthetic biology, the theoretical basis of these techniques and synthetic biology as a whole, along with the frontiers of current research in the field. Building on last semester’s successful series, this semester we are diving deeper into specialty topics that highlight the latest advancements in the field. This four-part workshop series will take place on the following dates: 03/23/25 – Applications of CRISPR Technology 03/30/25 – Regenerative Medicine 04/06/25 – Computational Biology 04/13/25 – Applications of Synthetic Biology in Industry Lessons will be delivered live through the Systems Biology Initiative's Zoom account on Sundays from 2:00-4:00pm. Please note that in order to participate in the workshop series, students will need to make a free zoom account. The Spring 2025 application for this program can be accessed through this google form. The deadline for the application is Sunday, March 9th, 2025. Please note that successful registration requires the completion of the application and the email submission of the forms linked in the application, which are also due on March 9th. For any questions, please contact us at cu.syn.bio.initiative@gmail.com

title: Reynolds Young Writers Workshop
description: “The workshop is an eight-day residential program that incorporates small creative writing workshops, group sessions with Denison creative writing faculty and notable visiting writers, and much more. Only 48 students get the chance to come to The Hill to participate each June. That means students experience small, intimate writing workshops and one-on-one interactions with people who have made writing their career. It's a great way to connect with a close-knit community of writing teachers, mentors, and peers from around the world.”
cost: $1,500 – Financial aid available for eligible students

title: NYC Public School Film Festival
description: “The 7th Annual NYC Public School Film Festival is open to all NYC Public School middle and high school students. All entries must be five minutes or less, in the categories of Animation, Documentary, Experimental, or Short Feature/Narrative. Each selected film will receive a “Certificate of Official Selection”. All filmmakers will be invited to a special screening day and career development event tentatively scheduled for April 29, 2025.”

title: Stossel in the Classroom Essay Contest
description: “Students can submit an essay of 500 to 1,000 words on one of four topics: The Effect of Minimum Wage on Entry-Level Workers: A Better Immigration System; Cancel Culture or Censorship – Is it an assault on 1st Amendment freedoms?, and Coercion vs. Choice.” Top submissions will win a cash prize of up to $2,500.”

title: Our History Our Voice Video Contest
description: “The Center on Asian Americans and the Law at Fordham Law School, the AAPI Crime Victims and Education Fund, and NAPABA are sponsoring a video contest for Middle and High School students that we hope will engage them in Asian American legal history. The contest carries a $5,000 top prize and three additional $1,000 prizes and invites students to learn about cases involving Asian Americans and to retell the stories in short videos.”

title: Teen Writing Contest at the Morgan Library & Museum
description: “The Morgan Library & Museum is hosting a Teen Writing Contest inspired by our exhibition Franz Kafka presents, for the first time in the United States, the Bodleian Library’s extraordinary holdings of Kafka’s manuscripts and diaries, as well as exploring the influential afterlife of his works. Describe a landmark, location, or other feature of New York, but add your own fictitious twist. How has your space been transformed? Is it more welcoming or sinister? Does it draw crowds or repel them? Who will inhabit your imagined space, and what will they do there? The winning entries will receive a $100 MasterCard gift card.”

title: Gilder Lehrman Institute Contest - Vietnam Veterans: Legacies of Service
description: Awards “Students are encouraged to create a biographical profile of a Vietnam War Veteran. Profiles could include written reports, eulogies, videos, podcasts, poems, or songs. Student work must be submitted by a teacher or parent/guardian.” The top ten submissions will receive $500 prizes.

title: Stossel in the Classroom Essay Contest
description: “Students can submit an essay of 500 to 1,000 words on one of four topics: The Effect of Minimum Wage on Entry-Level Workers: A Better Immigration System; Cancel Culture or Censorship – Is it an assault on 1st Amendment freedoms?, and Coercion vs. Choice.” Top submissions will win a cash prize of up to $2,500.”

The contest carries a $5,000 top prize and three additional $1,000 prizes and invites students to learn about cases involving Asian Americans and to retell the stories in short videos.”

description: “The Morgan Library & Museum is hosting a Teen Writing Contest inspired by our exhibition Franz Kafka presents, for the first time in the United States, the Bodleian Library’s extraordinary holdings of Kafka’s manuscripts and diaries, as well as exploring the influential afterlife of his works. Describe a landmark, location, or other feature of New York, but add your own fictitious twist. How has your space been transformed? Is it more welcoming or sinister? Does it draw crowds or repel them? Who will inhabit your imagined space, and what will they do there? The winning entries will receive a $100 MasterCard gift card.”

description: Awards “Students are encouraged to create a biographical profile of a Vietnam War Veteran. Profiles could include written reports, eulogies, videos, podcasts, poems, or songs. Student work must be submitted by a teacher or parent/guardian.” The top ten submissions will receive $500 prizes.

title: Apex for Youth College Success Scholarship
description: “Apex for Youth is committed to supporting Asian and Asian-American students through college and lessening the financial burden of pursuing their academic goals. Apex for Youth is offering six scholarships of up to $10,000 each year of college to Asian-American high school students.”
eligible: Current Seniors who are low-income and identify as Asian

title: 2025 NY College Expo
description: “Learn more about your college options, chat with current college students about their experience and ask any lingering questions before making your college decision. This event is both for Seniors who have already applied to college and for Juniors who are just starting the college search and are interested in Bottom Line! Parents/guardians are also invited to attend! Join us for raffles🎟, prizes 🎧, and a college student panel to answer your college questions! College students in attendance will be from schools such as: CUNY Hunter, City College, Baruch, Lehman, John Jay; SUNY: Albany, New Paltz, Old Westbury, Stony Brook; Privates: Syracuse, NYU, Columbia, St Josephs, St Francis, Fordham and MORE.
location: St. Francis College, 179 Livingston Street, Brooklyn

title: Deadline Approaching: Stony Brook University Pre-College Program
description: “Explore your academic passions in Stony Brook's residential summer program for talented high school students. In SBU's pre-college summer program, you can discover your academic interests and aptitude through challenging courses, gain invaluable skills for academic success in college preparation workshops, connect with Stony Brook faculty and industry experts, and enjoy access to state-of-the-art facilities, libraries, and student resources. The program offers courses in biotechnology, dental sciences, machine learning, journalism, finance, engineering, law, and much more.”
location: Stony Brook University, Stony Brook NY

title: Yale Ethics Society High School Fellowship Sessions
description: “The Yale Undergraduate Ethics Society is a vibrant community of thinkers who organize events related to ethics and philosophy on Yale's campus. Annually, we participate in the Collegiate Ethics Bowl, host events with guest speakers who are renowned in their fields of bioethics, AI ethics, animal ethics, etc, and organize a tournament between U.S. and Chinese high school students. The fellowship will consist of two virtual sessions involving discussions with other fellows and Yale students on various ethical philosophies and dilemmas, and an in- person symposium on Yale's campus. The symposium will center around a discussion with a Yale professor as guest speaker, and will also include group bonding activities between fellows, a tour of campus, and time to chat with Yale Ethics Society members about philosophy, college, or anything of the like.”

title: Columbia University Science Honors Program
description: “The Columbia University Science Honors Program (SHP) is a highly selective program for high school students who have a strong interest in the sciences and mathematics. Courses are primarily in the physical, chemical, biological, behavioral, and computing sciences; and instructors are scientists and mathematicians who are actively engaged in research at the University. ”
cost: $50 Application Fee; $700 program fee (fee waivers may be available for

title: Washington University Gateway to Business Pre-College Programs
description: “Gateway to Business is a comprehensive hybrid course that introduces students to business, leadership and teamwork skills development, and career preparedness. The curriculum includes a foundational view of business, creative problem solving, experiential learning, professional communications, career strategies, and the creation of a professional development plan, including real-world examples of founding and operating a startup, how to think like an entrepreneur, and potential career paths. Students who participate will earn college credit, refine professional communications, build a personal brand, problem-solve for real-world clients through an experiential learning project, and spend a week on WashU’s campus engaging with faculty, professionals, and fellow students.”
location: Hybrid; In-Person at Washington University, St. Louis

title: Postsecondary College & Careers Fair
description: “The Brooklyn STEAM Center is excited to announce its 2nd Annual Postsecondary Fair. We will be hosting 60+ postsecondary options for scholars in high school to explore as future pathways to success. A postsecondary option is a pathway beyond high school that supports you in attaining your dream career. This can include any of the following options we'll have representatives from colleges/universities, trade schools, apprenticeships, armed service, and direct employers.”
eligible: All students (highly encouraged for current juniors)
location: Brooklyn STEAM Center, 141 Flushing Avenue (Building 77, Floor 3)

title: Museum of Finance Academy
description: “The Museum Finance Academy (MFA) is a FREE five session personal finance certificate course for 11th and 12th graders with the goal of teaching students to aspire to financial independence through developing an appreciation for savings, establishing financial goals and learning to avoid scams. Students are expected to attend all five sessions and keep cameras on during the sessions. This course requires NO prior knowledge of finance, business or economics. The top four students from each class will be awarded a partial college scholarship ranging from $500 to $1,000.”
date: March 18, 25, April 1, 8, 15 (Tuesday session) or March 20, 27, April 3, 10, 15

title: Exploring Entrepreneurship: One Week High School Intensive at Fordham
description: University “During this week-long intensive, students will gain a comprehensive overview of the entrepreneurial process in a hands-on fashion. From coming up with a business idea, testing & refining, and ultimately pitching that idea to a panel of university professors and entrepreneurs, this week will prove to be a thought-provoking, skills-building, and transformative experience.”

title: Fordham University Finance Institute
description: This is a one-week program that introduces high school students to the finance industry and to leading business companies & executives.
location: Virtual or in-person options (441 E. Fordham Road, Bronx) available
deadline: April 1 (Priority and financial aid deadline), Rolling Basis

title: One Deadline Approaching:
description: Young Women’s Institute Business Program (YWI) “The Young Women’s Institute is a program run by the Kelley School of Business at Indiana University in Bloomington, Indiana, that introduces young women to the world of business through lectures, workshops, and practical endeavors. During the one-day program, participants get to join workshops that feature top faculty members. The YWI gives participants access to current business students and alumni, a chance to explore a real-world business case project, build leadership and communication skills, and connect with like-minded women interested in business.”
eligible: Current sophomores and juniors who have a minimum 3.5 GPA
location: Virtual and in-person options available; Indiana University (Bloomington,
cost: Free (transportation and personal expenses not covered)

title: Gilder Lehrman History Internships
description: “Students from all over the country will take part in a variety of engaging internships, gaining valuable experience in museum collection management, educational programming, and nonprofit operations. Interns will be paid $16.50 per hour.” Available positions for high school interns are History School Intern and Teacher Seminars Intern.

title: Postsecondary College & Careers Fair Registration
description: “The Brooklyn STEAM Center is excited to announce its 2nd Annual Postsecondary Fair. We will be hosting 60+ postsecondary options for scholars in high school to explore as future pathways to success. A postsecondary option is a pathway beyond high school that supports you in attaining your dream career. This can include any of the following options we'll have representatives from colleges/universities, trade schools, apprenticeships, armed service, and direct employers.”
eligible: All Students (highly encouraged for current juniors)

title: 2025 NY College Expo
description: “Learn more about your college options, chat with current college students about their experience and ask any lingering questions before making your college decision. This event is both for Seniors who have already applied to college and for Juniors who are just starting the college search and are interested in Bottom Line! Parents/guardians are also invited to attend! Join us for raffles🎟, prizes 🎧, and a college student panel to answer your college questions! College students in attendance will be from schools such as: CUNY Hunter, City College, Baruch, Lehman, John Jay; SUNY: Albany, New Paltz, Old Westbury, Stony Brook; Privates: Syracuse, NYU, Columbia, St Josephs, St Francis, Fordham and MORE.
location: St. Francis College, 179 Livingston Street, Brooklyn
