description: “The Brooklyn STEAM Center is excited to announce its 2nd Annual Postsecondary Fair. We will be hosting 60+ postsecondary options for scholars in high school to explore as future pathways to success. A postsecondary option is a pathway beyond high school that supports you in attaining your dream career. This can include any of the following options we'll have representatives from colleges/universities, trade schools, apprenticeships, armed service, and direct employers.”
eligible: All Students (highly encouraged for current juniors)

title: Chinatown 360 Youth Wellbeing & Cultural Identity Survey
description: “In partnership with youth-serving Asian American organizations across New York City, Chinatown 360° is excited to launch the Youth Wellbeing & Cultural Identity Survey, the first city-wide prevention survey for Asian American youth populations. Open to all NYC youth, the survey aims to understand and uplift the needs of youth. Survey participants will be entered into a raffle to win one $200 Visa gift card.”

title: Mayor’s Office Paid Internships
description: “The Mayor’s Office Internship Program allows students to apply to the department that interests them most, and, if selected, will work within that department for the duration of their internship. In their positions, interns will have the chance to collaborate with staff and work on a range of projects. such as conducting research, attending meetings, managing incoming inquiries, and more. Through the bi-weekly Speaker Series, interns will learn more about the inner- workings of City government. In collaboration with NYC Service, the Mayor’s Office division focused on volunteerism and service in New York City, interns will come together to develop a service project.”
eligible: Students who are at least 16 years old

title: Harvey Epstein For City Council Volunteer Fellowship
description: “The Harvey Epstein for New York City Council District 2 Campaign is seeking interns to join our team through the Democratic Primary in June. They will gain direct campaign experience and get familiar with NYC politics. Interns will participate in field operations, and have the chance to assist other departments as they desire (research, fundraising, graphic design, press, marketing, etc)”

title: Edafe Okporo For City Council Internship
description: “Edafe Okporo is a progressive candidate seeking to become the first former asylum- seeker to sit on the New York City Council. Edafe is seeking to represent District 7, which includes the Upper West Side, Morningside Heights, West Harlem, Hamilton Heights, and Washington Heights. Work can be done in-person or remotely and hours can be applied to volunteer credit. Interns will get a significant amount of direct campaign experience and have the flexibility to choose what they want to focus on, including direct voter contact, staffing the candidate at events, organizing meet-and-greets, earned media, graphic design, video design, and social media. ”
date: TBD (5 hours/week based on schedule availability)

title: Deadline Approaching: It Starts With the Arts” Art Competition
description: “We are seeking student artwork to be featured on “It Starts With the Arts” campaign postcards that will be circulated to government officials and shared in campaign materials in support of increased, sustainable funding for arts education in our public schools. We will select three winners who, along with having their art featured, will receive $200 Visa gift cards, and be honored in-person at Face to Face 2025. Runners- up will be featured on our website and social media channels and will receive $50 Visa gift cards.”

title: The Teen Art Hang at the Jewish Museum
description: “Teens are invited to explore art and create as a community in this free after-school drop-in program (4:00 – 6:00pm) at the Jewish Museum. Through themed activities, teens engage with different mediums and materials to make works of art, exploring topics most relevant to them.”
location: The Jewish Museum at 92nd Street and 5th Avenue

title: Gilder Lehrman History Internships
description: “Students from all over the country will take part in a variety of engaging internships, gaining valuable experience in museum collection management, educational programming, and nonprofit operations. Interns will be paid $16.50 per hour.” Available positions for high school interns are History School Intern and Teacher Seminars Intern.

title: Brooklyn Bridge Park TIDES Program
description: “Join TIDES (Teens Interested In and Dedicated to Environmental Stewardship) and meet other teens from across the city! This opportunity brings students together to complete weekly community service projects that focus on ecology, conservation, and sustainability. TIDES is perfect for students who have an existing or budding interest in the environment, looking for new experiences and are ready to learn new skills. No experience in stewardship or environmental projects is needed to apply!”
eligible: All students who are at least 14 years old

title: Columbia University Student Group Science Research Symposium
description: “Columbia’s Modulus Research Education Club is hosting a spring symposium in which students who have previously conducted research can present to and engage in conversation and debate with students looking to get involved in research. There are three main components of this symposium: asynchronous project submissions, presentations, and debate. In the asynchronous symposium round, students who have previously conducted research can submit a short research paper by March 23, 2025. Then, some students will be selected to present their work at a live presentation round. Students who are eager to get involved in research should attend the presentation round to learn more! The final component is an optional journal/club debate where students will read a paper and discuss its findings and broader implications.”

title: Pioneer Research Program
description: “Pioneer Academics is a research institute for high-achieving high school students seeking to conduct accredited research in STEM, social sciences, and humanities. It is the only online research program that grants college credit through our partnership with Oberlin College. Pioneer is committed to access for all students accepted into the program. This program strives to meet admitted students’ demonstrated financial need, where need could be assessed.

title: Columbia University Science Honors Program
description: “The Columbia University Science Honors Program (SHP) is a highly selective program for high school students who have a strong interest in the sciences and mathematics. Courses are primarily in the physical, chemical, biological, behavioral, and computing sciences; and instructors are scientists and mathematicians who are actively engaged in research at the University. ”
cost: $50 Application Fee, $700 (fee waivers available for eligible students)

title: Next Session Approaching:
description: Syska Hennessy Group Student Engineering Sessions “Syska Hennessy Group is a leading global engineering and technology company. With more than 500 professionals across 18 offices, we provide a full range of engineering services for projects of every size and budget: from global headquarters to small office renovations; from the premier healthcare facilities to essential mission- critical facilities. Syska’s goal is to maintain the relationships formed during a student’s H.S. years, working with the Exploring Program, to take the students to the next phase in their journey - such as being selected for Syska’s college intern program full-service.”

title: Deadline Approaching:
description: MIT Lincoln Laboratory Radar Introduction for Student Engineers (LLRISE) “The LLRISE program is a residential summer workshop teaching students how to build small radar systems. This summer STEM program is a FREE two-week project- based enrichment program for outstanding students currently in their junior year in high school. Students in the LLRISE program gain in-depth experience building small radar systems. Participants will utilize a Doppler and range radar by using creative problem-solving strategies. This hands-on program allows students to receive instruction from highly talented scientists and engineers.”
eligible: Current juniors (Underrepresented and lower-income groups encouraged to

title: Carnegie Mellon University picoCTF Hacking
description: Competition “picoCTF is the largest cybersecurity hacking competition for middle, high school, and college students. Participants 13 years and older of all skill levels are encouraged to compete. Competitors must reverse-engineer, break, hack, decrypt, and think creatively and critically to solve the challenges and capture the digital flags. Competition prizes have eligibility requirements, but everyone is encouraged to play for fun and learning.”

title: Ross Mathematics Program
description: “The Ross Program is an intensive summer experience designed to immerse students in a world of mathematical discovery. The Number Theory is the central topic of the program, but students will also explore deeper concepts. There are also undergraduate and graduate student counselors studying math and science providing guidance.”
eligible: All students who are between 15 and 18 years old

title: Princeton University Laboratory Learning Program
description: “Princeton’s Laboratory Learning Program is a free research experience in the sciences or engineering. Students are included in ongoing research programs where they are closely supervised by Princeton faculty and research staff. The participation dates are customized according to the schedules of the research personnel and the specifics of the project. Internships typically span 5-6 weeks over the summer. Students may apply online or mail-in applications.”
eligible: All students who will be at least sixteen years old by June 15

title: University of Michigan’s Joy of Coding Summer Course
description: “Jumpstart your introduction to the world of coding with an Intro to Coding online course from University of Michigan Engineering faculty. No prior coding experience required! All courses are online and self-paced, so you can fit them into your schedule. Upon completion of the course, students receive a certificate of accomplishment from University of Michigan ECE to include in college applications.”
eligible: All students who have taken algebra

title: Manhattan/Staten Island Summer Health Internship Program (SHIP)
description: SHIP invites students with an interest in the health professions to apply for a summer health internship program that allows students to interact with medical professionals. The medical sites for this six-week program are in Manhattan and Staten Island.
eligible: Current sophomores, juniors, and seniors (at least 17 years old by program

title: Bronx/Westchester Summer Health Internship Program (SHIP)
description: SHIP invites students with an interest in the health professions to apply for a summer health internship program that allows students to interact with medical professionals. The medical sites for this six-week program are in the Bronx and Westchester.
eligible: Current juniors and seniors (at least 17 years old) who live or attend school

title: Event Approaching:
description: Girls Write Now Career Chat: Physicians Write Now “Join this career chat to explore the symbiosis of careers in fiction writing and medical practice. Hear from award-winning fiction novelists including Dr. Lydia Kang of the University of Nebraska Medical Center, Dr. Sayantani DasGupta of Columbia University’s Program in Narrative Medicine, and Dr. IW Gregorio of Philadelphia. This is a unique chance to understand how fiction writing can function as a remedy for career burnout, as well as how to combine creative writing with a career in medicine.”

title: Richard L. Price New York City Public High School Essay Contest
description: “The New York County Lawyers Association, Law-Related Education Committee is pleased to announce its annual Honorable Richard L. Price New York City Public High School Essay Contest. We invite students to submit essays on the following topic: “What criteria should the Supreme Court use to determine whether to overrule one of its past decisions?” Committee members will review the essays and select the winners who will receive prizes of $750 for first place, $500 for second place, $400 for third place, $300 for fourth place, and $150 each for fifth to tenth places. An awards ceremony will be held in the spring of 2025 at NYCLA.”

title: 2025 Ned Vizzini Teen Writing Contest
description: “Student writers in New York City are invited to enter the Brooklyn Public Library’s 2025 Teen Writing Contest. Entries will be accepted in two categories: Poetry and Prose. Submissions will be judged by a panel of BPL’s expert young adult librarians for creativity, style and voice and winners will receive the Ned Vizzini Teen Writing Prize with cash awards and have their pieces published in the Teen Writing Journal distributed by the Library and be honored at a celebration in June.”

title: Youth Communication Spring Writing Contest
description: “Since taking office, the Trump Administration has effected change at a dizzying pace–cutting the funding of many government agencies and programs; pursuing undocumented people; affecting trans and nonbinary people ; making diversity, equity, and inclusion efforts against the law; upending the U.S.’s relationships with other countries; and more. For this spring’s contest, we’d like writers to reflect on how their life has changed since Trump took office, if it has. Please be specific and detailed. Winning entries will be published on our website and winners will receive prizes of $150 (first place); $75 (second place); or $50 (third place).”

title: Deadline Approaching: It Starts With the Arts” Art Competition
description: “We are seeking student artwork to be featured on “It Starts With the Arts” campaign postcards that will be circulated to government officials and shared in campaign materials in support of increased, sustainable funding for arts education in our public schools. We will select three winners who, along with having their art featured, will receive $200 Visa gift cards, and be honored in-person at Face to Face 2025. Runners- up will be featured on our website and social media channels and will receive $50 Visa gift cards.”

title: Deadline Approaching:
description: Carnegie Mellon University picoCTF Hacking Competition “picoCTF is the largest cybersecurity hacking competition for middle, high school, and college students. Participants 13 years and older of all skill levels are encouraged to compete. Competitors must reverse-engineer, break, hack, decrypt, and think creatively and critically to solve the challenges and capture the digital flags. Competition prizes have eligibility requirements, but everyone is encouraged to play for fun and learning.”

title: Richard L. Price New York City Public High School Essay Contest
description: “The New York County Lawyers Association, Law-Related Education Committee is pleased to announce its annual Honorable Richard L. Price New York City Public High School Essay Contest. We invite students to submit essays on the following topic: “What criteria should the Supreme Court use to determine whether to overrule one of its past decisions?” Committee members will review the essays and select the winners who will receive prizes of $750 for first place, $500 for second place, $400 for third place, $300 for fourth place, and $150 each for fifth to tenth places. An awards ceremony will be held in the spring of 2025 at NYCLA.”

title: 2025 Ned Vizzini Teen Writing Contest
description: “Student writers in New York City are invited to enter the Brooklyn Public Library’s 2025 Teen Writing Contest. Entries will be accepted in two categories: Poetry and Prose. Submissions will be judged by a panel of BPL’s expert young adult librarians for creativity, style and voice and winners will receive the Ned Vizzini Teen Writing Prize with cash awards and have their pieces published in the Teen Writing Journal distributed by the Library and be honored at a celebration in June.”

title: Harvard Library of New York Young Readers Prize
description: “Known unofficially as “the bookworm award,” the prize is intended to encourage the kind of self-reflection, empathy, curiosity and broad-mindedness that reading for its own sake fosters. To be considered for the prize, students must submit brief essays related to their love of reading and show thoughtfulness about what they read and how it impacts them. Prize winners will be recognized and awarded a $500 gift certificate to the Center For Fiction Bookstore in Downtown Brooklyn as well as a selection of books curated by our 2025 Keynote Presenter.”

title: Congressional Black Caucus Foundation Scholarships
description: “For more than three decades the CBCF in partnership with CBC Spouses has awarded scholarships to talented and deserving students. Each year, we award more than 300 scholarships to students that demonstrate leadership ability through exemplary community service and academic talent. Our scholarship programs support students across a variety of disciplines and include the Ally Financial Public Policy Scholarship, Ally Financial Law Scholarship, CBC Spouses Education Scholarship, CBC Spouses Performing and Visual Arts Scholarships, Stephen Feinberg Scholarship Program, United Health Foundation Louis Stokes Scholarship.”
eligible: African American students who are current seniors, have a minimum GPA

title: Event Approaching: Meet the Experts: Unlocking Civic Careers
description: “Join us to meet individuals working in different aspects of civic engagement and learn about how they got into the field. You'll hear from young people from a variety of professions who are putting their passion for community service and activism to use in their careers. Civic engagement can be so many things and includes using skills like public speaking, advocacy, research, outreach, journalism, and more! You’ll walk away with more knowledge about different civic pathways and how being involved in civic engagement and/or advocacy helps build invaluable skills no matter what jobs you end up pursuing in the future.”

title: Event Approaching: Engineering & Engineering Technology at SUNY
description: “Learn about SUNY's two- and four-year engineering and engineering technology programs through this special-focus group information session, specifically designed for high school juniors and their families. We will explore the magnitude of SUNY's engineering programs, how to prepare for an engineering career, and discuss the employment outlook. This session will also include an admissions overview and time for questions.”

title: StuyHacks Event
description: “StuyHacks is a hackathon run by Stuyvesant HS students. We strive to introduce Stuy high-schoolers to the world of hackathons, programming, and general technology. Students will create coding projects that will be judged on and can receive prizes! There will also be workshops (topics ranging from APIs to Site Reliability Engineering!) for students to attend and meet industry professionals. We are hosting it in-person on Saturday, 3/29 from 8AM to 4PM and require attendees to register through this form. The deadline to register is Saturday, 3/15. The only thing you will need to bring is your own laptop and charger, and you are set. There will be food, swag, and lots of fun! If you are interested in coming, please register using this form to attend! Share with friends! If you have any questions, feel free to reach out to stuyhacks.marketing@gmail.com!
eligible: All Stuy students – Attendance wil lbe capped at 50 participants - first come,

title: Deadline Approaching: TryEngineering Summer Institute Program
description: “Innovative design challenges, along with exciting field trips, personalized instruction, weekend activities, and advice from industry guest speakers, make the TryEngineering Summer Institute a program like no other.” This scholarship that offers financial assistance to students interested in attending the TryEngineering Summer Institute. Awards for 50% - 100% of the full tuition cost are offered to accepted students.

title: Summer Careers Exploration Program
description: “This paid summer internship program is a fantastic opportunity for eligible students to gain real-world experience in fields like healthcare, law, finance, research, and public service. Summer Careers Exploration Program Details Internship Duration: July 7 – August 16, 2025 Stipend: $1,200 for completing the 100-hour minimum Bonus Scholarship: Up to $3,000 based on performance Eligibility: Students 16 years or older who identify as Asian, as defined by the U.S. Census Students will have the opportunity to intern in a variety of fields, including healthcare, law, finance, research, and public service.

title: Deadline Approaching: Personal Finance Video Contest
description: All students may submit a short (45 seconds - two minutes) video on personal finance topics (check link for examples) – the top prize is $2,500.

title: Baruch College Stock Market Challenge
description: “Participants will explore the complexities of the stock market and gain insight into the principles of saving and investing, all within an interactive classroom environment. They will then put their newfound knowledge to the test as they compete against fellow high school students in an engaging four-week stock market challenge. Working in small teams, students will collaborate to analyze company and industry data and pricing information throughout the competition. The program is offered at no cost to schools and students, with exciting prizes and awards up for grabs.”

title: GenHERation Summer Intensive
description: “Designed to equip students with the tools to succeed in the classroom, college, and beyond, the GenHERation® Summer Intensive is a rigorous, dynamic, and immersive experience that inspires young women to achieve their personal and professional goals by encouraging them to think big and push the limits of what’s possible. During the GenHERation® Summer Intensive, students will: ● Learn from the most innovative companies in America through panel discussions, mentoring sessions, and custom-designed challenges ● Meet powerful leaders from Fortune 500 companies, tech giants, retailers, government agencies, and sports franchises ● Participate in skill-building simulations to practically apply learnings and real- world business practices ● Collaborate as a team to develop and present a venture to a panel of community leaders ● Explore different career paths to discover future job and internship opportunities ● Refine their leadership, creativity, critical thinking, communication, entrepreneurial, analytical, and problem-solving skills”
location: Sidwell Friends School,Wash. D,C. or Harvard WestlakeSchool, , L.A, CA.

title: Questbridge College Prep Scholars Program
description: “The College Prep Scholars Program equips high-achieving high school juniors from low-income backgrounds with the knowledge, confidence, and resources to apply to top colleges. Awards for College Prep Scholars may include: -A full scholarship to a college summer program hosted by Yale, Emory, UChicago, and others -Quest for Excellence Awards, such as $1,000 for a new laptop or other resources to help the student enhance their college application, -Exclusive access to a QuestBridge National College Admissions Conference — an invite-only event featuring workshops and a college fair with our college partners -Personalized college essay feedback, campus visits or other opportunities from QuestBridge college partners, along with specialized guidance and resources for the college application process -Peer-to-peer support in an online community
eligible: Current juniors who excel academically and are low-income

title: Event Approaching: Meet the Experts: Unlocking Civic Careers
description: “Join us to meet individuals working in different aspects of civic engagement and learn about how they got into the field. You'll hear from young people from a variety of professions who are putting their passion for community service and activism to use in their careers. Civic engagement can be so many things and includes using skills like public speaking, advocacy, research, outreach, journalism, and more! You’ll walk away with more knowledge about different civic pathways and how being involved in civic engagement and/or advocacy helps build invaluable skills no matter what jobs you end up pursuing in the future.”

title: Sadie Nash Summer Leadership Institute
description: “SNLP focuses on the intellectual and personal development of young women and gender-expansive youth, with a focus on youth of color. Participants explore their leadership skills and build a strong community. Their programming also provides networking opportunities, boosts college applications, and provides youth with a safe, enriching, and creative experience to explore their identity and power. Students take part in workshops about feminism, identity, and social justice; meet accomplished women and gender-expansive elected officials, business owners, and artists. All participants are eligible to receive up to a $450 stipend based on attendance.”
eligible: All students who identify as female and/or gender-expansive youth

title: Young Leaders Summit (YLS)
description: “The Young Leaders Summit (YLS), presented by the Youth Leadership Consortium (YLC), is designed to give young leaders the practical tools they need to successfully apply to top universities, have full access to scholarship and financial aid opportunities, and set a course for academic and career success. Attendees will enhance their leadership abilities and expand their professional networks by participating in college and career workshops and interacting with college students and professionals who serve as their mentors.”
eligible: Low-income juniors with a minimum GPA of 80
location: Hybrid (virtual, then in-person at the Princeton University campus)

title: FIRE Free Speech Leadership Summit
description: Join the next generation of free speech leaders for the inaugural FIRE Free Speech Leadership Summit! Students will gain a thorough understanding of free speech, including what it is, why it is important, and how it empowers all of us to solve real- world problems and achieve our full potential. The summit will strike the perfect balance of academic rigor, immersive activities, leadership-building, and fun. Through a shared interest in free speech, students will make lifelong memories with new friends.
cost: Responsible for traveling costs (Limited Need-Based Scholarships)

title: Mark Levine Campaign Fellowship
description: “The Mark Levine for Comptroller campaign is hiring Campaign Fellows to support our petitioning efforts, followed by our Get Out the Vote campaign ahead of the June 24, 2025 primary. The Campaign Fellows will work with the Field Director and Field Organizers in implementing the campaign’s GOTV plan and voter contact strategies, focusing on direct voter contact programs and event recruitment. Additionally, Campaign Fellows will work with the Communications Director to draft and disseminate messaging for campaign content. As a Campaign Fellow, you’ll receive direct guidance and professional development from experienced political organizers, strategists, and campaign leaders. You’ll have the opportunity to gain hands-on experience in a high-stakes political environment while receiving personalized training based on your career goals.”

title: Deadline Approaching: Create Real Impact Contest
description: “Create an original work (video, music, creative writing, or artwork) showcasing your idea for a SOLUTION or STRATEGY to end reckless and distracted driving. Distracted driving is anything that takes your eyes off the road, your hands off the wheel, your mind off your driving, or keeps your ears from being alert to your surroundings. The top prize is $1,000.”
eligible: Students who are at least 14 years old

title: Port Authority Earth Day Poster Contest
description: “Create a poster for Earth Day! The overall theme of the 2025 Poster Contest is ‘Our Power, Our Planet’. The submission should educate viewers about the importance of increasing renewable energy (solar, wind, hydroelectric, geothermal, and tidal generated energy). Each winner will receive (1) Port Authority issued trophy and a family pack (4 individuals) gift card for 2 hours of bowling and refreshments at Frames Bowling located within the Port Authority Midtown Bus Terminal.”

title: The Jewish Museum High School Video Workshop
description: “In this free vacation week program, students will work with a teaching artist to explore video as an artistic medium. Students will use video as a form of personal expression and will work in small groups to create films. The class will explore how to use video in creative ways, from pre-production to developing camera techniques and, finally, editing. No prior experience necessary—beginners are welcome!”

title: The Jewish Museum Teen Intern Program
description: “Students will work with Museum educators to facilitate programs for families and other audiences, assist with special projects, and explore art and culture through the Museum’s collections. After participating in a training program in the spring of 2025, interns will begin working at the Museum during the 2025-26 school year. Interns will receive a stipend for their participation. All applicants must submit an application form and one letter of recommendation ”

title: Deadline Approaching: Zero Waste Island Internship
description: “Zero Waste Island is a collaboration between Earth Matter NY and the Trust for Governors Island to create a plan to increase waste diversion with the goal of zero waste. As a Zero Waste Island (ZWI) intern, you’re a key player. You’ll work on a team of five interns to implement this plan. The experience provides a comprehensive overview of sustainable waste management practices and a chance to work in a real world setting with diverse partners toward a shared vision.”

title: Van Cortland Park Green Scholars Internships
description: 1 – Wilderness Warriors “This session will bring participants close to nature, learning about the plants and animals around us, learning skills such as how to build a shelter, camping 101, and setting out into VCP to go on some hikes. This internship will take place over 4 Saturdays from 10am to 12pm with a final overnight camping adventure in Van Cortlandt Park. Upon completion of this session, participants will receive a $100 stipend.”

title: Event Approaching: Engineering & Engineering Technology at SUNY
description: “Learn about SUNY's two- and four-year engineering and engineering technology programs through this special-focus group information session, specifically designed for high school juniors and their families. We will explore the magnitude of SUNY's engineering programs, how to prepare for an engineering career, and discuss the employment outlook. This session will also include an admissions overview and time for questions.”

title: StuyHacks Event
description: “StuyHacks is a hackathon run by Stuyvesant HS students. We strive to introduce Stuy high-schoolers to the world of hackathons, programming, and general technology. Students will create coding projects that will be judged on and can receive prizes! There will also be workshops (topics ranging from APIs to Site Reliability Engineering!) for students to attend and meet industry professionals. We are hosting it in-person on Saturday, 3/29 from 8AM to 4PM and require attendees to register through this form. The deadline to register is Saturday, 3/15. The only thing you will need to bring is your own laptop and charger, and you are set. There will be food, swag, and lots of fun! If you are interested in coming, please register using this form to attend! Share with friends! If you have any questions, feel free to reach out to stuyhacks.marketing@gmail.com!
eligible: All Stuy students – Attendance wil lbe capped at 50 participants - first come,

title: Kode with Klossy
description: All female students are invited to engage in online coding and other computer science activities over the summer. Students may choose among three camp programs - web development, mobile applications, machine learning, or data science. A series of two– week programs are offered, beginning June 2. No prior knowledge is necessary.

title: First Deadline Approaching:
description: Write The World Songwriting Competition 2025 “This songwriting competition invites teen writers around the world to submit their original lyrics for a chance to win $100. You don't need to be a performer to enter, but there is also an option to submit a recording of your song - with another $100 prize for the Best Performance!”

title: Octavia Project Summer Program: Science Fiction/Fantasy Workshops
description: “The Octavia Project Summer Institute is a free five-week-long program for people who are into science fiction/fantasy and interested in workshops that combine art, writing, science, and tech. Participants will create an online multimedia portfolio; strengthen skills in digital-media, art, and writing; and have access to a network of professional women and opportunities for fellowships and other leadership positions.”
eligible: Students who identify as female, trans, nonbinary, or non-conforming and
location: Pratt Institute in Fort Greene, Brooklyn

title: Deadline Approaching: Create Real Impact Contest
description: “Create an original work (video, music, creative writing, or artwork) showcasing your idea for a SOLUTION or STRATEGY to end reckless and distracted driving. Distracted driving is anything that takes your eyes off the road, your hands off the wheel, your mind off your driving, or keeps your ears from being alert to your surroundings. The top prize is $1,000.”
eligible: Students who are at least 14 years old

title: Deadline Approaching: Personal Finance Video Contest
description: All students may submit a short (45 seconds - two minutes) video on personal finance topics (check link for examples) – the top prize is $2,500.

title: Opportunity Music Project
description: “Opportunity Music Project is a 100% tuition-free comprehensive music education program for students in underserved communities. Students will receive weekly private lessons on violin, viola, cello, or double bass. Families interested in applying must demonstrate significant financial need and must fall within 0-80% of AMI under the OMP Income Guidelines in order to qualify.” Students should have some experience in playing an instrument, and will need an audition video and written statement, as well as a passion for music.
eligible: All students with significant financial need

title: First Deadline Approaching:
description: Write The World Songwriting Competition 2025 “This songwriting competition invites teen writers around the world to submit their original lyrics for a chance to win $100. You don't need to be a performer to enter, but there is also an option to submit a recording of your song - with another $100 prize for the Best Performance!”

description: “Create an original work (video, music, creative writing, or artwork) showcasing your idea for a SOLUTION or STRATEGY to end reckless and distracted driving. The submission should educate viewers about the importance of increasing renewable energy (solar, wind, hydroelectric, geothermal, and tidal generated energy). Each winner will receive (1) Port Authority issued trophy and a family pack (4 individuals) gift card for 2 hours of bowling and refreshments at Frames Bowling located within the Port Authority Midtown Bus Terminal.”

title: Baruch College Stock Market Challenge
description: “Participants will explore the complexities of the stock market and gain insight into the principles of saving and investing, all within an interactive classroom environment. They will then put their newfound knowledge to the test as they compete against fellow high school students in an engaging four-week stock market challenge. Working in small teams, students will collaborate to analyze company and industry data and pricing information throughout the competition. The program is offered at no cost to schools and students, with exciting prizes and awards up for grabs.”

title: Stuyvesant Alumni Association Scholarships
description: The Stuyvesant Alumni Association awards more than 40 scholarships totaling more than $100,000. These scholarships are available only to Stuyvesant seniors. (There is one scholarship available to juniors, The Carol and Theodore Lerner Award for Creativity). Some answers to common questions on the FAFSA/providing financial information:  If the students have already provided their colleges with the CSS Profile, they can submit that form in lieu of the FAFSA, but only if they did not submit a FAFSA.  If the student never filed either the CSS or FAFSA because they are not a citizen or legal permanent resident, they should be sure to state it's because they are not a citizen or legal permanent resident in the Financial aid information question on the application. All information submitted by the students in their application is kept to the strictest confidentiality. All of the staff and any scholarship committee members, as well as any other additional parties who read the scholarship applications, must sign and adhere to a confidentiality agreement.  Students must provide the financial information listed in the checklist in some form, even if they submit a one-page doc with all of it listed out. If you have any questions, please email alumni@shsaa.org.
eligible: All Seniors (one scholarship is available to juniors)

title: Deadline Approaching: Islamic Scholarship Fund
description: “Students who are Muslim or active members of the Muslim community may apply for the Islamic Scholarship Fund. The ISF awards multiple scholarships each year ranging from $3,000 - $10,000. Students must submit applications including essay questions, work samples, and letters of recommendation, and must also be majoring in an ISF-supported field related to media or politics.”
eligible: All students who identify as Muslim

title: N.L.H.A. Air Cares Scholarship
description: “The NLHA Education Fund will offer scholarships, one in recognition of one of the nation’s largest affordable rental housing providers and three in memory of three dedicated housing professionals and active NLHA members. The Air Gives Opportunity Scholarship is directed to eligible applicants living in or coming from affordable housing who demonstrate both merit and need and are pursuing an undergraduate degree. The William F. Gandert Memorial Vocational Scholarship is to benefit an eligible graduating high school senior or returning student who demonstrates both merit and need to pursue educational opportunities in a specific trade or vocation.”
eligible: Students who live in federally-assisted housing

title: NACAC In-Person College Fair
description: This large college fair includes many participating schools, along with sessions about various aspects of the college admissions process.

title: Queens Public Library College Readiness Fair
description: “Join us at QPL's Central Library for an exciting College Fair to provide students and families with valuable information about higher education opportunities! This event is open to the public and will feature representatives from CUNY, SUNY, and private colleges and universities. The first 100 attendees for each session will receive a prize!    Meet with admissions officers from multiple colleges and universities to learn about the programs and financial aid opportunities they offer.    Join workshops on the College Admissions Process for High School Students and Applying for College Financial Aid.    Visit the Teen Center College Room: Get to know the College Readiness team and discover the library’s free college readiness services, such as one-to-one college coaching, year-round workshops, and more! Students may attend either Session 1 or Session 2 (not both)

title: College Now Summer Courses @ City College & Hunter College
description: The CUNY College Now Program at campuses throughout the city offers free college-level science, math, & humanities classes to current juniors & seniors (sophomores may be eligible for some programs depending on requirements). The application deadlines and course times vary for each individual campus - students should explore their options and apply ASAP. See the links below for more detailed information about programs and courses. 1-City College of New York
location: Virtual or at City College – 160 Convent Avenue, Manhattan

title: Alfred University Summer Institutes & Camps
description: “Our summer programs provide students with opportunities to learn more about specific career fields, to sample life on a college campus, and to meet other students with similar interests as well as academic and athletic abilities. These weeklong Summer High School Institutes will offer a look into each discipline taught, guided by the Faculty of Alfred University. High school institutes include programs for astronomy, creative writing, engineering, music, 3D printing, and more. Sports camps include lacrosse, swimming, football, basketball, and more. ”
location: In-Person at Alfred University, Alfred NY

title: The Long Island University Summer Honors Institute
description: “The LIU Summer Institute offers two-week intensive classes in a wide variety of fields (ranging from Computer Science to Game Design to Health Professions to Sports Management Camp; and more) at their campus in July.”

title: AoPS Academy Summer Virtual Campus
description: “Since 1993, Art of Problem Solving has helped train the next generation of intellectual leaders. Hundreds of thousands of our students have gone on to attend prestigious universities, win global math competitions, and achieve success in highly competitive careers. Designed by PhDs from MIT, Princeton, and Stanford, our curriculum has helped thousands of motivated students develop the problem-solving skills they need to succeed in school and beyond. With a blend of a video-based live classroom, captivating instructors, and interactive, collaborative content, your student will be fully absorbed in our virtual Math & English classes.”

title: YEP! NYC Entrepreneurship Incubator –Information Session at Stuy
description: “If you’ve ever thought about starting your own venture, meeting inspiring entrepreneurs, or connecting with Columbia University students, YEP! NYC’s Entrepreneurship Incubator is for you! Led by Columbia students, this seven-week program will help you develop your own business idea, gain real-world entrepreneurial skills, and hear from innovative speakers—all while enjoying great food. No prior experience is expected or required!” There will be an Information Session at Stuyvesant (Lecture Hall B) after 10th period on Wednesday, March 19th – all are welcome.
date: Saturdays, March 29 – May 3 (11:00 AM – 12:30 PM); Info Session - March

title: Rock the Street Wall Street Finance Program
description: Rock the Street Wall Street invites female students to apply for this series of in- person sessions for Stuyvesant students, taking place after-school at Stuyvesant. Participants meet with female finance industry professionals and learn about personal finance, financial businesses, and more. Participants also receive help in finding summer internships in this field of business. “We are excited to be starting another cohort of Rock the Street, Wall Street programming at Stuyvesant this year! We have a group of women from Invesco Corporation excited to meet the great group of students at Stuyvesant and share their time and knowledge with you all! Here are the details:” --Once a week Spring Term Workshops (& a possible Field Trip to Invesco Headquarters (near Stuy): Tuesdays, 4:00 - 5:00 PM from March 25 – April 29. Please register on our RTSWS App to participate. The app can be accessed via the link below to access their document and then scan the QR code in the document for instructions. Join our 2025 ‘Rock The Street, Wall Street’ cohort at Stuyvesant!
eligible: All female identifying and non-binary students
date: March 25, April 1, April 8, April 22, and April 29 - Tuesdays at Stuy in Room

title: NYC Parks Kids in Motion City Seasonal Aide
description: “NYC Parks is home to free concerts, world-class sports events, and cultural festivals. Public Programs, a division of NYC Parks operates the Kids in Motion program at an estimated 100 locations. Kids in Motion staff (City Seasonal Aides) lead four to seven hours of free activities for children per day, including organized sports, games, fitness demos, guided walks, board games, water games and more! Aides will be paid $18.54/hr.”
eligible: Students over 16 or 18, varies by borough
cost: Hired candidates who are not currently employed by the City will be subject to a
deadline: Rolling Basis (until the position is filled)

title: 1- Seeds of Fortune Girls Start Up Business Accelerator
description: “This one-year program helps HS Scholars access the tools, resources, and networks necessary to supercharge social impact ideas. We help them formulate their ideas and provide the necessary feedback and funding streams to turn their ideas into action. At the end of the program, students will compete for an all-expenses-paid trip to Miami, FL, where 3 lucky winners could receive up to $3,000 in capital funding!”
eligible: Current juniors, household income $125,000 or less
deadline: May 8 (or until all spots are filled)

title: 2- Seeds of Fortune Business Innovation Research Fellowship
description: “The Hybrid Innovation Research Fellowship is a unique hybrid program that pairs high school students with top companies such as Chanel, Mount Sinai, Dentons, and Nasdaq. It provides hands-on experience, opportunities to conduct groundbreaking research, and participation in real-world case studies. Scholars will create virtual consultant groups with a partner corporation for 10 weeks in the spring and summer of their junior year. In the Fall and Spring of Senior year, students will receive assistance with the college application process and admission.”
eligible: Current juniors, household income $125,000 or less

title: School of Business @ Stevens Institute of Technology Internships
description: “The School of Business at Stevens Institute of Technology is offering three virtual research programs for high school students this summer in Organizational Leadership, Finance and Investing, and Quantitative Finance. These programs are designed for ambitious high school students interested in pursuing careers in business and offer a unique opportunity to develop foundational skills for future success in higher education and beyond.” 1 - Finance and Investing 1-Week Intensive Virtual Bootcamp “The Stevens School of Business is offering a one-week intensive boot camp, where high school students will take a deep dive into the world of finance and investment, gaining hands-on experience with tools used by top financial professionals. The program simulates the experience of a professional portfolio manager. Throughout the week, students will learn the fundamentals of investing, including equity analysis, risk assessment, and portfolio diversification. This program provides an excellent foundation for those considering a future finance or investment management career.”

title: Queens Public Library College Readiness Fair
description: “Join us at QPL's Central Library for an exciting College Fair to provide students and families with valuable information about higher education opportunities! This event is open to the public and will feature representatives from CUNY, SUNY, and private colleges and universities. The first 100 attendees for each session will receive a prize!    Meet with admissions officers from multiple colleges and universities to learn about the programs and financial aid opportunities they offer.    Join workshops on the College Admissions Process for High School Students and Applying for College Financial Aid.    Visit the Teen Center College Room: Get to know the College Readiness team and discover the library’s free college readiness services, such as one-to-one college coaching, year-round workshops, and more! Students may attend either Session 1 or Session 2 (not both)

title: NACAC In-Person College Fair
description: This large college fair includes many participating schools, along with sessions about various aspects of the college admissions process.

title: Youthbridge New York Fellowship Program
description: YouthBridge-NY offers a two-year Fellowship program, in which juniors and seniors from diverse backgrounds participate in intensive training for leadership and diversity. Throughout the first year of the program, first-year teen Fellows participate in skill- building workshops and team-based learning opportunities; then second year Bridgers are immersed in experiential learning opportunities and mentoring with successful professionals.”

title: Brooklyn District Attorney Summer internship
description: “The Brooklyn District Attorney’s Summer High School Internship offers an overview of one of the largest DA’s offices in the country. Selected students will participate in workshops, conversations, and presentations regarding law enforcement. Interactive participation will be required. The program is open to students who live and/or attend school in Brooklyn. Applicants will be selected for Summer and must be able to commit to the entire duration of the internship. The Summer internship will run from July 7th through August 1st , from 10:00am-3pm. Students will receive a $150 stipend weekly.”
eligible: Current sophomores & juniors who live in Brooklyn

title: Griptape Learning Challenge
description: “The GripTape Learning Challenge provides you with financial support to pursue an interest or learn something you’re passionate about. In addition to funding, GripTape pairs you with a Champion to support you throughout your 10-week Learning Challenge. A Champion is a person who believes in you no matter what and is genuinely curious about you and your interests. And they help you think by asking great questions while never telling you what you should do.”
eligible: All students who are at least 14 years old

title: AFS-USA Study Abroad Programs
description: “When you study abroad with AFS, you’ll do far more than travel to a new country – our immersion programs provide authentic intercultural experiences where you will build meaningful connections with your host family, community, and school. You will learn about the world in ways that cannot be found in a guidebook! Get ready to get out of your comfort zone and experience an abundance of growth over the course of your exchange program and beyond.”

title: Event Approaching:
description: Breakdown: The Promise of Decay: FREE Teen Tour and Activity at the Staten Island Museum “For Teens by Teens! Tour the Staten Island Museum’s newest exhibit, Breakdown, led by the museum’s Bloomberg Arts intern Latifa Labdouni. Investigate the world of fungi, mold, and microplastics through the eyes of artists and scientists. Breakdown features contemporary artwork, objects from the museum’s collection, and scientific innovations in the curious world of decomposition. After the tour, Latifa will lead participants in creating an exhibit-based zine, or a small artist’s book, with folded paper, drawings, and personal notes. The tour and activity are FREE for students with student ID and will take place from 1:00–3:00pm.”
location: Staten Island Museum (1000 Richmond Terrace, Building A, Staten Island)

title: Event Approaching:
description: Staten Island Museum FREE Teen Drawing Workshop “Are you working on new pieces for your portfolio, or do you simply want to try drawing from observation? In this FREE still life drawing workshop, participants will work from a dynamic installation including taxidermy, fungi, and other specimens from the museum’s natural science collection, composing the objects on the page, observing complex shapes and negative space, and examining the lights and darks to shade the drawing with graphite pencils. No experience necessary. Participants are invited to view the Museum’s newest exhibition, Breakdown: The Promise of Decay in addition to the drawing workshop. The workshop is FREE for students with student ID and will take place from 2:00–4:00pm.”
location: Staten Island Museum (1000 Richmond Terrace, Building A, Staten Island)

title: Cooper Hewitt Design Career Fair
description: “High school students, thinking about a career in design and wondering where to start? Join us for the Cooper Hewitt Design Career Fair! This annual event welcomes 9th -12th grade students to speak with National Design Award winners, guest designers, and colleges on the many pathways toward design. Designers from every discipline including fashion, architecture, product design, graphic design, UX, and more will be available to discuss everything from mentorship and college to the future of the field. Creative careers are growing fast to meet the needs of our changing world. See how these jobs fit into different industries and make an impact!”

title: Van Cortlandt Park Garden 2 Market Internship
description: “This 8 week internship is for anyone interested in our food system and covers topics from growing to selling and eating. During their time in the program, interns work in our garden learning about horticulture, composting, and the social and community aspects of a garden. They spend time exploring food justice issues and learning about the business of running a weekly farm stand: learning everything from ordering and pricing to stocking the table and completing a sale. They gain communication skills and become advocates for healthy eating in their community. The internship includes many chances to taste and cook new foods and recipes- because no internship about food is complete without eating! Interns obtain their Servsafe Food Handlers Certificate, which is valid for three years. A tuition free, 3 credit college course through SUNY Environmental Science and Forestry (ESF) is available for interested first year and returning interns. Interns are paid $16.50/hour, returning interns are paid $17/hour.”

title: Wyckoff Farmhouse Garden Apprentice
description: “The Youth Garden Apprentice Program (GAP) provides first-hand experience cultivating organic vegetables, herbs, flowers, and perennials on our 1.25 acre site. The garden includes raised beds for seasonal vegetables and medicinal herbs, as well as fruit and nut trees, wildflowers, roses, and native plants. You will learn alongside qualified gardeners/urban farmers, fellow apprentices, and community members of all ages. Key Apprentice Responsibilities    Farming and gardening: planting seeds and starts, harvesting vegetables, weeding, watering, composting    Engaging with community members, volunteers, and visitors    Participating in weekly workshops and field trips, facilitating a workshop for peers    Assisting with special events, including the weekly farmstand, public community workshops, seasonal programs and open volunteer days”

title: NYC Parks Kids in Motion City Seasonal Aide
description: “NYC Parks is home to free concerts, world-class sports events, and cultural festivals. Public Programs, a division of NYC Parks operates the Kids in Motion program at an estimated 100 locations. Kids in Motion staff (City Seasonal Aides) lead four to seven hours of free activities for children per day, including organized sports, games, fitness demos, guided walks, board games, water games and more! Aides will be paid $18.54/hr.”

Upon completion of 50 hours of service over the summer, teens receive a $1,000 stipend. ”

Students will learn about topical environmental issues, hear from top design experts in the field and work with biomaterials in designing and producing objects that address today’s environmental challenges.”

From April through June, students will meet Museum scientists and engage with a range of scientific topics, including evolution and Earth and planetary sciences, to nurture their innate curiosity and help them generate new questions about the natural world. Another available course is Oceans at Risk: Protecting Marine Biodiversity.”
location: American Museum of Natural History, 200 Central Park West, Manhattan

This session will feature two guest speakers who have made incredible strides in the field of space science. They will share their journeys, challenges, and insights into careers in astronomy. Whether you are curious about space, interested in STEM careers, or looking to be inspired, this event is for you!”

title: Actuarial Science and Programming Summer Camps
description: “Our Actuarial Science Summer Camps are week-long intensive programs for rising high school seniors designed to help them decide if they’re interested in actuarial careers, specifically actuarial science or computer programming. Leveraging industry connections and alumni suggestions, we’ve forged an authentic experience that features interaction with actuaries and an introduction to relevant software and content. We will have two one-week long camps: a Computer and Data Science Summer Camp and an Actuarial Science Camp.”

title: Center for Architecture Summer Programs
description: “Summer Programs give curious kids the opportunity to dive into specific interests in architecture and test out their own ideas. Each program explores a different theme through art and building activities, design challenges, guided investigations of architectural examples, and site visits. Classes are taught in a group setting and students engage independently to design and build projects. Programs include Digital Design: Tiny Houses, Architectural Design Studio, and Drawing Architecture.”

title: UCLA Global Medical Brigades Science and Medicine Competition
description: “Calling all aspiring healthcare innovators! Step into the world of global health and tackle real-world challenges that test your problem-solving, critical thinking, and teamwork skills. In the Preliminary Round, each participant will individually tackle 35 multiple-choice questions and a short-answer question designed to evaluate their knowledge in science, medicine, general topics, and problem-solving. In the Final Round, your team will present a solution to a critical global health problem live on Zoom to a panel of judges. Showcase your creativity, collaboration, and ability to drive meaningful change in global healthcare.”

title: DNA Learning Center In-Person Spring Break Day Camps
description: “Camp courses include DNA Science. The DNA Learning Center is the world's first science center devoted entirely to genetics education. We offer fun and challenging camps for science enthusiasts entering 6th–12th grades. location: Cold Spring Harbor (Long Island) or Sleepy Hollow

title: Manhattan Medical Immersion Camp
description: “The Manhattan Medical Immersion Camp is a week-long, one-of-a-kind, hands-on summer program that allows high school students to perform procedures on real cadavers under the tutelage of physicians from a variety of medical specialties (anesthesia, dermatology, orthopaedic surgery, vascular surgery, radiology, etc). Students will learn to perform advanced procedures such as rotator cuff repairs and total knee replacements using the same equipment that physicians use, while practicing on cadavers that are not fully embalmed in formaldehyde. They will also learn about the medical device industry. This will all be under the direct supervision of board-certified surgeons.”

Camp courses include Forensic Crime Lab, DNA Science, Genome Science, DNA Barcoding, Biocoding, and more.”

title: Rosetta Institute of Biomedical Research Workshops
description: “The Rosetta Institute of Biomedical Research is entirely focused on creating highly regarded workshops for high-achieving high school students. Our instructors are PhD- level scientists who are actively engaged in medical research, and they expose students to cutting-edge molecular biology through engaging lectures, real-world labs, and independent projects. Our in-person workshops at various universities include AI- enhanced bioinformatics, Molecular Neuroscience, Bioinformatics of Cancer, Molecular Biology of Cancer, Molecular Immunology, Molecular Biology of Aging, Immunologic Bioinormatics, Neurological Bioinformatics, and Biomedical Research. Our online workshops are separate concurrent sessions of Medicinal Chemistry, Medical Bioinformatics, and Introduction to Cellular and Molecular Medicine.”

title: Event Approaching: Unlimited @ MoMath - Rhythm, Harmony, and Form:
description: Pop Music and the Fibonacci Sequence “Mathematical patterns naturally appear everywhere — even in music! Whether it’s intentional or not, songwriters often create music in which we can find the Fibonacci sequence and the Golden Ratio. Come explore how these mathematical concepts show up in some pop songs you know. Does this increase their impact and give them more emotional power? Join us to discuss how math lends music harmony and beauty, discover that math and music aren’t so different, and hear some great songs along the way!”
location: National Museum of Mathematics (225 Fifth Avenue)

title: Hearst High School Media Internship

The program offers students the opportunity to develop the knowledge, skills, and network necessary to prepare for college and to break into the media and entertainment industry. Students will be compensated at $16.50 an hour.”

Learn how to apply technical elements of theater such as lighting design, audio engineering, videography, carpentry, and production design, to live and recorded stage productions from the pros at The Apollo” This is a paid opportunity.

title: Think for Yourself Essay Contest
description: “Applicants are required to write a 600–800-word essay on one of five prompts. Four winners will receive Scholarship Prizes. One winner will receive $8,000 and three winners will receive a Scholarship Prize in the amount up to $2,000.”

description: “How can poetry be an effective response to current events and the issues impacting our communities? How can journalism and poetry help us make connections between global issues and our local and personal contexts? Students are invited to explore these questions and make their voices heard in their entries to the Fighting Words Poetry Contest.” The top prize is $300 and a publication on the Pulitzer Center website.

The Brandon Hendricks Scholarship was created to carry out his vision for a better Bronx by enabling young folks in the community to receive a college education. Two students will win $20,000 each to use toward their education over a four-year period. In order to continue receiving $5,000 per school year completed, scholarship winners need to maintain a 3.0 GPA and be involved in one extracurricular activity at school (clubs, sports, etc.). ” Applicants will need to provide written statements, resume, a letter of recommendation, and participate in an interview if chosen to be a finalist.

With on-campus housing and commuter options available, this pre-college program is crafted to redefine the summer and set the stage for students' future success.”

They are designed to supplement student learning and encourage them to explore their interests and come away from the experience brighter, bolder, and ready to take on the world.” Programs include the NextGen Leadership Institute, Health and Society Institute, Athena Summer Innovation Institute, Summer Food Institute (Institutes are 3 weeks), and Pre-Baccalaureate Program (7 weeks).

Or, join us on campus for a weeklong summer intensive covering admissions strategy, essay writing, test prep and more.”

Gain exclusive insights into the accounting field through tours of top organizations and private-sector companies. Build teamwork and collaboration skills through engaging in group projects and case studies. Stay connected with year-round programming that supports your personal and professional development through workshops, mentoring, and career resources.”

title: Student Election Day Poll Worker Jobs:
description: Students 17 and older may apply to become paid poll workers for the June 24 th and November 4th election days at voting sites throughout the city. Students will receive $250 for working a full election day. They will also be paid for two training sessions leading up to the elections (paid only if they subsequently work on an election day). Here is the link to the application page to view: Student Poll Worker Application Students can apply to work in whichever borough they reside in or prefer – applications should be submitted to that borough Board of Elections office (email addresses for each office are in the link below). --Queens voting sites: For students interested in working in Queens, it is recommended that potential applicants complete the attached application and return it by mail or hand deliver to the office (118-35 Queens Blvd, 11th floor). --Manhattan voting sites: Completed applications can be sent to theStudent Poll Worker Liaison, Afi Bush (ABush@boenyc.gov). Required training will be available and students notified upon completing and submitting their applications. Please note this Election all poll workers will be required to take two training classes. The Basic poll Worker Inspector class along with a Rank Choice Voting class. NYC Elected Office elections utilize Rank Choice as a method of vote casting. This allows a voter to select a tiered selection of candidates as their priority choice. See Ranked choice voting | NYC Board of Elections. Work Schedules are limited to Election days. Primary Election June 24, 2025 (Stuy graduation day!) and General Election on November 4, 2025.
eligible: All students 17 and older by June 24th
date: June 24 and November 4; 2 training sessions (paid) are also required

title: Deadline Approaching: Summer Meals Program Paid Apprentice Program

Mills (MMills@schools.nyc.gov) and Samillah Feliciano (SFeliciano12@schools.nyc.gov) until close of business (5:00pm) on Friday, March 28, 2025 to be eligible for an interview. Be sure to include your contact information, e-mail address, home address, phone number, age and grade. Selected candidates will be notified of interview by mail. Apprentice workers will earn $16.50 per hour and work from 7:30am - 1:30pm (with 30 minutes for lunch),”Monday - Friday.

Dive into key aspects of the college application and transition process, such as essay writing, building your college list, and applying for financial aid and scholarships.”

They learn the practical aspects of government as it exists in New York State, and come to recognize that the individual is integral to the character and success of government. They also participate in physical fitness, teamwork and other activities under the guidance of American Legion counselors and U.S. Marines. If you or a youth you know would like to apply, contact your local American Legion Post to inquire about sponsoring you to Boys State. title: One Deadline Approaching: Urban Ecology Teen Internship
description: “Urban Ecology Teen Internship (Urban Eco-Teens) is a summer paid internship for high school students that prepares a new generation of students for college, stewardship, and careers in the environmental fields. All interns work in the park, alongside horticulturists and natural areas restoration staff from Van Cortlandt Park. They also go on nature-focused field trips, and explore green career opportunities with natural resource professionals. Tuition free, 3 credit college course through SUNY Environmental Science and Forestry (ESF), EST 135 Introduction to Climate Justice, offered to qualified first year interns. Returning interns can take EST 296 | Comics and the Drawn Environment or EHS 150 | US History & Environmental Health. The course will be asynchronous. Interns typically work 18 hours per week and are paid $16.50/hour. Second year interns are paid $17.00/hour.”

title: New York Road Runners Run for the Future Program

Topics include nutrition, mental wellness, body image, and self-awareness. NYRR staff and women leaders from our community lead interactive, informative educational sessions that provide a safe space and rich learning experience for our young women. Participants receive a MetroCard for in-person practices, New Balance running gear and sneakers, healthy snacks, and a fitness kit to support their training during the season. The new runners are required to maintain an 80% attendance rate and complete their first 5K race at the end of the program. At the conclusion of the program, participants receive a wellness kit.”

There are many exciting opportunities for you to take advantage of, and opportunities to grow within the program throughout the seasons.
