description: “Teaching artists, all working professionals, lead sessions in acting, movement, writing, voice training, video techniques and more. A summer at the Institute builds confidence, independence, and creativity. Stepping outside their habitual selves, participants develop personal agency by taking risks in performance, and engaging in deep and revelatory play. Students are accepted as young as twelve and are invited back every summer until they graduate from high school, at which time they may return as paid interns.” Lunch and MetroCards are provided.
eligible: All students are 17 years old and younger
location: The Performing Garage, 33 Wooster Street, Manhattan

title: Legacy Project: Listen to a Life Story Contest
description: “To enter, all you have to do is Read, Listen, & Write! One Grand Prize Timeless Award winner receives a beautiful keepsake art piece from Cedar Lake Studios – which offers a curated selection of finely-crafted, unique, inspired art and gifts created by Canadian artisans – along with $100 cash. 7 Legacy Awards receive a keepsake cedar mini chest. One GTB (Greater Tkaronto Bioregion) EcoLegacy Award winner receives $250 cash. All winners also receive a framed award certificate and an autographed copy of Dream, an award-winning bestseller about hopes and dreams across a lifetime, through history, and into the future.

title: Teen Art Showcase Video Challenge
description: “This art video competition invites teen artists around NYC to submit a 1-2 minute video introducing an interesting fact/aspect of an art form they are passionate about for a chance to win a top prize of $500 (second place, third place, and categorical prizes are also available). This competition is an opportunity to showcase your talent, win exciting prizes, gain recognition from a broad audience, and network with other artists. Submit videos in any of four categories: visual arts, dance, theater, or music.”

title: Girls Write Now Collaboratory Summer Journeys 2025
description: “Girls Write Now’s Collaboratory is full of Journeys that are expertly curated packages of mentorship, community experiences, and writing-based courses—for both mentors and mentees. Check out our diverse collection and pick the Journey that's right for you based on your goals, schedule, and passions.” Journey options include songwriting, college preparation, writing for TV, and more.

title: Literacy Unbound Summer Writing/Performance Institute
description: “Inquisitive high school students will find an outlet for their creativity and curiosity at this unique institute, which will pair them with professional artists and teachers from around the world for an exclusive collaboration. As a student player in the institute, you'll tap into your reading, writing, performance, and multimedia abilities as you remix this year's selected text and co-create a live performance that will debut at Teachers College, Columbia University.”

title: Write the World Virtual Summer Writing Camps 2025
description: “Jump into new genres of writing, connect with campers across the globe, and learn from notable authors, editors, and educators in Write the World’s Virtual Writing Camp. During camp, you’ll engage in interactive writing activities, connect with peers around the world, and work together to grow your writing skills. After camp, you’ll work independently (and asynchronously) on writing prompts and activities, guided by peer and expert review, at your own pace, for a total time commitment of about three to four hours per day.”

title: ReelWorks Film Summer Supported Experimental Lab
description: “The Summer Supported Lab is a creative space designed for neurodivergent New York students, ages 15-21, to explore, experiment, and express themselves through film, media, and mixed art forms. This Experimental Film Lab encourages bold ideas and new ways of storytelling by providing you with new skills, equipment, connections, and more. Whether working with video, sound, or multimedia, you’ll develop your voice in a space that values collaboration, creativity, and self- expression.”
eligible: All students; focus on neurodivergent students
date: July 8 – July 31 (Tuesdays to Thursday from10:00 – 3:00 pm)

title: ReelWorks Introduction to Broadcast Journalism
description: “In this hands-on summer Journalism course, you’ll learn to research, report, film, and edit news segments that reflect diverse voices and perspectives. Using industry- standard tools, you'll develop on-camera confidence, interview skills, and storytelling techniques to bring real issues to life. This lab is for students ages 16-19. Some experience in filmmaking, journalism, or creative writing is a plus, but not required! Enroll and tell the stories that matter!”
date: July 7 – August 7 (Mondays to Thursdays from10:00 – 3:00 pm)

title: STEM from Dance: Girls Rise Up
description: “Girls Rise Up is our three-week summer program designed for girls to explore the exciting world of STEM. Each day is jampacked with dance to get participants moving and to supercharge their STEM skills. By the end of the program, participants will showcase what they’ve learned in a performance that merges dance and technology – all created by them and their fellow participants. Girls Rise Up is an opportunity for girls of all backgrounds to level up their confidence, unlock new STEM abilities, and connect with a supportive tribe of like-minded creatives and technologists.”
eligible: All students who identify as a girl

title: Deadline Approaching: The OK You Challenge
description: “The OK You Challenge calls for all high school students to share creative ways they work through stress and worry. If selected as a finalist, your project will be featured in our e-book and website to inspire others to create their own OK. The cash prizes are $350, $250, $150.

title: Legacy Project: Listen to a Life Story Contest
description: “To enter, all you have to do is Read, Listen, & Write! One Grand Prize Timeless Award winner receives a beautiful keepsake art piece from Cedar Lake Studios – which offers a curated selection of finely-crafted, unique, inspired art and gifts created by Canadian artisans – along with $100 cash. 7 Legacy Awards receive a keepsake cedar mini chest. One GTB (Greater Tkaronto Bioregion) EcoLegacy Award winner receives $250 cash. All winners also receive a framed award certificate and an autographed copy of Dream, an award-winning bestseller about hopes and dreams across a lifetime, through history, and into the future.

title: Teen Art Showcase Video Challenge
description: “This art video competition invites teen artists around NYC to submit a 1-2 minute video introducing an interesting fact/aspect of an art form they are passionate about for a chance to win a top prize of $500 (second place, third place, and categorical prizes are also available). This competition is an opportunity to showcase your talent, win exciting prizes, gain recognition from a broad audience, and network with other artists. Submit videos in any of four categories: visual arts, dance, theater, or music.”

title: Art Studies/Art History Scholarship
description: The Dedalus Foundation offers seven $2,000 scholarships to graduating seniors with an interest in studying art or art history in college.
eligible: Current seniors who intend to study fine arts or art history

title: Event Approaching: Tri-State Engineering Expo
description: “Students of all ages and their families are welcome to join us at The Tri-State Engineering EXPO, where there is something exciting for everyone! Engineering EXPO features 150+ exhibitors across all disciplines of engineering. To skip the lines at the door and get a chance to win free giveaways, register here. You won’t want to miss out on this exciting opportunity to learn about cutting-edge engineering and how you can become an engineer!”
location: White Plains High School, 550 North Street, White Plains, NY

title: Prom x QPL: Prom Attire Giveaway Events
description: “We have hundreds of FREE brand new and gently used dresses, tuxedos, shoes, handbags, and jewelry, all of which were generously donated by members of the Queens community (and beyond) to help make prom fun, fabulous, and memorable for the teens of Queens. Prom x QPL is going to be a total blast, with music, freebies, photos, and lots of FREE prom attire for you to choose from!”
date: April 12 (10:30 am - 4:30 pm, big giveaway event), and also: April 14, 15, 16,
location: Cambria Heights Teen Center (218-13 Linden Boulevard)

title: Princeton Splash On-Campus Mini-Classes
description: “Come spend a day on Princeton’s campus taking classes on everything and anything, from computational neuroscience and K-pop dance to classical mythology and botany, taught by passionate Princeton students.”

title: STEP SUMMER Programs: “STEP (Science and Technology Entry Program)
Fordham University STEP Summer Program
description: “The Fordham Science and Technology Entry Program (STEP) is an academic enrichment program, established in 1986, designed to prepare underrepresented minority and economically disadvantaged junior high and high school students for college and careers in STEM fields (science, technology, engineering, and math) fields, health careers, and licensed professions, like accounting, law, psychology, social work among other licensed fields.”
eligible: Rising sophomores, juniors, and seniors of underrepresented groups
date: Monday - Thursdays from July 7 - July 31 (9:15 AM - 4:30 PM or 9:30 – 3:40
location: Lincoln Center Campus, Manhattan OR Rose Hill Campus, Bronx
cost: Free, with registration fee for accepted students (aid available)

title: Columbia's Double Discovery Center Summer Academy
description: “The Double Discovery Center (DDC) at Columbia University's Summer Academy is a five-week academic enrichment commuter program for 9th—and 10th-grade New York City high school students. It is held on Columbia University's Morningside campus. Students commute to campus throughout the program. Academic programming occurs Monday through Thursday, with trips on Fridays. This program is free for 9th and 10th-grade students enrolled in DDC. Expect classes such as Sociology, Writing, Math, Environmental Justice, and more!”
eligible: Low-income, first-generation freshmen and sophomores who live in Harlem,
location: Double Discovery Center @ Columbia University (2920 Broadway)

title: Deadline Approaching: PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) Tour Sign-Up
description: “PwC, a global professional services firm, is inviting Stuyvesant students to tour its office and learn about its career opportunities on Tuesday, April 15 (12PM - 2PM). Enjoy lunch, a presentation by senior firm leadership, and the chance to mingle with Stuy alumni who work at PwC. This is an exclusive event usually reserved for business undergraduates and students from select universities—don’t miss your chance to explore competitive career options in business!”

title: Paid Kayak Associates with the Brooklyn Bridge Park Conservancy
description: “Join us on the waterfront as a part-time Kayak Associate this summer! Ideal applicants will be adept at multitasking, work well with youth, passionate about public programs, and ready to take on many and varied responsibilities. They must also be comfortable with being on and around the East River and have a background in kayaking or other water-based recreation (and willingness to be trained as a safety boater). They should genuinely enjoy being on the ground with program partners and participants, making sure things run smoothly and safely, and that everyone has a great time. This is a part-time, seasonal position, approximately 20-25 hours per week, with shifts available throughout the week (mornings, afternoons and evenings), from end of May- September. Pay rate is $20.00/hour.”
date: Varies, from end of May - September

title: Apex for Youth Career Exploration Events
description: Event Approaching: 1- Apex for Youth x Welcome to Chinatown Career Panel & Networking Event “Join us for a panel featuring Chinatown's small business owners and a chance to network with them!”
location: Welcome to Chinatown Event Hub, 115 Bowery, NYC

title: Seeds of Fortune Summer Programs Info Sessions
description: “Join us for an engaging and informative session about Seeds of Fortune Inc.'s exciting Summer Programs - the Girls Start-Up Business Plan Accelerator and the Innovation Research Fellowship! Learn about our innovative programs designed to empower and guide high school students in exploring entrepreneurship and cutting-edge research. Discover how Seeds of Fortune fosters a supportive environment for young women of color to thrive, connect with like-minded peers, and gain valuable skills.”

title: Global Kids Internships & Paid Positions
description: Internships are available for current high school seniors at Global Kids. If interested in internships, please send your resume along with a cover letter which includes your availability to: internship@globalkids.org

title: Go Getter Summer Internship
description: “During the five-week GO Summer program, interns will be supporting instruction in one of our K – 4 classrooms under the guidance of a Head Teacher or Enrichment Teacher. Interns will work in small groups or one-to-one within the classroom to help students complete projects, remain focused, and build confidence as learners. Interns will also be participating in rigorous daily professional development sessions where a strong social justice-centered curriculum and required readings and assignments will form the core framework for the internship.”
eligible: Students who are at least 16 years old

title: New York Public Library Business Plan Competition
description: “Are you an entrepreneur looking for the chance to launch your business? Join the New York StartUP! 2025 Business Plan Competition! Turn your ideas into reality with access to Library resources, mentorship, and cash prizes between $7,500 and $15,000. Learn more below about the requirements of the competition at the links below.”
eligible: All students who live in Manhattan, Staten Island or the Bronx
date: April 8 - TBD (Mandatory online orientation sessions begin April 8th)

title: Luna Park Summer Jobs
description: “Luna Park is the largest theme park in NYC, and they offer many exciting opportunities whether you want to work behind the scenes or right in the middle of the action.”
eligible: Students who are at least 18 years old

title: Whatever It Takes (WIT) Courses
description: “WIT provides virtual business and leadership courses for 6th - 12th graders. Classes can be taken for college-credit in partnership with UCSD.” 1- WIT Podcast Program “Over the last few years the #1 business/project that teens want to launch is a podcast. This is why WIT is partnering with renowned podcast host Felix Levine. In this unique class teens will learn the ins and outs of starting and growing their very own podcast.”

title: CUNY Explorers Program
description: “CUNY Explorers is more than just a campus tour; it's a transformative journey of college and career exploration. Students will have the opportunity to visit CUNY college campuses in person or remotely, gaining invaluable insights and experiences.”

title: Peace Ambassador Leadership Summit (PALS)
description: “The Peace Ambassador Leadership Summit (PALS) is a transformative, seven-day immersive program that empowers high school students to become leaders, advocates, and changemakers. Hosted across four prestigious universities—Georgetown University, University of Florida, University of Central Florida, and Florida International University—PALS combines rigorous workshops, hands-on service projects, and unforgettable experiences designed to prepare students for college, careers, and life.”

title: GenHERation Summer Intensive Programs
description: “Designed to equip students with the tools to succeed in the classroom, college, and beyond, the GenHERation® Summer Intensive is a rigorous, dynamic, and immersive experience that inspires young women to achieve their personal and professional goals by encouraging them to think big and push the limits of what’s possible. Our summer intensives take place on-site at our partner schools across the country. Please click on the camp location to register directly with the host school.”

title: MoMA Teens Media Lab: Pinhole Photography with Kelli Anderson
description: “Join us for MoMA Teens Media Lab, a free, monthly workshop series on Saturdays for youth ages 14–19. In this two-hour workshop, participants will take photos using This Book Is a Camera, working independently and collaboratively to learn how to use this simplified pinhole paper camera. Each participant will walk away with a paper camera and digitally developed versions of their photographs. Metrocards, snacks, and supplies will be provided.”

title: GuggTeens Fest at the Guggenheim Museum
description: “Join the Guggenheim Museum for GuggTeens Fest at the Museum. Inspired by current exhibitions, this program will include art making, gallery exploration, activations by our incredible community partners, and more! GuggTeens Fest is made by teens, for teens. Participants will receive a roundtrip MetroCards, snacks will be provided, and be entered into a raffle to win prizes, such as art supplies, exhibition catalogs, and gift cards.”

title: Folk Art Museum's Youth Art Connection (YAC)
description: “Youth Art Connection (YAC) is a free, six session summer program for high school students interested in art and museum careers. YAC participants view and discuss artwork from the Museum’s current exhibitions, create art inspired by the collection, meet museum staff and go behind the scenes of the museum, and participate in field trips to other arts institutions.”
location: Museum’s administrative offices in Long Island City, Queens and at partner

title: Arts Connection Teens Curate Teens Artists - Collective Pulse
description: “Submit your art to an exhibition created by teens for teens. Open to NYC students ages 14-19 (9th-12th grade), this exhibition showcases artwork inspired by a theme voted on by teens. This year's winning theme is Culture & Community. Selected artists will receive a $100 Blick gift card!”
eligible: All students who are at least 14 years old

title: Hudson River Park Volunteer Program
description: “Volunteers play a vital role in keeping the Park looking great year-round and are a key part of the Hudson River Park community. Hudson River Park Friends, a non- profit dedicated to the completion and care of the Park, is proud to provide numerous opportunities for the public to give back through gardening, environmental cleanup, events and more! Get involved in our Neighborhood Gardener Program, HRPK Green Team, Corporate Volunteer Opportunities, Compost Volunteering and Special Events Volunteer opportunities.”

title: The Summit STEM Fellowship
description: “The Summit STEM Fellowship is a summer fellowship for ambitious young female students. The fellowship selects for students who are self-motivated and driven to make an impact in the world. Prior experience in STEM is not required, but students must demonstrate academic excellence, leadership capabilities, and self-discipline. The program selects for students they believe to exhibit strong future potential in STEM.”

title: Event Approaching: Tri-State Engineering Expo
description: “Students of all ages and their families are welcome to join us at The Tri-State Engineering EXPO, where there is something exciting for everyone! Engineering EXPO features 150+ exhibitors across all disciplines of engineering. To skip the lines at the door and get a chance to win free giveaways, register here. You won’t want to miss out on this exciting opportunity to learn about cutting-edge engineering and how you can become an engineer!”
location: White Plains High School, 550 North Street, White Plains, NY

title: MIT Lincoln Laboratory Cipher Program (LLCipher)
description: “The Lincoln Laboratory Cipher program is a non-residential summer workshop providing an introduction to theoretical cryptography. This summer STEM program is a FREE one-week enrichment class for high-school students who are interested in mathematics or cyber security. This is a non-residential program - Students will provide their own residential arrangements & transportation to and from the MIT main campus at the beginning and end of each class. Lunch will be provided.
eligible: All students (Underrepresented groups encouraged to apply)

title: SigmaCamp
description: “At SigmaCamp, students spend a week with other talented campers, who were interested in learning about the exciting puzzles and mysteries of the world around you. They are guided by college students and graduate students from top US universities and taught by leading professors and scientists from Stony Brook University, Brookhaven National Lab, Yale, Stanford, and MIT. The days are filled with discussions of the most exciting topics in contemporary science; hands-on experiments; debates; and educational games.”
location: Silver Lake Camp and Conference Center (Sharon, Connecticut)
cost: $1,800 (sibling discounts and need-based financial aid available)

title: Mathily
description: “Mathily is a rigorous summer program for mathematically talented students. Students will explore various undergraduate and graduate-level mathematics in classes led by a mathematician with a Ph.D. and mathematics students. There will also be discussions about college choices, a session on career possibilities, and more.”

title: NYU CREATE Coding for Game Design High School Summer Program
description: “In this two-week session, participants will learn about the principles of game design, and will be introduced to C# and Unity scripting, which they will use to create their own custom games! The program emphasizes team collaboration and close work with experienced CREATE game designers and developers. Students will work together and independently to create 3D Unity games based on design principles and development techniques used by professionals at NYU.”
date: Session 1: July 7 – July 18, Session 2: July 28 – August 8

title: New York Historical Society Tech Scholars: Web Design
description: “New-York Historical Society offers a robust suite of digital humanities programs for high school students year-round in the Tech Commons. Explore how women across the spectrum of race, class, and sexuality exercised power and effected change. Be a digital changemaker and learn how to use HTML and CSS to design, code, and build your own websites to share powerful stories about women in history.”
eligible: All Students who identify as female

title: New York Historical Society Tech Scholars: Podcasting
description: “New-York Historical Society offers a robust suite of digital humanities programs for high school students year-round in the Tech Commons. Collaborate with other teens to create the first season of the New-York Historical teen podcast! This season’s theme will be “Through Fresh Eyes.” Hone your skills in history, storytelling, and technology as you research a topic; interview an artist or expert; and write, record, and edit your own podcast episode!”
date: Cohort 1: July 7 – 11 (10 AM – 4 PM) OR Cohort 2: August 18 – 22 (10 AM –
location: New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West (77th Street)

title: John Jay College Forensic Science Workshop
description: “This Forensic science workshop offered by STEP at John Jay is designed to educate high school students on the principles and techniques of forensic science. It offers hands-on experience with evidence analysis and crime scene investigation procedures, all within a college classroom setting. The topics will include crime scene investigation, fingerprint analysis, and blood spatter analysis.”
location: John Jay College of Criminal Justice

title: Columbia University State Pre-College Enrichment Program (S-PREP)
description: “The State Pre-College Enrichment Program is an academic enrichment program designed for students who are interested in pursuing a career in medicine or related STEM fields. S-PREP offers enrichment courses and activities geared toward preparing students for success in math and science. In addition to the rigorous academic schedule, the program offers college preparation and career development workshops, college counseling services, field trips, and college tours. S-PREP requires that students attend consistently and give their best effort.”
eligible: All students who meet the economic eligibility guidelines outlined by the
location: Columbia's Vagelos Education Center: 104 Haven Ave, Manhattan

title: Apex for Youth Healthcare Careers Virtual Panel
description: “Join Apex virtually to hear a panel from across various healthcare roles & workplaces. Panelists will share more about their specific roles, their career trajectory and their day-to-day.”

title: Event Approaching: Girls Write Now Career Chat: Demstifying the World
description: of Publishing with Macmillian “Come discover the various roles and opportunities at Macmillan Publishers! Whether you’d like to someday have your work published or you’d like to be a part of the publishing industry, this Career Chat is made for you. Meet employees from different departments and hear their professional journeys. This is a great opportunity to learn more about Macmillan and to help you chart your future career goals.”
location: Girls Write Now Headquarters, 247 W 37th St #1000, Manhattan

title: YC Teen Annual Summer Writing Workshop
description: “If you're a young person interested in telling stories about making change, we invite you to apply to Youth Communication’s 46th annual summer writing workshop! You will participate in writing lessons, discussions, field trips, and group activities. You will write memoir-style and reported stories about making change. You’ll learn narrative writing techniques along with research and interviewing skills, work one-on- one with a professional adult editor, and share your work with your peers. Participants will publish at least one story in our online magazines. All participants receive a $1,500 stipend for completing at least one story in the workshop. A daily two-trip MetroCard will also be provided.”

title: Litchfield Jazz Camp & Scholarship Opportunity
description: “LJC is a non-competitive program focusing on musical and personal growth. No pre- audition is required. We listen to you when you arrive and assign you to a combo at your level. In a month-long program on the campus in Washington, Connecticut, Litchfield Jazz Camp embraces all learners - students 13 years to adult, beginners, intermediate and advanced players, students with learning disabilities, and others. Each year Litchfield Performing Arts awards approximately 1/3 of their students need-based scholarships to Jazz Camp, thanks to additional funding made available through grants, foundations, and individual donors.”

title: A Voice for Animals Contest
description: The 35th Annual Contest is open to all students 14-18 interested in promoting the humane treatment of animals and accepts video, photograph, and essay submissions on the topic. The top prize is $500, and a total of $5,900 will be awarded to winners.
eligible: All students who are at least 14 years old

title: A Voice for Animals Contest
description: The 35th Annual Contest is open to all students 14-18 interested in promoting the humane treatment of animals and accepts video, photograph, and essay submissions on the topic. The top prize is $500, and a total of $5,900 will be awarded to winners.
eligible: All students who are at least 14 years old

title: Spectrum News Challenge TV Show Contestant Application
description: “Are breaking headlines always in your Twitter and Tik Tok feeds? Are you interested in what’s happening in current events, politics, science, the environment, sports, wellness and pop culture? Become a contestant on the Spectrum News Challenge, a national televised program where high school students compete head-to-head to win prizes and the title of “Spectrum News Challenge Champion.”

title: New York Public Library Business Plan Competition
description: “Are you an entrepreneur looking for the chance to launch your business? Join the New York StartUP! 2025 Business Plan Competition! Turn your ideas into reality with access to Library resources, mentorship, and cash prizes between $7,500 and $15,000. Learn more below about the requirements of the competition at the links below.”
eligible: All students who live in Manhattan, Staten Island or the Bronx
date: April 8 - TBD (Mandatory online orientation sessions begin April 8th)

title: Deadline Approaching: The Gloria Barron Prize
description: “The Barron Prize honors public-spirited young people who worked as an individual to lead their service work. Students must either are currently working on an inspiring service project or have done so within the past 12 months.” Students are eligible for a top prize of $10,000.

title: E-waste Scholarship
description: “Each year there are 20 to 50 million tons of e-waste discarded in the world. E-waste contains toxic materials, including heavy metals, that can easily seep into the ground and ultimately get into groundwater supplies. According to the EPA, recycling e- waste allows more than 100 million pounds of materials to be reused annually. The purpose of this scholarship is to help you understand the impact of e-waste and what can be done to reduce e-waste. The winner will receive a $1,000 scholarship.”

title: Return2College (R2C) Scholarship
description: “We know the essay requirement does not allow for many words. We want you to focus on the most important reason for getting your degree. Nevertheless, we realize that some of you may want to say more. Therefore, you may submit more than one entry. We will judge all completed entries. The first-place award is a $1,000 scholarship which will be paid directly to the applicant or designated school.”

title: Milton Fisher Scholarship
description: “The Milton Fisher Scholarship is a four-year renewable scholarship open to exceptionally Innovative and Creative high school seniors, and first-time college freshmen. The award ranges from $4,000 - $20,000. Apply for this scholarship if you are a student who has solved an artistic, scientific, or technical problem in a new or unusual way, or a student who has come up with a distinctive solution to problems faced by your school, community or family.”

title: Study.com Student Scholarships
description: “In order to push toward our goal of making education accessible, Study.com has designated a wide variety of academic awards and scholarships for students. Study.com is thrilled to be awarding over $50,000 in scholarships. These academic awards are geared toward people with ranging backgrounds, identities, and academic goals. Check out our list below to apply for any scholarships you may qualify for!”

title: First Event Approaching NYPL Riverside Library Comic Book Events
description: The NYPL Riverside Library is offering various in-person or virtual events to teens who may be interested in art or comic-making. This includes an “Copyright for Comic Makers and Artists: Everything You Need to Know to Protect Your Creative Works” event, “Virtual Comics Chat: Arab American Heritage Month, Muslim Comics and Spring” event, and a Create Your Vision Workshop for Teens @ Riverside” workshop. See the link below for more information.
date: Copyright for Comic Makers and Artists (April 9, 4-5 PM), Virtual Comics
location: Virtual or In-Person at NYPL Riverside Library

title: Event Approaching:
description: Rockefeller University Data 4 People Q&A: Challenging Gender Bias in Science “We’re reuniting with our Season 5 presenters for a “Town Hall”-style Q&A event, where we’ll dig into deeper discussion of the origins, impacts, and future implications of gender bias in science. Our conversation will also have a new perspective, thanks to a (TBA) expert panelist in gender studies who will be joining us as well! Drawing from primary scientific literature and current research practices, our sessions will challenge the notion of scientific neutrality–revealing how pervasive, persistent gender biases influence everything from hypothesis formation to data interpretation while highlighting innovative research methods that embrace diversity and complexity in biological sex studies.”

title: Event Approaching:
description: Columbia Climate School Young Leaders in Action Event “Register for Columbia Climate School's April Climate LIVE K12 session! Hear from climate change-maker Anna Panjwani, who developed a community-focused website that breaks down the Inflation Reduction Act’s incentives and all the financial tricks that make going green not only the best choice environmentally but also financially. Her project aims to help people save money while reducing emissions, and empower individuals to take action on climate change through accessible resources. Anna Panjwani will share about her climate action journey and inspire participants to support their own communities.”

title: Queensborough Community College - College Now
location: Virtual or in-person at 222-05, 56th Avenue Bayside, depending on the

title: Queensborough Community College – Robotics Summer Program
description: “Looking for something exciting to do this summer while earning free college credits? Then the College Now Summer Robotics Program is for you! Students work in teams in person on the QCC Campus to design, construct and program autonomous mobile robots. Students will demonstrate what they have learned at a showcase on August 4th.”

title: Oxford Summer Courses
description: “Oxford Summer Courses offers exciting 2-week summer programs across 40+ subjects. Delve into a subject you love guided by an expert tutor alongside students from all over the world in a world class university setting in Oxford or Cambridge. Small class sizes mean that teaching can be tailored to the student interests and are designed to challenge perspectives and develop new ways of thinking. Oxford Summer Courses is inspired by the world class teaching methodologies of Oxford and Cambridge. Over your two-week course, you will learn to challenge ideas and follow your own path - within the walls of leading university settings. Our courses are designed to help you explore, free from restrictive curricula and expected outcomes and discover your passions, guided by an expert tutor.”
location: Oxford University (Wellington Square, Oxford OX1 2JD, England)

title: Event Approaching:
description: Columbia CORE Youth Building Blocks Spring Startup Workshop Day Columbia's student-run CORE Youth Program is hosting a free Startup Workshop Conference on April 12. You will brainstorm, build, and bring an idea to life - no experience needed! If you are interested in tech, design, engineering, or just curious about entrepreneurship, it's a workshop to help students create something from scratch alongside other middle and high school students. The event includes a keynote speaker, workshops on business, design, and coding, plus dedicated work sessions to help you create something by the end of the day. We’ll provide lunch and snacks! Columbia's CORE Youth is an initiative that seeks to empower students into the startup world. We will cover how to develop an app, basic entrepreneurial concepts, product design, and more! We will have several networking events as well. Please first register for the CORE Youth Program before you sign up the Startup Workshop Day. Space is limited, so please register soon!
location: Columbia Startup Lab, 69 Charlton St, Manhattan

title: Powers of a Great Resume: Virtual Workshop
description: “This virtual workshop by the New York Hall of Science will cover how to structure a powerful resume that will showcase your unique experiences.”

title: StandOut Connect High School Internship Program
description: “StandOut Connect is a program that matches high school students with internships. We created a program that matches high school students with companies founded by top university alumni who have previously only accepted high school interns from within their personal network. Now, instead of applying to competitive state programs, you can connect directly with unique companies in fields that excite you.”
eligible: All students 15+ by start of program

title: Science Career Ladder (SCL) Paid Explainers Program
description: “The Explainers program is part of the Science Career Ladder (SCL). The SCL is an innovative education and employment program open to high school and college students. While in the Explainer program, students represent the public face of the museum. They are provided with training and with opportunities to further their learning of STEM and receive professional development. Through co-facilitation and co-creation, Explainers elevate youth voice in the design and iteration of museum content, STEM activities, exhibit development, and our educational programming.”
eligible: All students who are at least 14 years old and have working papers

Unlike precollege programs, these courses do not offer college credit, but instead immerse you in a professional field while answering questions such as: What is college like? How can I prepare for college? What is a good career for me?”
cost: $2,579 per course, additional $640 for housing, dining, and application fees (no

title: Helicon Algebra I Regents Tutoring Internship

As a tutor, you will teach Algebra I topics, provide one-on-one math tutoring, administer/correct daily “mental math” quizzes, record scores in Excel database, conduct daily Algebra I Regents Examination Practice Test Sessions and review solutions, and answer students questions about taking the SHSAT and life in a specialized high school. Tutors are eligible to earn community service credits.”
eligible: All students who identify as female

As a tutor, you will assist the executive director develop a pilot program, provide one-on-one math tutoring, administer/correct daily mental math quizzes; record scores in Excel database, organize daily mental math games and tournaments, video math games, tournaments, and individual student presentations, and answer students questions about taking the SHSAT and life in a specialized high school. Tutors are eligible to earn community service credits.”

description: “Goodwill Virtual Career Center is a proactive learning program that offers free workshops to help you hit the ground running with your best foot forward on the path to success. These scholarships include room, board, learning materials, and transportation and admission to historic sites. Walk in the footsteps of leaders who helped define and shape the American story, including presidents, civil rights leaders, and soldiers who fought for the birth and survival of the nation. See and learn about seminal documents that shaped our history from subject matter experts and master teachers. Get behind-the-scenes access to historic sites no other program can provide.”
location: Foxcroft School (22407 Foxhound Ln, Middleburg, VA 20117)

title: InspirinGirls Young Ambassador Program 2025 - 2026
description: “Are you a young girl looking to build your confidence and develop leadership and life skills? Do you want to prepare for college, internships, and future jobs while also participating in civic engagement at the national level? As a Young Ambassador, you'll have access to impressive women professionals who can help guide you on your path to success, the opportunity to practice interviewing and networking, finding your voice, and establishing your brand, and make friends with like-minded girls. You’ll attend 1.5 hour calls once a quarter to discuss goals and connect with other Ambassadors, meet role models and interview women for the Inspiring Girls Video Hub, start an Inspiring Girls Circle in your community, craft social media posts to inspire your peers, and even co-host Inspiring Girls events.”

The Summer Career Lab will be organized around lectures on architectural fundamentals, workshops on drawing and making, one-on-one critiques and collective pin-up reviews, field trips, site work, presentations from architects, historians, and designers, and office tours. The curriculum incorporates mixed fabrication, computer-aided design, interdisciplinary research, and sustainability as core tenets. The Lab provides its participants with the experience needed to make an informed career choice, competitive work for design portfolios, and skills immediately applicable in design endeavors.”

Get involved in our Neighborhood Gardener Program, HRPK Green Team, Corporate Volunteer Opportunities, Compost Volunteering and Special Events Volunteer opportunities.”

This program introduces students to many aspects of engineering.”

Throughout the program students will learn industry-aligned technical and professional skills, gaining knowledge of key coding languages and frameworks including HTML, CSS, and Bootstrap. During the final week of the program, students will put their knowledge to the test and work in teams to create and present a final website during the end-of-program Demo Day Competition.”
eligible: Rising juniors and seniors (priority to underserved and minority students –

title: Vaughn College Computer Engineering Summer Academy
description: “Cybersecurity and information technology jobs are currently among the fastest growing career sectors in the nation. Are you ready to become a highly sought-after candidate and change the course of your future? Attending Vaughn’s Computer Engineering Summer Academy can be that first big step! Topics covered will include basic and intermediate blockchain, Artificial Intelligence, and cybersecurity.”

Students can enroll in IBM courses for AI and cybersecurity certificates, as well as first semester courses that include English literature and composition (six credits) for free.”

title: Deadline Approaching: Brooklyn Young Writers’ Summer Workshop
description: “Hawthornden Brooklyn invites applications from creative high school students who currently attend New York City public schools to participate in our Summer 2025 Young Writers’ Workshop. In three separate ten-day workshops, students will have the opportunity to sharpen their skills in either fiction, poetry, or creative nonfiction at the Hawthornden Brooklyn house in Ditmas Park, a space specially designed for writers. Workshops will include guided instruction, assigned reading, field trips, mini lessons, collaboration, as well as the time and space to generate new work. Class size is limited to 10 students per workshop, and lunch will be provided. Each student will receive a stipend of $1,000 and have access to quiet writing spaces, and an elaborate library. For students interested in creative writing, this is a great chance to shoot your shot and become part of Hawthornden’s literary community.”
date: Three separate 10-day sessions (Poetry, Fiction, and Non-fiction)

title: NYU Tisch Online High School Filmmakers Workshop
description: “This online workshop introduces students to the theory and techniques of developing and producing short films that are shot and edited digitally. Early assignments familiarize them with equipment as well as documentary, experimental, and narrative approaches. Working in online crews, students will collaborate to develop their directing, shooting, and editing skills as they produce music videos and short films (three to five minutes in length). Students learn the basics of screenwriting through writing exercises, reading assignments, viewing online media examples, as well as the script development and research of their short films.”

title: AAGUNV National High School Essay Contest
description: “To enter the Americans Against Gun Violence National High School Essay Contest, students must submit an original essay of 500 words or fewer in response to the following prompt: The late Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas’s opinion in the 1972 case of Adams v. Williams. The first place winner will receive $3,000.”

description: “New York City students in grades 9-12 are invited to enter the PAL/NYPD “Police Commissioner for a Day” essay contest. The topic is; “as Police Commissioner for a Day, what steps would you take with MTA officials to prevent and deter young people from participating in “subway surfing”? The winner will meet with Police Commissioner Tisch, and all winners will spend a day with top NYPD officials. The top winner will win $500, a personalized plaque, and a $250 donation to their school.”

title: Filmmaking at Hooks Art Media
description: “Accepted applicants will learn how to use DSLR cameras and the professional sound and lighting equipment used on sets all around the world. Students learn camera operation, sound recording, use of lighting equipment, video editing software and produce short documentary videos on topics of relevance to themselves and their communities. All participants earn minimum wage equivalent stipends for their participation. The program concludes with a public screening of students’ films for families and friends.”

The Fellows Program is an intensive and challenging program requiring an exceptionally high levels of commitment. In addition to the 30- month class schedule, students and instructors oftentimes spend weekends and evenings at Ghetto Film School when necessary.”

Douglas’s opinion in the 1972 case of Adams v. Williams. The first place winner will receive $3,000.”

Participants will be able to choose from over 150 academic and creative courses taught by university teachers and professionals and designed to use the venues as teaching tools. Oxbridge students undergo a transformation in their sense of self, their capabilities, and where they place learning and creativity in their lives.”

title: College Passport SAT Prep Summer 2025
description: “This course is designed to provide you with the knowledge and skills needed to succeed on the SAT exam. The course covers all sections of the exam, including reading and math, and includes practice tests and personalized feedback to help you identify areas that need improvement. With the guidance of experienced instructors, you'll learn test-taking strategies, time management skills, and how to approach different types of questions. By completing this SAT Prep Course, you'll be better prepared for the exam and increase your chances of achieving your desired scores. Students are required to upload or email their transcripts. Metro cards and snacks will be provided.”

The program includes several lectures on legal subjects per day, and distinguished guest speakers including law professors, attorneys, judges, and elected officials.”

location: Fordham University School of Law (150 W 62nd Street, Manhattan)

No prior art- making experience is necessary. Metrocards, snacks, and supplies will be provided.” Registration required.

By linking historical, cultural, and political context to physical forms of buildings and urban spaces, the program will deepen their appreciation for how architecture can engage with various disciplines to reshape our built environments and experiences. The program includes strategies to succeed in college, supported laboratory workshops, field trips, interface with guest lecturers and community members, and a final showcase built into the curriculum.”

description: “The Timbuctoo Climate Science and Careers Institute provides high school students going into their sophomore and junior year with a two-week summer experience exploring the foundations of climate science and the careers dedicated to and intersecting with the environment. Students will collaborate with faculty from SUNY ESF and Medgar Evers College. The Timbuctoo Institute offers a thoughtful immersive experience, beginning in Brooklyn before students travel to Kingston and Syracuse for several days, then heading to the Adirondacks for the second week. Throughout the two-week experience, students are engaged in instruction by college faculty and research staff, as well as hands-on activities, experiential learning, and guided exploration at each location.” A $1,280 stipend is provided.

title: 66th London International Youth Science Forum (LIYSF)
description: “The London International Youth Science Forum CIC (LIYSF CIC) offers a two- week STEM summer camp in the UK, held both online and in-person, at Imperial College London & The Royal Geographical Society. Each year, 500 students aged 16- 21 years old from 70 countries enjoy our 15-day STEM summer camp, with lecture demonstrations from leading scientists, scientific visits to world-class laboratories and scientific universities, combined with international cultural interaction. Founded in 1959, the London International Youth Science Forum is a STEM summer camp in the UK, that aims to give a deeper insight into science and its applications for the benefit of humankind. LIYSF CIC is a not-for-profit social enterprise.”

Our certified Drone Pilot instructors will provide the students with basic knowledge of drone photography, videography principles and basic drone coding commands.”

description: Public Health Summer Programs “This program hosted by the Columbia University Vagelos College of Physician and Surgeons (VP&S) is a 3-week summer program that meets on Sundays from 8/3 – 8/24.

title: Urban Barcode Research Program 2025-2026 School Year
description: “This science education initiative engages students in studies of biodiversity using DNA technology. Once accepted into the program, students take a training course covering basic concepts in biodiversity, conservation biology, and science research. This course also provides hands-on laboratory experience with common science research techniques. Students then conduct student-driven research projects using DNA barcoding under expert mentorship. The UBRP enables students to gain knowledge, confidence, and interest in science while studying the interaction between biodiversity and human activity. Students who complete the 55 hours of research and present their projects at the Research Symposium each receive a $500 stipend.”

Representatives from each university will present information about their institution, discuss the application process, and answer questions on how to put together a strong and reflective application. Each program will end with breakout sessions where representatives will answer questions about their specific school and the application process.”

The workshop will cover interview techniques, the interview environment, and the importance of active listening. By the end of the session, you will learn how to uncover and amplify meaningful narratives that might otherwise be overlooked.”

Students who successfully complete their projects are eligible for a stipend.”

As a High School Fellow, you’ll have an Advising Fellow, someone from a similar background as you, walk you through every step of the process, 1:1, virtually, and for free. This includes creating a balanced college list, filling out applications, applying to financial aid and scholarships, preparing for college life, and more.”

description: “The Gilder Lehrman Institute (GLI) is launching the 2025 Citizenship Challenge: Redesigning America’s Citizenship Test contest for students in our Affiliate School network to creatively showcase their understanding of American history, civics, and the naturalization exam. Each winning student will receive a $500 prize and be featured on GLI’s ‘The Citizenship Test: Civics and American History’ webpage. Ten prizes will be awarded. As part of the contest, students can submit an original essay, podcast, or documentary as an entry to the competition.”

title: AAPI-LEAD Program (Asian Americans and Pacific Islanders- Learn.
description: Engage. Advocate. Dream) “AAPI-LEAD is a 4-day youth conference that brings together NYC’s AAPI and allied youth to discuss the experiences and issues most relevant to AAPI young people. AAPI-LEAD aims to develop AAPI youth's understanding of and relationship to their own identities, deepen the connections between social justice and equity in relation to systems and community, and equip youth with the tools to advocate for themselves, their families, and the wider AAPI community as a whole. Youth will also have the opportunity to apply to the Asian American Students Advocacy Project (ASAP), CACF's youth leadership program, by coming to this conference. ”

title: Gilder Lehrman Institute: David McCullough Essay Contest
description: “Students are invited to submit an interpretive essay focusing on close reading and analysis of one primary source from American history, 1491 to 2001, in the Gilder Lehrman Collection of more than 87,000 historical documents, or students are invited to submit a research essay incorporating primary and secondary sources on a topic in American history from 1491 to 2001. The David McCullough Essay Prizes recognize fourteen outstanding high school students with prizes of up to $5,000.”

Students will hear career presentations from working professionals engaged in computer science jobs and career fields such as web design, software development, and user design, along with the business operations of technology companies. Students will also experience the field firsthand by working on a small, facilitated group project related to web design, basic software and user experience.”

title: Summer 2025 Cyber Security Course
description: “Interested in learning about Cyber Security? Want to know more about Digital Forensics, Cryptography and Ethical Hacking? Then this course is for you! With this Cyber Security course, you will learn how to navigate Networking threats, Threats and Attacks on Endpoints, Authentication and more. Our experienced instructor is dedicated to successfully guiding you through this 5- week course, at the end of which you will have gained knowledge that can help you in everyday life and for future job opportunities.”

In these weekly sessions, the goal will be to answer questions and shine a spotlight on key areas of pursuing a career in healthcare with a focus on children's health. After successfully finishing the 20 hour program, students will receive a Certificate of Completion.”

Participants will gain technical skills in photography and storytelling while building confidence in expressing themselves through images and writing. As students share stories from their own lives and document the community around them, they will create portraits and narratives that reflect the complexity of their identities and experiences. Through this process, we hope to empower students and cultivate a generation of young storytellers who can shape more empathetic and inclusive narratives within and beyond their communities. The workshop will culminate in a public exhibition of their work.”

You’ll leave with a better understanding of your interests and goals as a writer, an understanding of what it takes to make a career in the literary community, and a highly-developed body of new work.”
eligible: All students who are at least 15 years old
date: July 14 – 24 (workshop for ages 12 – 14) or July 14 – 31 (workshop for ages

title: Gilder Lehrman Institute: David McCullough Essay Contest
description: “Students are invited to submit an interpretive essay focusing on close reading and analysis of one primary source from American history, 1491 to 2001, in the Gilder Lehrman Collection of more than 87,000 historical documents, or students are invited to submit a research essay incorporating primary and secondary sources on a topic in American history from 1491 to 2001. The David McCullough Essay Prizes recognize fourteen outstanding high school students with prizes of up to $5,000.”

title: Event Approaching: Genspace Biannual Open Lab
description: “Open Lab is a biannual gathering where Genspace members share their work with each other and the public. Meet other life science enthusiasts and hear about opportunities to get involved with individual and community projects. If you're considering joining the lab or are just curious to see what we're all about, this is a great time to get to know us.”

title: College Passport at University Settlement: Intro to Calculus
description: “The Intro to Calculus program aims to support students who either: a) do not feel challenged enough in schools; b) plan to study a Math-intensive major in colleges, such as science, engineering, social-science-related majors (Psychology, Quantitative Sociology, Education Studies, etc.), or business-related majors (Finance, Accounting, Marketing, Communication, etc.) c) hope to study in advance to better prepare for their calculus classes in future.”
location: East Side Community High School, 420 East 12 Street, Manhattan

title: Hostos Community College STEP Summer STEM Program
description: “Proyecto Access is offering enrichment courses focusing on science, technology, engineering, and mathematics. Students will receive academic advice and professional development opportunities. Courses include Bio Life Sciences, Engineering & Technology, Cyber Security, Human Services, Computer Science, Engineering, Chemistry, and more.

title: St. John’s Summer Academy
description: “St. John’s Summer Academy is a college summer program for high school students (ages 15 to 18), modeled after St. John’s discussion-based, interdisciplinary method of teaching great books. A genuine introduction to college life, Summer Academy helps students hone their reading, critical thinking, and discussion skills in classes led by St. John’s faculty. Our goal with the Summer Academy is to introduce high school students to the world of critical thinking and discussion while reading great books on subjects like philosophy, literature, psychology, history, science, and more. Summer Academy is perfect for students who want to immerse themselves in books, ideas, and a community that loves learning as much as you do.”
location: Virtual OR in-person at Annapolis or Santa Fe

title: Wharton Global Youth Comment & Win Contest
description: “The Wharton Global Youth Program Comment & Win is an annual contest that runs from June to August and is designed to encourage high school-age students to discover Global Youth stories, podcasts, and videos, learn about business, and develop stronger reflective and persuasive commenting skills. Four biweekly rounds of competition include a new theme introduced each round. Students can choose to participate in one or two rounds, or all four. Four-round competitors are entered into the running for a special Grand Prize.”

title: Brooklyn Library Virtual Teen Techies Volunteers
description: “Branches of the Brooklyn library system welcome student volunteers to provide tech and support assistance throughout the summer, and for a minimum of three hours per week for at least six months during the school year. By participating, you'll learn new computer skills in a two-week fall technology institute, and then share those skills by helping patrons use library computers. You'll also assist library staff with computer troubleshooting and computer training workshops for the public. Participants will receive eight days of training and small stipends.”

title: Penn Early Exploration Program (PEEP)
description: “Are you a rising high school senior interested in learning more about Penn and applying to selective universities? Would you like to gain confidence in navigating the application process and hone your application skills? Do you identify as limited- income and/or first-generation to college? PEEP is an online workshop-based virtual program designed to help get you ready to apply to college and thrive once you’re there. Admissions experts and members of the Penn community will guide you through the college application process and help you gain insight on finding community and support at college.”
eligible: Current juniors who identify as first-generation and/or financially

title: The National Security Language Virtual Initiative for Youth (NSLI-Y)
description: “Virtual NSLI-Y, a program of the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Educational and Cultural Affairs, provides U.S. high school students with beginner-level foreign language and culture experience. Eligible U.S. high school students can apply to Virtual NSLI-Y to study Arabic, Chinese (Mandarin), Hindi, Korean, Russian, or Turkish. Selected finalists will receive a merit scholarship to study the language and associated culture(s) in live, online classes with peers from across the U.S.!”

title: Future Teachers Program with Young Minds in Motion – For Seniors
description: “Are you a high school senior interested in becoming a teacher? The Future Teachers Program offers a paid, hands-on experience in early childhood and elementary education. Students will work alongside certified educators, attend career development workshops, and receive mentorship to support their journey into the teaching profession. To start the application process, email your resume to Niyasha James at niyashaj@youngmindsinmotion.com ”

title: 2025 NYC HERricane Summer Session
description: “HERricane is a national innovative program created to empower women to excel in Emergency Management and related fields. With women often underrepresented yet disproportionately affected by disasters, it's time to change the narrative. Participants will participate in a variety of activities focusing on emergency management and personal development including but not limited to: Interactive workshops, Emergency management simulations, Field trips, and Trainings to equip young women with lifelong skills.”
location: NYC Emergency Management headquarters (165 Cadman Plaza East,

title: Public Advocate Candidate Internship
description: “Jenifer Rajukumar for Public Advocate is seeking Campaign Fellows to work on a competitive Public Advocate race in New York City. We are looking for passionate, hard-working individuals who will work with the campaign team to build a robust voter outreach and turnout program in New York City. Fellows will engage directly with voters through door-to-door canvassing, phone banking, texting, and conversations at campaign and community events; work with campaign staff to plan and execute campaign events; and recruit and train volunteers to participate in direct action with the campaign.”

title: Teen Service Corps
description: “The Teen Service Corps is a 3 or 6-week service learning program with cohorts in Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens and Long Island. Throughout the program teens (rising 9th through 12th graders) will learn about systemic injustice through a Jewish lens, hone leadership skills, and volunteer in various neighborhoods to promote food and housing justice, and have fun!”

title: Deadline Approaching: Summer Teen Art Classes at MoMA
description: “Throughout this program, you’ll have the opportunity to enhance your artistic skills, build your portfolio, and immerse yourself in the New York art world. Under the guidance of MoMA educators, participants will explore different art-making techniques in one of four cohorts (Sculpture; Drawings & Prints; Photography & Moving Image; and Architecture & Design) centered around the theme of Building Community & Belonging. MoMA will provide all art materials, MetroCards for transportation to and from the Museum, snacks, and any other costs associated with participating.”
location: Museum of Modern Art (11 West 53 Street, Manhattan)

title: NewMu Teen Fellowship at the New Museum of Contemporary Arts
description: “The NewMu Teen Fellowship is a paid, afterschool program for New York City public high school students. The Fellowship spans two school years, allowing time for Fellows to develop their creativity, critical thinking, and self-expression. They earn $16 an hour while working directly with professional artists, Museum staff, and community members, and gaining creative and professional development through mentorship, work experience, and leadership opportunities. The Fellowship amplifies youth voices and ideas by supporting large-scale projects, including a public display of their artwork and a Youth Summit.”

title: Introduction to Architecture Online: Foundation Studies and Portfolio
description: Development Program “This five-week intensive is designed to familiarize students with architectural thinking and design while developing a portfolio of projects. Students are guided to prepare a portfolio to apply to a broad range of programs, such as schools of design, architecture, and art. The programs will consist of workshops, seminars, and learning about the history, contexts, and processes forming the architectural discipline. Students will receive instruction in a variety of representational tools and media: digital drawing and model- making techniques, analysis and representation, computer modeling and fabrication. Students who complete all of the assignments will receive an official Certificate of Completion from The Cooper Union.”
date: July 7 - August 8 (Monday-Friday, 9 AM - 11 AM or 2 PM - 4 PM )

title: Columbia Silent Spring Summer Institute
description: “This summer, Silent Spring is offering a free virtual program for high school students interested in learning about environmental health. Students will learn how our everyday environments—the water we drink, the air we breathe, the food we eat, and the products we use—shape our health and well-being and how science can advance solutions to reduce disease risk and create healthier communities.”

title: Deadline Approaching: Aviation and Aeronautics Academy @ York College
description: “The JFK Redevelopment Aviation and Aeronautics Academy at York College (JFKR AAA) aims to expose local youth to science, technology, engineering, and math concepts related to aviation, aeronautics, and airport management, as well as to introduce them to leadership and career opportunities in the industry. In partnership with York College, the JFKR Aviation & Aeronautics Academy will provide approximately 700 students with aviation-related educational opportunities throughout the school year, including corporate partnerships with AT&T, Con Edison, and National Grid. This new STEM Program will fulfill one of the most important community needs - educate, train, and retain local children and youths in aviation and ensure future workforce development.”
location: York College, 94-20 Guy Brewer Blvd, Jamaica

title: Vineyard App Camp
description: Week-long sessions in app development, tech entrepreneurship, and more for students at all skill levels: “We create a highly personalized mentorship atmosphere in our classes, with one instructor to every 5 students. Two format options are offered: M-F one-week camp, or one hour a week for the whole summer.

title: College Passport at University Settlement: Intro to Calculus
description: “The Intro to Calculus program aims to support students who either: a) do not feel challenged enough in schools; b) plan to study a Math-intensive major in colleges, such as science, engineering, social-science-related majors (Psychology, Quantitative Sociology, Education Studies, etc.), or business-related majors (Finance, Accounting, Marketing, Communication, etc.) c) hope to study in advance to better prepare for their calculus classes in future.”
location: East Side Community High School, 420 East 12 Street, Manhattan

title: MehtA+ AI/Machine Learning Research Bootcamp
description: “The MehtA+ AI/Machine Learning Research Bootcamp is an intensive 6 week bootcamp in which students will learn about the theory and application of AI/machine learning, and work on machine learning research in sciences and humanities in collaboration with top universities.”

title: DigiPen Academy Virtual in Game Design, Programming, & Music
description: “DigiPen Academy's online summer courses offer four-week programs in Art & Animation, Game Design, Video Game Programming, and Music & Sound Design. These courses introduce students to college-level coursework and industry-relevant skills. Over four weeks, students delve into the fundamentals of their chosen field, guided by expert instructors in morning sessions focused on core concepts and hands- on project labs in the afternoons.”

title: Summer Shakespeare Theater Program
description: “Summer Shakespeare is a five-week summer intensive that is free for qualifying students. Twenty-two students are selected to train five days a week in voice, movement, ensemble work, and scene study (50 hours of classes total). The program culminates in a production of an abbreviated Shakespeare play. Summer Shakespeare is an intensive program that requires the quick understanding and execution of new skills through master classes, play rehearsals, and the final performances.”
eligible: All students who identify as financially disadvantaged
location: In-person at Stella Adler Studio of Acting, 65 Broadway, Manhattan

title: New York Theater Workshop Mind the Gap
description: “The goals of the program are both to teach writing and theatre skills and foster better communication and understanding between these two age groups: Adolescents & Seniors. Through the workshop participants are able to: INVESTIGATE, LISTEN and EMPATHIZE with someone of another generation, while using playwriting as a tool to understand and represent their unique experience, BROADEN THEIR PERSPECTIVE, see the other generation in a new light, and take on the task of telling someone else’s story with respect and understanding, SHARE THEIR STORIES and ultimately see them interpreted through another’s eyes making meaning out of their personal narratives and gaining insights into their own lives.”
eligible: All students who are at least 14 years old
location: The Sheen Center (18 Bleecker Street, Manhattan)

title: The Stuck at the Prom Contest
description: This challenges students to create prom attire out of Duck Brand duct tape. Students may win up to $15,000. Winners will be announced by July 16.
eligible: All students who are at least 14 years old

title: Bank of Hope - Hope Scholarship Foundation
description: “As one of the leading Asian American Banks, we strive to be good neighbors and support our customers and communities in any way we can. To date, we have distributed more than $2 million in scholarships through the Hope Scholarship Foundation. This is a great opportunity for (2025 high school graduate)/college freshmen at a 4-year or 2-year institution in financial need who have demonstrated strong academic performance and leadership capabilities. To be considered, applicants will have the opportunity to submit 500 words on a selected essay topic and show us why they are deserving of the $2,500 award.”
eligible: Seniors living in Nassau County, New York County, or Queens County

title: Pasta Rose Scholarship
description: “The Pasta Rose Scholarship is a yearly scholarship awarded to Brooklyn high school students who have lost a parent to cancer. Having the strength and resilience to go on after losing a parent at a young age is no easy task. This scholarship will help those kids who have lost so much... help them to go to college, to succeed, and to help them feel just a little bit better.”
eligible: Current seniors who live in Brooklyn

title: Deadline Approaching: Teen Night: Cosmic Cowboy
description: “Join us as we transform a section of the High Line into the intergalactic wild west for an out-of-this-world Teen Night: Cosmic Cowboy experience! Inspired by the legendary West Side cowboys and our park in the sky, this free, youth-led event will feature activities, art workshops, performances, an open-mic segment, snacks and food tasting, a scavenger hunt, and dancing. We encourage you to unleash your inner cowboy, alien, or astronaut by wearing your cowboy or space-inspired outfit for a fun time travel and galaxy-hopping adventure that is sure to be a blast!”
location: On the High Line between 15th and 16th Streets, Manhattan

title: Event Approaching: Arts Connection Pizza and a Movie Night (PAAM)
description: “What’s your plan for the first Friday of the month? Bring your friends—or make new ones—at PaaM! Enjoy FREE pizza and a movie night exclusively for teens (ages 14- 19). Vote on the movie, enjoy great food, and meet students across NYC!”
eligible: All students who are at least 14 years old
location: 53rd Street New York Public Library (18 West 53rd St, Manhattan)

title: Columbia University Academic Year Weekend Program
description: “Columbia University's Academic Year Weekend program offers academically exceptional high school students a preview of the college experience through online coursework and community activities over ten weekends this fall. Choose from over thirty courses that emphasize experiential and collaborative learning. Students join their classes for two hours on Saturday or Sunday, learning from scholars and practitioners who are experts in their fields. Students also participate in co-curricular activities which help build skills for college life and beyond. Upon successful participation, students receive official Columbia University Certifications of Participation and written evaluations from their instructors.”

title: For a list of Fall 2025 College Now programs at campuses around the city,
Tomorrow’s Business Leaders Summer Program
description: “This free virtual program connects students who have an interest in business to young professionals who help them with resumes, interview skills, personal finance information, and more.
date: June - August (meetings twice a week, one weekday afterschool & one

title: Jane Street INSIGHT Business Program
description: “In this multi-day program, we invite women, transgender, and gender-expansive people to learn about the roles within our firm and how we solve challenges at Jane Street — including the specific concepts and tools we use in our daily work. As you explore opportunities within the program, you’ll notice that event topics and locations will vary. We offer classes and activities in three separate tracks: software engineering, trading, and strategy & product.”

title: Study Buddies Connect Summer Volunteering
description: “Study Buddies Connect is the educational support unit of the Association to Benefit Children. They run a summer tutoring intensive from July through August and are currently recruiting high school volunteers to help. This is a great opportunity to make a real difference in children's lives while also gaining hands-on experience. Volunteers work on reading, writing, math, and more with students.”

title: GeneraBridge Volunteering Opportunity
description: “GeneraBridge is a non-profit organization aimed at bridging the gap between the elderly and the youth. It is a virtual community service opportunity jointly hosted by over 350 nursing homes nationwide, including BAYADA Home Health Care, Atria Senior Living, and Brandywine Senior Living. Our volunteers can schedule video chats with the elderly from the nursing homes through our website and gain community service hours.”

title: Windows on Williams (WOW): Visit to Williams College
description: “WOW participants stay in dorms with current students, attend classes, meet with professors and learn about our admission process and extraordinary All-Grant Financial Aid program. Williams will pay for and arrange transportation to campus and cover all additional expenses including meals and overnight hosting in a dorm. Preference is given to high-achieving students who couldn’t otherwise afford to visit Williams.”

title: Priority Deadline Approaching:
description: Apex for Youth’s Virtual Mentorship Program “The National Virtual Mentorship Program (NVMP) pairs Asian American high school students — particularly those from immigrant or low-income backgrounds — with caring, vetted mentors for long-term, 1:1 guidance. Through virtual mentorship, students receive guidance on academics, college and career planning, and navigating the unique challenges of growing up Asian American. NVMP is especially designed for youth who don’t have access to Apex for Youth’s in-person programs, creating a safe, empowering space no matter where they live.” What students get:  1:1   mentorship for at least 2 years  Monthly   Zoom workshops with peers nationwide  Up   to $40K in scholarships  Career   & college readiness support A   free summer retreat in NYC
eligible: All Asian-American students may apply – focus on those from lower-income

title: Yale Undergraduate Moot Court 2025 Summer Legal Scholars Program
description: “During our one week virtual program, you’ll master the principles of moot court and put them into practice with our annual program showcase. You’ll be learning from the best of the best — competitors on Yale Undergraduate Moot Court don’t just excel at moot court at a national level, but are also involved in other public speaking activities like debate and Mock Trial. You will also have the chance to hear from legal professionals about their paths to law school and to practice — many of whom did moot court in undergrad or in law school. Through this program, students will develop critical thinking, legal analysis, and public speaking skills, guided by experienced mentors and judges.”

title: NYC Youth Food Advocates
description: YFA is for young people who want to learn about social justice, public policy and advocacy, and are ready to create systemic change in New York City food systems, with a focus on school food. YFA members complete a week-long summer leadership training, attend (virtual) weekly meetings during the school year and participate in 4 in-person workshop days throughout the year. YFA members also receive a stipend of up to $550.

title: Summer Arts Dorill Program
description: “The Summer Arts Dorill Program provides a structured, supportive space for young people to explore multiple art forms, work alongside experienced teaching artists, and connect with peers in a creative environment.”
location: The Lower Eastside Girls Club, 402 E 8th Street, Manhattan

title: School of Visual Arts Pre-College Program
description: “The School of Visual Arts offers various courses including animation, cartooning, interior design, etc. Students will have the opportunity to enhance their creative skills, learn about a particular field of art, and develop their portfolios. This year, there is an in-person option offered for students, as well as virtual courses. Three credits will be awarded for the successful completion of the summer program.”
location: Virtual or in-person at 209 East 23rd Street, Manhattan

title: Event Approaching: Metropolitan Museum: Teens Take the Met!
description: “Come and be the first to experience The Met’s new Michael C. Rockefeller Wing, featuring the Museum’s collections of the arts of Africa, the ancient Americas, and Oceania. With performances, music, and more, there's something for everyone to enjoy. No link—free and open to all teens 13 and older who bring their middle or high school ID.”

title: Deadline Approaching: UCLA Game Lab High School Summer Institute
description: “The UCLA Game Lab Summer Institute introduces high school students to game making as a form of artistic practice, teaching them the techniques and tools that will help them develop analog and digital games that reflect their own creative voice and vision. Students develop a solid aesthetic and technical foundation in various aspects of game design as well as learn how to express personal ideas through game-making.
