Taught by alumni of the UCLA Game Lab, these workflow-oriented classes focus on learning the fundamentals of game design, creating compelling game characters, building game worlds, and programming games. By the end of the two weeks, students will have created complete games or game assets in each of the four classes.”
date: July 7 - July 18 (Virtual), July 20 - August 2 (In-Person), or July 21 – August 1
location: Virtual OR In-Person at the University of California, Los Angeles

title: Girls Who Code Summer Immersion Program Waitlist
description: The Girls Who Code free virtual two-week summer computer science immersion program welcomes current 10th and 11th grade applicants. Robotics, web design, industry & mentor meetings, and other exciting experiences are available. Interested students should apply ASAP to be placed on the waitlist, which closes in August.
eligible: Current female freshmen, sophomores, and juniors who haven’t taken AP

title: Bronx Health Prospects 2025-2026 Medical Program
description: “BxHP is a free developmental online high school program focused on educating and empowering students interested in pursuing a career in healthcare. The BxHP team consists of student leaders from the acclaimed Bronx Community Health Leaders (BxCHL) program. Our mission is to encourage and educate underrepresented high school students interested in healthcare. We are excited to invite high school students from all grades who are passionate about exploring the healthcare field to join our program for the 2025-2026 academic year.”
eligible: Focus on under-represented groups; all students may apply

title: Deadline Approaching: Behind the Curtain: Technical & Design Careers
description: “The New York City Center Externship Program introduces students and young adults to the many career options available to them in the arts, focusing on creative, technical, design, and administrative arts jobs. Utilizing breaks in the NYC public school year, each session is centered around in-depth, experiential seminars. Under the guidance of City Center staff and artists, participants will have opportunities to explore responsibilities and tasks for a variety of arts jobs and have a greater understanding of non-profit operations. Each program is free and includes daily lunch and complimentary tickets to a City Center production. Upon completion of each session, participants will leave with their creative project materials.”
location: New York City Center. 131 West 55 Street

title: Naval Horizons Essay Contest
description: “This contest challenges students to picture themselves in a STEM career by designing the U.S. Navy and Marine Corps of the future. Watch the videos to learn about U.S. Navy and Marine Corps STEM research areas and our people. Choose one of the STEM topics highlighted in the videos, conduct additional research on the subject, and compose your essay. Your essay needs to include 1) STEM Research Area, 2) Our People, and 3) The Future. The essays must be between 500-1,500 words total. All winners are eligible to receive a $200 cash prize.”

title: Breakthrough Junior Challenge Video Contest
description: “You’ve grasped an important scientific theory, concept or principle. Now can you share your insight? An inventive video can get across complex material that would take pages of text to communicate. To take part in the Breakthrough Junior Challenge, create a short video (two minute maximum) to explain a big idea in one of these fields: physics, mathematics, or life sciences. The top prize is a $250,000 scholarship!”

title: Young Artists and Writers Summer Workshops (YAWP)
description: SUNY Stonybrook is offering one-week creative & script-writing workshops for high school students on Zoom in July and August. The YAWP Summer Workshops will pair seasoned adult writers with students for workshops in fiction, personal narrative, poetry, playwriting and screenwriting.

title: Naval Horizons Essay Contest
description: “This contest challenges students to picture themselves in a STEM career by designing the U.S. Navy and Marine Corps of the future. Watch the videos to learn about U.S. Navy and Marine Corps STEM research areas and our people. Choose one of the STEM topics highlighted in the videos, conduct additional research on the subject, and compose your essay. Your essay needs to include 1) STEM Research Area, 2) Our People, and 3) The Future. The essays must be between 500-1,500 words total. All winners are eligible to receive a $200 cash prize.”

title: Breakthrough Junior Challenge Video Contest
description: “You’ve grasped an important scientific theory, concept or principle. Now can you share your insight? An inventive video can get across complex material that would take pages of text to communicate. To take part in the Breakthrough Junior Challenge, create a short video (2:00 – two minute max) to explain a big idea in one of these fields: physics, mathematics, or life sciences. The top prize is a $250,000 scholarship!”

title: Transportation YOU High School Scholarship
description: “To assist women pursuing education and professional careers in transportation- related fields, the Greater New York Chapter of WTS invites eligible women to apply for the scholarships. The Transportation YOU High School Scholarship for $1,500 is awarded to an outstanding high school junior or senior interested in undertaking careers in transportation and studying math, science, engineering or technology.”
eligible: Priority to students identifying as female who are pursuing an education in a

title: Event Approaching: Brooklyn Community Board 9 Youth Job Fair
description: “Brooklyn Community Board 9's event will equip participants 14 and older with essential career skills through a series of informative workshops covering job development, interview preparation, elevator pitch techniques, and resume building. Attendees will have the opportunity to participate in a Q&A with industry professionals. They will also network with potential employers at a career fair. If you already have a resume, you should bring multiple copies for employers.”

title: Event Approaching: Let Me Finish! Girls Write Now Voices of Comedy
description: “Join us for Girls Write Now’s very first stand-up comedy showcase—an afternoon of laughs, empowerment, and celebration! Come enjoy an event filled with big laughs, bold stories, and plenty of heart, as mentees take the mic for their stand-up comedy debut. After the show, stick around to mingle and celebrate! Hosted by GWN teaching artist and Stand Up! Girls board member Hollie Harper, the evening will also feature performances by NYC-based female stand-up comedians. Let’s honor these young voices as they use comedy to challenge the status quo—one punchline at a time.”

title: Girls Write Now Salon Series - Writing the Places That Save Us
description: “Sometimes, the places we love are the spaces that allow us to create community. Sometimes, the places we love are the spaces keeping us alive. Join Reese’s Book Club LitUp Fellow Arriel Vinson as she discusses her debut YA novel, Under the Neon Lights, and explores what it means to write the places that save us.”

title: NYPL Anti Prom Event
description: “Come hang out and dance the night away at Manhattan Anti-Prom, the Library's annual celebration for teens, featuring music, art activities, snacks, and more. Special outfits are optional… but always encouraged! Anti-Prom welcomes and celebrates young people of all sexualities and gender identities and expressions. Featuring a special fashion show by student designers from the High School of Fashion Industries and a performance by Bharatnatyam dancers from Aalokam!”

title: Planet Fitness High School Summer Pass
description: “Starting June 1st, teens ages 14-19 can work out for FREE at Planet Fitness ALL SUMMER LONG! But don't wait, pre-register now!”

title: Program Dates Approaching: Vogue Summer School
description: “Vogue Summer School invites high school students who are curious and passionate about the world of fashion to experience it first-hand in the heart of New York City— one of the most important fashion capitals in the world. Students will explore a range of topics shaping the industry today and can choose from specialized courses in fashion business, fashion styling, and fashion media. Join like-minded students and fashion enthusiasts from around the world and go behind the scenes to learn about the inner workings of the fashion, media and lifestyle industries with Vogue experts as your guide.”

title: Program Dates Approaching:
description: The School of The New York Times: Summer Academy N.Y.C. “Summer Academy N.Y.C. at The School of The New York Times is designed for curious-minded high school students interested in learning how to think critically and creatively about the world. Students explore a range of subjects including journalism, business, politics and the arts alongside New York Times journalists and other industry thought leaders. Learn more about our two-week programs available this June and July in New York City.”
date: Term 1: June 8 - 20, Term 2: June 22 - July 4, Term 3: July 6 - 18, Term 4:

title: LVC Summer One-Week Actuarial Science Camp
description: “Students with an interest in actuarial science, math, and finance are welcome to apply for either the late June or mid-July sessions. Students will work in teams and present their solutions to relevant problems; practicing actuaries will give real time presentations and work with students on mini projects.”
location: Lebanon Valley College (101 N College Ave, Annville, PA 17003)

title: Deadline Approaching: Jane Street WISE Program
description: “In this challenging multi-day program, we invite women, transgender, and gender- expansive people to learn how we use math, computer science, and probability concepts in trading. This program was created for people who are early in their undergraduate studies, including students about to start their first year of university. Participants will have the chance to meet some of our traders and technologists and learn how they transitioned from studying STEM subjects to careers at Jane Street.”
eligible: Current seniors who are female, transgender, or gender-expansive

title: The Knowledge Society (TKS) Innovation Program
description: “TKS is a 10-month global innovation program for ambitious high school students. By the end of the 10-month program, students will gain real-world work experience with organizations such as Google, Meta, Airbnb, the United Nations, and Mastercard, be future-ready with a good understanding of emerging technologies such as Artificial Intelligence, develop a portfolio of projects that can be used to stand out in university applications, internships, and more, and learn the mindsets, confidence, and problem- solving abilities you'll need to be a leader. And, you will be mentored by industry professionals, and have the chance to earn scholarships.”
location: Virtual or In-Person at various locations

title: Smarts4Hearts
description: “Smarts4Heart matches high school & college students with families needing reliable babysitting and/or tutoring while donating a portion of our proceeds to the Ronald McDonald House New York. Signing up is an easy, 4-step process!”
date: Weekends, After school, and During Summer

title: Deadline Approaching: Senior Summer Success Camp
description: “Interested in learning about the college admissions process? Want some help applying, finding your best fit school and choosing a career path? If so, Senior Summer Success Camp is for you! Join us for a summer of learning, college readiness, trips, food and workshops. Our experienced team of College Advisors are equipped to provide guidance from college/university choices to financial aid, school work balance, and more. In the end, you will have gained knowledge to successfully complete the college admissions process during your Senior year of high school.” Metro cards will be provided.
date: July 8 - August 6 (Tuesdays and Wednesdays, occasional Thursdays)
location: East Side Community High School, East 12th Street, Manhattan

title: RNH College Directions Summer Bridge Program
description: “RNH Summer Bridge will provide insider tips, guides and support for your upcoming college application process. At the end of the program, you will have knowledge to effectively research colleges based on your needs, do a first draft college essay, compile a college list, get an overview of the college financial aid process & available scholarship opportunities, and experience college trips/Guest Speakers from CUNY, SUNY & Private Colleges. A $200 stipend will be awarded upon completion of the program requirements.”

title: Harvey Mudd College’s Fall FAST Fly-In Program
description: “The Future Achievers in Science and Technology (FAST) is our all-expenses-paid (in other words, free for you!) overnight fly-in program for high-achieving, college- bound high school seniors who demonstrate strong potential to leave a meaningful impact within the fields of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM). During the program, you will have an opportunity to interact with current Harvey Mudd students, professors, and other high school seniors to envision a collaborative, interdisciplinary future in STEM.”
date: September 14 - 16 (FAST Part I) & October 26 – 28 (FAST Part II)

title: University of Massachusetts/Amherst College Prep Workshops
description: “College prep workshops at UMass Amherst offer high school students an essential toolkit for college preparedness: practical skills and knowledge to confidently navigate the college application process. Choose from two invaluable online workshops: learn SAT & ACT test prep strategies, or craft a true-to-life personal essay using techniques from UMass Amherst's award- winning Writing Program. Or, join us on campus for a weeklong summer intensive covering admissions strategy, essay writing, test prep and more.”
location: Virtual or at 300 Massachusetts Ave, Amherst, Masachusetts

title: Student Historian Internship 2025-2026 Program
description: “Student Historian interns are high school students who use the resources of the New York Historical Society to conduct exciting research and share their scholarship through creative digital projects. Interns meet with professional staff to learn about careers in the museum, library, and history fields; work collaboratively with fellow students to develop their public speaking and leadership skills; and engage in hands- on work to deepen their understanding of American history. The theme of this year’s internship is “Our Composite Nation: Frederick Douglass’ America” Upon completion, participants receive a $700 stipend.
location: New York Historical Society (170 Central Park West, Manhattan)

title: Deadline Approaching: New York Film Academy Summer Camps
description: “New York Film Academy is hosting Summer Camps in New York, Los Angeles, Miami, & Online, in programs including Filmmaking, Acting for Film, Game Design, Musical Theatre, Screenwriting, & more! Taught by industry professionals, students learn by doing, completing projects in their chosen discipline. These programs also build transferrable skills like collaboration, presentation, and discussion, preparing them for high school and beyond.”

title: Summer Sports Instructional Programs
description: Free summer sports instruction and play programs are open to all students. These include, tennis, golf, soccer, and more.

title: The New York Academy of Sciences Junior Academy
description: “The Junior Academy is a virtual community of international students ages 13-17 who are passionate about science, technology, engineering and math (STEM), and committed to making a difference in the world. Within the Junior Academy community, STEM professionals are available to act as mentors, who guide teams throughout their challenge process. Start your application today to learn advanced research and innovation skills and collaborate with a global team to tackle real-world challenges!”
eligible: All students between the ages of 13 – 17 (cannot turn 18 before 5/1/26)

title: SUNY Purchase Summer Tech Camp
description: This virtual program offers a range of computer & tech courses, including animation, 3D modeling and more, along with gaming, social, and wellness activities. Languages include Python and Java.
date: Various one-week sessions from June 22 – August 1
cost: $1,400 by check or $1,450 by credit card for commuters; additional $625

title: LVC Summer One-Week Actuarial Science Camp
description: “Students with an interest in actuarial science, math, and finance are welcome to apply for either the late June or mid-July sessions. Students will work in teams and present their solutions to relevant problems; practicing actuaries will give real time presentations and work with students on mini projects.”
location: Lebanon Valley College (101 N College Ave, Annville, PA 17003)

title: Hack Club Athena Award
description: “Hack Club wants you to make things. Cool engineering things. Things you love to make. If you code and deploy three technical projects and spend 30 hours of coding by Oct 31st, Hack Club will issue you the Athena Award certification. This is an exclusive badge for your website/LinkedIn/GitHub that is recognized by colleges like MIT and employers like SpaceX. You will also instantly qualify to join Hack Club's NYC hackathon - the nation's largest all-girl hackathon - running from November 14th-November 16th. 250 girls can attend this 36 hour event, and we'll issue nearly 100 travel stipends.”

title: First Session Approaching:
description: Inspirit AI Scholars Sessions – Summer Courses “AI Scholars Live Online is a 10-session (25-hour) program that exposes high school students to fundamental AI concepts and guides them to build a socially impactful project. This year we have exciting ChatGPT and Generative AI-focused projects, and special sessions that we hope will help build a relevant and unique AI passion project, taught by our team of graduate students from Stanford, MIT, and more. Inspirit AI students will explore applications, create foundational AI concepts, and develop AI programming skills before developing a Social Good project. No prior programming or computer science background is required, but an interest in AI is appreciated!”
date: Various from early June – late August

title: Cosmetic Science and Formulation Design Summer Camp
description: “Did you know that The University of Toledo College of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences has the nation’s only bachelor’s degree program in cosmetic science and formulation design? If you're interested in learning about the process of creating makeup and personal care products, join us for our second annual Virtual Cosmetic Science and Formulation Design Summer Camp. Participants will receive a camp kit including a t-shirt, DIY activities, games, and more! Challenges will be incorporated throughout the live camp and give attendees the opportunity to win prizes!”

title: Program Dates Approaching:
description: The School of The New York Times: Summer Academy N.Y.C. “Summer Academy N.Y.C. at The School of The New York Times is designed for curious-minded high school students interested in learning how to think critically and creatively about the world. Students explore a range of subjects including journalism, business, politics and the arts alongside New York Times journalists and other industry thought leaders. Learn more about our two-week programs available this June and July in New York City.”
date: Term 1: June 8 - 20, Term 2: June 22 - July 4, Term 3: July 6 - 18, Term 4:

title: Event Approaching: Let Me Finish! Girls Write Now Voices of Comedy
description: “Join us for Girls Write Now’s very first stand-up comedy showcase—an afternoon of laughs, empowerment, and celebration! Come enjoy an event filled with big laughs, bold stories, and plenty of heart, as mentees take the mic for their stand-up comedy debut. After the show, stick around to mingle and celebrate! Hosted by GWN teaching artist and Stand Up! Girls board member Hollie Harper, the evening will also feature performances by NYC-based female stand-up comedians. Let’s honor these young voices as they use comedy to challenge the status quo—one punchline at a time.”

title: Girls Write Now Salon Series - Writing the Places That Save Us
description: “Sometimes, the places we love are the spaces that allow us to create community. Sometimes, the places we love are the spaces keeping us alive. Join Reese’s Book Club LitUp Fellow Arriel Vinson as she discusses her debut YA novel, Under the Neon Lights, and explores what it means to write the places that save us.”

title: Final Education PSA Scholarship
description: “This year, we are inaugurating our first Financial Education PSA Scholarship to current and incoming undergraduate and graduate students. The goal is to provide students with an outlet to educate their fellows in an area of financial literacy that interests them. You will write a public service announcement (PSA) addressed to your peers. Choose a topic related to financial literacy and craft a persuasive and informative PSA according to the guidelines below. The winning submission, selected by our scholarship selection committee, will receive $1,500.”

title: Event Approaching: Girls Write Now One Letter 4 All Workshop Series
description: “Join us at the series kickoff to provide loving messages to people dealing with loneliness & isolation, in an inspiring afternoon of creative social activism at the home of Girls Write Now. We will write compassionate letters to Asian American elders from systemically under-resourced neighborhoods, and youth from a detention center in Birmingham, Alabama—connecting them all with the voices of the Girls Write Now community.”

title: NYPL Anti Prom Event
description: “Come hang out and dance the night away at Manhattan Anti-Prom, the Library's annual celebration for teens, featuring music, art activities, snacks, and more. Special outfits are optional… but always encouraged! Anti-Prom welcomes and celebrates young people of all sexualities and gender identities and expressions. Featuring a special fashion show by student designers from the High School of Fashion Industries!”
location: Main Library at Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street, Manhattan

title: College Now Fall Program at City College
description: “College Now at CCNY allows qualified New York City public high school students to enroll in courses that earn college credit and provides academic enrichment workshops and programs to its 35 partner high schools, strengthening students' foundation for academic success. Students have the opportunity to experience the richness of our campus by enjoying access to our facilities and by participating in academic, social, and cultural events. Interaction with CCNY faculty and students gives College Now students an authentic college experience, eases their transition from high school, and prepares them for a successful academic career.”
location: City College of New York, (160 Convent Avenue, Manhattan)

title: Student Historian Internship 2024-2025 Program
description: “Student Historian interns are high school students who use the resources of the New York Historical Society to conduct exciting research and share their scholarship through creative digital projects. Interns meet with professional staff to learn about careers in the museum, library, and history fields; work collaboratively with fellow students to develop their public speaking and leadership skills; and engage in hands- on work to deepen their understanding of American history. The theme of this year’s internship is “Our Composite Nation: Frederick Douglass’ America” Upon completion, participants receive a $700 stipend.
location: New York Historical Society (170 Central Park West, Manhattan)

title: Fusion Academy
description: Fusion Academy offers a variety of virtual summer programs in which students can take courses in their areas of interest, receive tutoring and mentoring service, or prepare for college. Courses cover all subjects, and one-week academic camps are also offered.
location: Virtual and in-person options available (One MetroTech Ctr., Brooklyn)

title: Khan’s Tutorial Tutoring Jobs
description: “We are looking to hire graduating seniors for in-person tutoring positions across various branches (we have locations in Brooklyn, Manhattan, Queens, and the Bronx). Positions include Common Core instructors, SHSAT instructors, GPA/Regents instructors, and SAT instructors. The pay varies per position. Workdays for instructors are just on the weekend during the school year and leadership is understanding and accommodating to college schedules and student life. ”

title: The New York Public Interest Research Group (NYPIRG) Climate
description: Activists for Community Outreach Campaign “NYPIRG, New York’s leading environmental organization, is hiring passionate, motivated climate activists to staff our statewide community outreach campaign. NYPIRG is a nonpartisan, not-for-profit organization that advances important public interest issues through sophisticated grassroots organizing and advocacy, public education, and media exposure. Our Community Outreach teams are building the grassroots movement to hold elected leaders accountable, end fossil fuel dependency, and bring climate polluters to justice! Staff will be paid $17.25 hourly and have health coverage and paid vacation benefits.”

title: Hofstra University PreCollegiate Career Discovery Program
description: Hofstra University is offering various courses this summer and fall. There are writing courses for students interested in creative writing, novel writing, or digital journalism. There is an Aviation Academy, along with a Veterinary Skills program. There is also a program for students interested in the arts, in which they can develop their musical, acting, or drawing skills.”

title: Deadline Approaching:
description: Sparks Within Reach Summer Education Internship “We are currently seeking high-school students to volunteer as part of our summer program at P.S. 188 (The Island School) in lower Manhattan. Interns will have the opportunity to make a real impact with housing-insecure students by helping to lead academic and enrichment programming and providing individualized support to students. In addition, all interns will become trained in trauma-informed educational methods and have the opportunity to pursue an independent project at the end of the summer. In this project, interns will utilize what they have learned throughout the program to further address housing insecurity and education inequality in an innovative way. , and there is a separate program at the Barrier Free Living Housing Center in the Bronx – check the flyer to learn more.”

title: Volunteering at Maimonides Medical Center
description: “Our volunteers are a diverse group, but they have some things in common: they are bright, enthusiastic, and generous individuals who give their time and energy to help others. Whether you’re a student interested in learning about healthcare careers, an adult gaining practical experience, a retiree seeking new challenges, homemaker, or business person wanting to give back to others—we have opportunities for you. The minimum volunteer time commitment is two 4-hour shifts per week; however, certain programs have more specific commitment requirements. We happily provide a letter of recommendation for volunteers who have given at least 150 hours of satisfactory service.”
eligible: All students at least 14 years old

title: Rescuing Leftover Cuisine Volunteering Opportunity
description: “Volunteer in the fight against food waste and hunger by making food deliveries! All you have to do is bring excess food from our food donors to our nonprofit partners in your community. Food rescues typically take less than an hour of your time and can be done by public transportation, car, on foot, or bike. With just an hour of your time, you can help reduce food waste and provide meals to those in need in your community!”
eligible: All students – those under 16 must have an accompanying adult

title: Interns for SHSAT Prep Course for female under-represented middle
description: school students Volunteers may work part-time or full-time, Mondays through Fridays, 9am – 3pm. Interested students may email the address below to volunteer or to learn more: allannahthomas@heliconinc.org
location: Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis H.S., 120 West 46 Street, Manhattan

title: Speech & Debate Coaching for Younger Students
description: Students interested in helping teach Speech & Debate to youngsters, either via Zoom or in Jackson Heights this summer, may contact this email address to learn more: smkalita@gmail.com Asian Americans for Equality Volunteer Program “Are you looking to make a difference in your community? If so, joining the AAFE team as a volunteer is a great way to contribute in a meaningful way. As the impacts of the pandemic and the rise in AAPI hate continue to be felt in Chinatown, Flushing, Jackson Heights, Elmhurst, and beyond, AAFE has organized many mutual aid events to help provide food, clothing, social services, and housing assistance to the most vulnerable community members in the neighborhoods we serve. On an ongoing basis, we need volunteers to help set up and run our food pantries and other giveaways, help with Chinese and Spanish translation, provide professional services, and more.”

title: Matriculate High School Fellows
description: “Matriculate is a FREE virtual college advising program that connects eligible students with a near-peer mentor who works one-on-one with students throughout the college and financial aid processes. As a High School Fellow, you’ll have an Advising Fellow, someone from a similar background as you, walk you through every step of the process, 1:1, virtually, and for free. This includes creating a balanced college list, filling out applications, applying to financial aid and scholarships, preparing for college life, and more.”
eligible: Rising seniors taking a rigorous course load with a >3.5 GPA and <$90,000

title: Apex for Youth College Access Program
description: “Current sophomores may apply for our FREE College Access Program for the 2024-2025 school year. This is a great opportunity for students who are interested and would benefit from in-depth and individualized college application support. Program Description:  Receive individualized support with the college and financial aid research, preparation, and applications process  Work with a dedicated, adult volunteer to explore academic and professional interests  Participants will also have access to other Apex for Youth opportunities including FREE college visit trips, Apex Scholarships, internships, and community events  Program will start September 2024
date: One or two Saturdays per month during the 2024-2025 School Year

title: University of Massachusetts/Amherst College Prep Workshops
description: “College prep workshops at UMass Amherst offer high school students an essential toolkit for college preparedness: practical skills and knowledge to confidently navigate the college application process. Choose from two invaluable online workshops: learn SAT & ACT test prep strategies from bestselling test-prep author Brian Leaf, or craft a true-to-life personal essay using techniques from UMass Amherst's award-winning Writing Program. Or, join us on campus for a weeklong summer intensive covering admissions strategy, essay writing, test prep and more.”
location: Virtual or 300 Massachusetts Ave, Amherst, MA 01003

title: Repainting Our Narratives Community Summer Program
description: “This paid 4-week summer program will focus on the importance of our stories in building community, critical consciousness, and cherished memories. Students will work closely with local artists and organizations, exploring community narratives and gaining hands-on experience in public speaking, conducting interviews, tech management, and data collection. The program is based in and will focus on Brooklyn communities. At the end of the program, there will be a presentation where students will share the stories they've gathered and reflect on the impact these stories have had on their understanding of their communities and themselves. Students who successfully complete the program will receive up to a $1,000 stipend.”

title: Event Approaching: GuggTeens Sketching Sessions
description: “NYC teens are invited to join GuggTeens Sketching Sessions, a FREE drop-in program to expand drawing skills and connect with other teen artists. Teens will sketch from artworks on view in the galleries using experimental prompts and with educator guidance. This FREE series is open to all young people ages 13–19 and no prior experience is needed. FREE museum admission, MetroCards, refreshments, and materials will be provided. Learn more and register in advance to reserve your spot on the Guggenheim website.”

title: GuggTeens Sustainable Studio
description: “Connect with others students who are interested in artmaking and sustainability to reimagine the future of climate impact in the studio and beyond. During these twice- monthly FREE programs, students will explore current exhibitions, experiment with environmentally friendly studio practices, and learn about sustainability at the museum. This series is open to all young people ages 13–19 and no prior experience is needed. FREE museum admission, MetroCards, refreshments, and materials will be provided. Learn more and register in advance to reserve your spot on the Guggenheim website.”

title: NYC H2O
description: NYC H2O is a non-profit organization (founded by Stuy alum Matt Malina – Stuy ‘91) that focuses on environmental education and stewardship in the five boroughs. They provide service learning opportunities for students at their weekend volunteer ecological stewardship events in City parks. There are upcoming programs coming at the Ridgewood Reservoir in Queens and many more. Learn more by emailing Matt Malina at: matt@nych2o.org and at their website below.

title: The New York Academy of Sciences Junior Academy
description: “The Junior Academy is a virtual community of international students ages 13-17 who are passionate about science, technology, engineering and math (STEM), and committed to making a difference in the world. Within the Junior Academy community, STEM professionals are available to act as mentors, who guide teams throughout their challenge process. Start your application today to learn advanced research and innovation skills and collaborate with a global team to tackle real-world challenges!”
eligible: All students between the ages of 13 – 17

title: Drexel University Digital Development Camp
description: “The Drexel University Digital Development Camp is a three-week in-person summer program led by College of Computing & Informatics (CCI) faculty and student leaders. Digital Development Camp Students choose between three tracks. The FullStack track gives aspiring developers the opportunity to learn about full-stack web development, including front-end design, human-computer interface, user experience, and back-end development. The Data Science track uses computing for social good as a springboard for student led projects using publicly available data to address relevant issues in a particular community. The Human-Computer Interaction track provides students with the tools to improve user experience and enable collaborative problem-solving among groups.”
location: In-Person at Drexel University, Philadelphia, PA.

title: SUNY Purchase Summer Tech Camp
description: This virtual program offers a range of computer & tech courses, including animation, 3D modeling and more, along with gaming, social, and wellness activities. Languages include Python and Java.
date: Various one-week sessions from June 23 – August 2
cost: $1,400 by check or $1,450 by credit card for commuters; additional $625

title: Youth Drone Camps
description: “Our Youth Drone Camp is an interactive program that engages students in the engineering design processes while having FUN!! The students will learn the essentials of operating drones including piloting, regulations, safety, and communication. In addition, students will participate in a drone race against other students. Our certified Drone Pilot instructors will provide the students with basic knowledge of drone photography, videography principles and basic drone coding commands.”

title: Event Approaching:
description: Girls Write Now One Letter 4 All Workshop Series “Join us at the series kickoff to provide loving messages to people dealing with loneliness & isolation, in an inspiring afternoon of creative social activism at the home of Girls Write Now. We will write compassionate letters to Asian American elders from systemically under-resourced neighborhoods, and youth from a detention center in Birmingham, Alabama—connecting them all with the voices of the Girls Write Now community.”

title: Usdan Summer Camp Programs
description: “Usdan’s Classic Program provides an immersive arts experience and fosters friendship and shared enthusiasm among young artists in grades 2 through 12. Our program offers instruction by experienced educators and professional artists in five art disciplines—Art, Creative Writing, Dance, Music, and Theater—and three specialty areas—Chess, Nature & Sustainability, and Recreational Arts. Like the musical notation for which it is named, Usdan’s Allegro Music Program is fun-filled and upbeat—a camp experience that expands students’ appreciation of music. For four or eight weeks, musicians and vocalists in our Allegro Music Program immerse themselves in music and nature on Usdan’s 140-acre campus.”

title: Deadline Approaching:
description: The Bell Summer Youth Podcast Academy “The three-week summer podcasting academy will give you immersive, hands-on training that you will use to create your own podcast episode. You will have the exciting opportunity to work alongside professional storytellers, editors, and producers. Participants will get journalism and multimedia storytelling skills that will prepare you to pursue media-related fields, one completed podcast episode (contingent upon your timely completion of assignments), a $500 stipend, contingent upon successful completion of the program, as well as daily lunch and metro card allowance, and the opportunity to be considered for future internship programs.”

title: Event Approaching: Saturday Science: Fish Migration Day
description: “Wade into the Hudson River for World Fish Migration Day! Collect and count species of fish in partnership with the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory and the Hudson River Sloop Clearwater.”
location: W. 172nd Street Beach at the Hudson River

title: Event Approaching: Saturday Science: Manhattanville Community Day
description: “Join us for Manhattanville Community Day, a free fun-filled celebration of community! We invite families and neighbors of all ages to explore the workings of the brain through hands-on activities and engaging scientific demonstrations. Visit the BioBus Mobile Lab, learn about the human body and the natural world, and discover our collections of brains.”
location: Columbia's Jerome L. Greene Science Center, 605 West 129th Street,

title: City Tech Bridging the Gap (BTG)/ STEP Program
description: STEPis a program that aims to increase the number of underrepresented and lower- income students in STEM professions. Courses include Algebra II, Introduction to Virtual Reality (VR), Introduction to Artificial Intelligence (AI), Introduction to Medical Field and Public Health, and others. There will be FREE MetroCards, textbooks, school supplies, and academic workshops. Submit a complete application to Mhernandez@citytech.cuny.edu.
eligible: GPA of 70+, with a good attendance record, and who who meet under-

title: Hudson Valley Community College Summer Classes
description: “Take up to 8 credits for free this summer online through Hudson Valley Community College! There are courses in Biology, Chemistry, Accounting, Arts, ASL, Business, Computer Science, Civil Engineering, Law, Economics, Education, English, History, Health, Math, Marketing, the Physical Environment, Philosophy, Political Science, Sociology, Spanish, and Sports.”

title: Fusion Academy
description: Fusion Academy offers a variety of virtual summer programs in which students can take courses in their areas of interest, receive tutoring and mentoring service, or prepare for college. Courses cover all subjects, and one-week academic camps are also offered.
location: Virtual and in-person options available (One MetroTech Ctr., Brooklyn)

title: The New York Public Interest Research Group (NYPIRG) Climate
description: Activists for Community Outreach Campaign “NYPIRG, New York’s leading environmental organization, is hiring passionate, motivated climate activists to work with our community outreach program in our urgent fight against the climate crisis. NYPIRG is a nonpartisan, not-for-profit organization that advances important public interest issues through sophisticated grassroots organizing and advocacy, public education, and media exposure. Our Community Outreach teams are building the grassroots movement to hold elected leaders accountable, end fossil fuel dependency, and bring climate polluters to justice! Staff will be paid $17.25 hourly and have health coverage and paid vacation benefits.”

title: Hofstra University PreCollegiate Career Discovery Program
description: Hofstra University is offering various courses this summer. There are writing courses for students interested in law & criminal justice or mechanical and automotive classes. There is an Aviation Academy, along with a Veterinary Skills program. There is also a program for students interested in the arts, in which they can develop their musical, acting, or drawing skills.”

title: InvestIn Career Education Programs
description: “We are delighted to share with you our career opportunities, which are available in 19 cutting-edge industries. Learn directly from some of the world's best professionals - doctors, lawyers, engineers, investment bankers and more - through a series of live, interactive simulations which provide tailor-made professional experiences to ages 12-18.” Available careers: Medicine, Engineering, Investment Banking, Law, Psychology, Architecture, Art, Dentistry, Entrepreneurship, Fashion, Filmmaking, Forensic Science, International Development, Journalism, Politics, Software Engineering, Vet, Video Game Design, and Writing.
location: In-person in London (and other areas), or Virtual

title: West Side Campaign Against Hunger Volunteering
description: “West Side Campaign Against Hunger (WSCAH) is looking for volunteers to assemble and pack food boxes with fresh produce and shelf-stable food items. This is a great opportunity to volunteer at their new warehouse in Washington Heights!”

title: FXB Climate Advocates Summer Program
description: “The Summer 2025 cohort of the FXB Climate Advocates Program is a two-week intensive program that equips youth to informs, empowers, and mobilizes youth to implement climate solutions. Participants will join a global network of youth climate advocates from 45 countries and learn from renowned experts from the FXB Center for Health and Human Rights at Harvard University, New York University, Project Drawdown, and others.”

title: Keith Power for Manhattan Borough President Fellowship Program
description: “This program is dedicated to giving young people a voice in political campaigns by directly reaching out to voters from Inwood to Battery Park City, while giving you a front-row seat to this intense political battle. Fellows will engage in direct voter contact including canvassing, phone banking, and visibility efforts to reach out to voters in the district, communicate, and advocate for Keith’s platform, issues, and policies. Living in Manhattan is not required.”

title: Alvin Bragg for Manhattan District Attorney Campaign Internship
description: “Alvin Bragg’s re-election campaign for Manhattan District Attorney is seeking passionate and committed interns to support our grassroots efforts. Interns will support Alvin Bragg’s re-election campaign through direct voter contact— canvassing, phone banking, voter registration, and event outreach. A commitment of at least 5 hours per week is expected, with flexible scheduling and some remote options available. Interns will receive training, gain hands-on political experience, and build connections within NYC’s civic community. This internship runs through the June 2025 Democratic primary on June 24th and does not extend into the general election. To apply, please email your résumé or a short statement of interest to quinn@alvinbragg.com with the subject line: [Your Name] – Alvin Bragg Campaign Internship Application.”

title: The Putney School Summer Arts Program
description: “Join us to hear about this hilltop in Vermont where teens, artists, and writers gather each July to make art, write, and create community. Students ages 14-17 live in dormitories for four weeks on campus to attend creative workshops and community building. Workshops include animation, ceramics, dance, farming, filmmaking illustration, life drawing, metal jewelry, painting, printmaking, sculpture, songwriting, theater, vocal ensemble, weaving, and writing stories.”
date: July 20 – 25 (one week intensive), June 29 – July 18 (three week immersive),

title: FXB Climate Advocates Summer Program
description: “The Summer 2025 cohort of the FXB Climate Advocates Program is a two-week intensive program that equips youth to informs, empowers, and mobilizes youth to implement climate solutions. Participants will join a global network of youth climate advocates from 45 countries and learn from renowned experts from the FXB Center for Health and Human Rights at Harvard University, New York University, Project Drawdown, and others.”

title: Drexel University Digital Development Camp
description: “The Drexel University Digital Development Camp is a three-week in-person summer program led by College of Computing & Informatics (CCI) faculty and student leaders. It provides participants with the chance to engage deeply with technology and digital development topics, guided by expert faculty and student leaders. Participants gain hands-on experience in areas such as virtual reality, artificial intelligence, programming, and game development while building technical skills and exploring future paths in computing.”
location: In-Person at Drexel University, Philadelphia, PA.

title: Preludes Summer Teen Musical Theater Intensive
description: “Students ages 13-18 are invited to join the Preludes! Summer Teen Theater Intensive at New York City Center—a week-long experience designed just for teen performers who love musical theater. The intensive master classes with guest artists, foundational musical theater workshops, and the creation of a devised group musical number. The program pays students a stipend of $250 and includes lunch. Auditions are next week, from 6/9 – 6/13 - Learn more and register for the program on the website.”
eligible: All students; preference to current 9th, 10th, and 11th graders

title: Usdan Summer Camp Programs
description: “Usdan’s Classic Program provides an immersive arts experience and fosters friendship and shared enthusiasm among young artists in grades 2 through 12. Our program offers instruction by experienced educators and professional artists in five art disciplines—Art, Creative Writing, Dance, Music, and Theater—and three specialty areas—Chess, Nature & Sustainability, and Recreational Arts. Like the musical notation for which it is named, Usdan’s Allegro Music Program is fun-filled and upbeat—a camp experience that expands students’ appreciation of music. For four or eight weeks, musicians and vocalists in our Allegro Music Program immerse themselves in music and nature on Usdan’s 140-acre campus.”

title: Queens Public Library Intro to Podcasting for Teens
description: “Join us for a hands-on workshop where you'll dive into the world of storytelling through sound. We'll explore fun warm-up games, brainstorm creative ideas and themes, and learn the basics of recording and editing. Whether you're looking to amplify your voice or simply try something new, this program will help you build confidence and hone new creative skills in a supportive, collaborative environment. No experience necessary!”

title: Pioneer Academics 4th Annual Co-Curricular Summit
description: “Pioneer Academics is a research institute for high-achieving high school students seeking to conduct accredited research in STEM, social sciences, and humanities. Come and join us to learn about this year summit theme: ‘‘To Lead is to Learn: Cultivating Resilient Leaders for an Unpredictable World.”

title: Bike New York Summer Program
description: “This 6 week program offers participants a chance to learn the mechanics of riding a bike, the rules of the road, best practices for riding in a group and on the streets, and– of course–the joy and freedom of biking. Meets weekly.”

title: World Series of Innovation Entrepreneurial Challenge
description: “Explore the innovation challenges offered this season and see what grabs your interest. Set a timer and come up with as many ideas as you can in short order. Go wild with the rapid ideation then look over your list and choose your best idea. Once you've signed up to compete you can access the online entry form by clicking Get Started and get to work building your entry. Just remember to submit your idea by December 15”

title: Mapt Content Development Internship
description: We are actively seeking a group of 15-20 students for a three-week product management internship. The selected students admitted into the program will become Content Development Interns. This means they will collaborate with other lead student interns to create a milestone worth of in-app content for the Mapt College Planning mobile app. Interns will ultimately help Mapt’s product team to build a product people love to use.
date: July 14 – August 1 (2 or 3 times per week)

title: Deadline Approaching:
description: Sparks Within Reach Summer BUILD Internship 2025 “We are currently seeking high-school students to volunteer as part of our summer programs at P.S 188 (The Island School) and Barrier Free Living Housing Center. Interns at each program will have the opportunity to make a real impact with housing- insecure students by helping to lead academic and enrichment programming and providing individualized support to students. In addition, all Sparks interns will become trained in trauma-informed educational methods and have the opportunity to pursue an independent project at the end of the summer. In this project, interns will utilize what they have learned throughout the program to further address housing insecurity and education inequality in an innovative way.”
location: P.S 188 in lower Manhattan or the Barrier Free Living Housing Center (in

title: Camp College
description: “Students from across New York State will participate in a free, informative, fun day program experience! Students will engage in small-group discussions, a mock college course, and workshops on admissions and financial aid. They will learn college interview and essay-writing techniques and gain leadership, teamwork, and networking experience. Camp College is a great opportunity to learn about the many post-secondary options in New York State and beyond. It is also a great way to meet new friends and mentors who will support you on your path to success after high school!”
eligible: All students (priority to rising juniors and seniors)
cost: Free (transportation costs to and back NOT covered)

title: Mandatory Information Sessions Approaching: College Explorers Program
description: “Students meet twice a week to learn about college admissions, including developing college lists, college essays, financial aid, visiting college campuses, and more.”
date: July 15 – August 14 (Mondays & Wednesdays; Info Sessions – 6/16 and 6/18

title: Deadline Approaching:
description: FHAA Teen Leadership Program: Youth Ambassadors “The Forest Hills Asian Association (FHAA), a community leader in advocacy, cultural celebration, and civic engagement, is launching the FHAA Youth Ambassadors Program. This student-led initiative empowers local teens through leadership development, community service, career exploration, and cultural enrichment. As a youth-led initiative, FHAA trains student leaders to become the next generation of changemakers. The training will focus on leadership development, team dynamics and the key qualities needed to be an effective community organizer. Parental consent is required for participants under 18.”
date: July 10 to Sep 13 (Thursdays 5:30 to 7:30pm, Saturdays 2:00 to 4:00pm)
location: Queens Forest Hills public library, 108-19 71st Avenue

title: Debate League Summer Camp
description: “The Brooklyn Debate League, a nonprofit organization recently featured in the media, is hosting a summer camp this July in downtown Brooklyn. All rising 7th through 12th graders are invited to join. All levels of experience with Speech & Debate are welcome - whether you are brand new or a State Champion, we'll have coaches ready to meet you where you are. Visit our website to learn more and to sign up!”
location: M.S. 50 (183 S 3rd Street, Brooklyn) or virtual
cost: Sliding scale: (based on the NYC Area Median Income) OR $1,200 (in-person),

title: Queens Public Library Intro to Podcasting for Teens
description: “Join us for a hands-on workshop where you'll dive into the world of storytelling through sound. We'll explore fun warm-up games, brainstorm creative ideas and themes, and learn the basics of recording and editing. Whether you're looking to amplify your voice or simply try something new, this program will help you build confidence and hone new creative skills in a supportive, collaborative environment. No experience necessary!”
location: McGoldrick Library (155-06 Roosevelt Avenue Flushing, NY 11354)

title: Rooted in the City Internship
description: “You’ll get your hands in the soil, learn to ID local plants and trees (yes, even the ones growing through sidewalk cracks), and discover how fungi, dirt, and weeds have medicinal purposes. Through different cultural stories and traditions, you’ll explore how the plants we find in our city have been used for healing, ceremony, and connection across generations. Along the way, you’ll deepen your knowledge of traditional plant wisdom, express your learning through creative mediums, and start to see the city—and yourself—differently. Together, we’ll weave our experiences into a youth-led public event that blends nature, culture, and creativity: ‘Moving Through our Senses with the Plant World.’” A stipend of up to $550 will be provided for this program.

title: Pioneer Academics 4th Annual Co-Curricular Summit
description: “Pioneer Academics is a research institute for high-achieving high school students seeking to conduct accredited research in STEM, social sciences, and humanities. Come and join us to learn about this year summit theme: ‘‘To Lead is to Learn: Cultivating Resilient Leaders for an Unpredictable World.”

title: Deadline Approaching: Lucid AI Academy Application
description: “The Lucid AI Academy is offering cohort-based AI boot camps and a 1-on-1 mentorship program designed to help high school students develop real-world AI skills and build impressive portfolio projects. Students will learn from other student AI researchers and engineers, build advanced AI projects, gain practical skills, and join a community of like-minded students. There are 2 programs open: AI Innovators and 1-on-1 Research Mentorship.”

title: Cyber-AI Investigation Camp
description: “The Cyber-AI Investigation Camp will focus on increasing student interest in cybercrime investigation by teaching cybersecurity knowledge, safe online behavior, and cyber forensics investigation. Camp participants will engage in hands-on explorations of the many aspects of cybersecurity, including foundations of cybersecurity, cyber law, ethical hacking, AI, and digital forensics investigation techniques. Camp participants will explore the world of cyber investigation with experts in the field through fun, real-world learning experiences enhanced by teacher-student interaction. Camp activities include hands-on exercises, interactive lectures, games, and career exploration.”

title: Program Date Approaching:
description: miRcore Computational Biology Research Camps “This camp is for students interested in computer science, biology, and research. The camp will focus on the role of genomics in diseases and symptoms and guide students in performing computational biology research using patient RNA expression data to identify genes related to certain diseases. Students will learn basic AI concepts in identifying diseases.”

title: Deadline Approaching:
description: Queens Public Library Intro to Podcasting for Teens “Join us for a hands-on workshop where you'll dive into the world of storytelling through sound. We'll explore fun warm-up games, brainstorm creative ideas and themes, and learn the basics of recording and editing. Whether you're looking to amplify your voice or simply try something new, this program will help you build confidence and hone new creative skills in a supportive, collaborative environment. No experience necessary!”
location: McGoldrick Library (155-06 Roosevelt Avenue Flushing, NY 11354)

title: World Series of Innovation Entrepreneurial Challenge
description: “Explore the innovation challenges offered this season and see what grabs your interest. Set a timer and come up with as many ideas as you can in short order. Go wild with the rapid ideation then look over your list and choose your best idea. Once you've signed up to compete you can access the online entry form by clicking Get Started and get to work building your entry. Just remember to submit your idea by December 15”

title: Ronald V. Dellums Memorial SMART Scholarship
description: “The Science, Mathematics, and Research for Transformation (SMART) Scholarship- for-Service Program is a combined educational and workforce development opportunity for science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) students funded by the DoD.” Scholarship includes: full tuition, $30,000 annual stipend, job in DoD, mentorship, summer internships.”
eligible: Seniors who plan to pursue a degree in STEM

title: Coursera Free Online Courses
description: “The New York State Department of Labor has partnered with Coursera, a leading online training provider, to offer unemployed New Yorkers access to nearly 4,000 programs in high-growth industries. These programs cover data science, business, and technology, leading to certifications and enhancing your career prospects. A team of New York State experts curates content based on industry demand to help job seekers acquire needed skills.”

title: Fordham University Real Estate Institute
description: The Real Estate Institute offers three non-credit courses: Entrepreneurship and Innovation, Building Design and Sustainability, and Principles and Processes. Students who complete at least 2 courses receive a certificate. Courses are taught by industry professionals and center around real estate development in NYC.
date: Principles and Process: July 8 – 11 (10 am – 4 pm)

title: Salesforce Resume Review and Speed Networking Sessions
description: “Run It Back is a non-profit focused on helping students develop themselves personally & professionally. They team with local companies to provide mentorship and professional development opportunities. They are partnering with corporate professionals from the Salesforce Corporation to host high school students for Resume Review, Career Panel and/or Speed Networking sessions.
date: Resume Review on June 17 (3:45pm – 5:00pm) or Speed Networking on
location: Salesforce Office (1095 Av of the Americas, 6th Avenue, Manhattan)

title: Endless Frontiers Lab Youth Ambassador Program
description: “Each year, EFL invites high school students to apply for the opportunity to join EFL conference days and learn from leading investors, business experts, startup founders, and NYU scientists through the EFL Young Ambassadors program! Students admitted into the Young Ambassadors program will join EFL for at least one meeting day, where they will have the opportunity to shadow an EFL Mentor, attend morning mentoring meetings, and join an afternoon plenary session where they will meet up to 25 groundbreaking startups in Life Sciences, Deep Tech, or Digital Tech industries. If you have any questions, please contactinfo@endlessfrontierlabs.com ”

title: World Series of Innovation Entrepreneurial Challenge
description: “Explore the innovation challenges offered this season and see what grabs your interest. Set a timer and come up with as many ideas as you can in short order. Don't limit yourself! Go wild with the rapid ideation then look over your list and choose your best idea. Once you've signed up to compete you can access the online entry form by clicking Get Started and get to work building your entry. Just remember to submit your idea by December 10”

title: VISIONS’ Intergenerational Program Volunteer Service
description: “VISIONS’ Intergenerational Program recruits and trains students, 15 years of age and over, to assist older adults who are visually impaired or blind. Student volunteers are tasked with assisting in technology classes in order to promote computer literacy and independence. Working in pairs student volunteers will also assist with local neighborhood excursions in order to assist older adults with errands. Other responsibilities include assisting with administrative office tasks and special events at our Older Adults Center located at 135 West 23rd Street between 6th and 7th Avenue in Manhattan If you have any questions or need further information, please contact Lisa Senior by phone at 646-486-4444, ext. 213 or by email at lsenior@visionsvcb.org.”
date: Minimum of 3 days per week during the summer

title: West Side Campaign Against Hunger Volunteering
description: “West Side Campaign Against Hunger (WSCAH) is looking for volunteers to assemble and pack food boxes with fresh produce and shelf-stable food items. This is a great opportunity to volunteer at their new warehouse in Washington Heights!”

title: Volunteer for MoMath 2024 NYC Math Festival
description: “MoMath is seeking volunteers to help with the 2024 NYC Math Festival, a public event organized by the National Museum of M athematics. Suggested time frames for volunteering are as follows: ●   First shift (8:00 am to 1:00 pm): ○   Setting up the public event space. ○   Learning about the exhibit/activity to which you will be assigned. ○   Welcoming the general public and explaining or helping them explore the exhibit/activity. ○   Ensuring knowledge transfer by training the next shift of volunteers who arrive to take over your post. ●   Second shift (12:30 pm to 5:30 pm): ○   Learning about the exhibit/activity to which you will be assigned. ○   Welcoming the general public and explaining or helping them explore the exhibit/activity. ○   Breaking down the event space and helping to clean up. To express interest in volunteering for the 2024 NYC Math Festival, please contact volunteer@momath.org with your availability and a brief introduction if this is your first time volunteering at a MoMath event.”
location: Fosun Plaza (28 Liberty Street, Financial District/Manhattan)

title: Camp Invention Leadership Intern Program
description: “Leadership Interns work closely with Camp Invention and Invention Project participants to help them explore STEM concepts and become creative thinkers who can invent a better tomorrow.” Interns receive online leadership training from a professional coaching and training organization, build their communication skills when working with campers or directors, guide K-6th grade students through hands- on STEM challenges in the Camp Invention and Invention Project programs. They may also earn up to 40 volunteer hours.

title: Help For Autistic and Disabled Children
description: “Stephy Street Inc. is a nonprofit focused on helping autistic and intellectually disabled children obtain fulfilling experiences. Their program runs year round weekend indoor and outdoor classes, which focus on activities such as sports, music and art. We are looking for students who have interest in the pre-health field and have skills in music (piano, strings, drums), dance visual arts (painting, drawing), or sports. Volunteers will initially work for five weeks and receive a certificate of completion. After four weeks, dedicated students will then be given the opportunity to work for a paid hourly rate and advance within the company. Daily lunch and travel expenses are provided for all staff.”
date: Various during summer and/or fall term

title: Visiting Neighbors Volunteer Program
description: “With a friendly visit, seniors enjoy a few hours of a company each week, offering both the senior and volunteer an opportunity to learn from one another. Each visit is as unique as the two individuals involved. Seniors and volunteers share memories and warm conversation; they may listen to music together, watch a favorite movie or enjoy a hobby or a game of cards. Volunteers benefit from learning about an older person's life experiences, and seniors enjoy an opportunity to share their views with younger generations and stay connected with the outside world. You can also escort a senior. If you have a special skill, such as graphics or writing, we can always use your help. We also need help with special projects, such as volunteer elves to deliver holiday gifts, or to help in the office, or with fundraising activities.”
eligible: All students who are at least 15 years old

title: New Group Theater: College Writing
description: “Students will create “monologues” drawn from personal experience that can be used as Common Application essays. Finding compelling stories by practicing speaking and writing about themselves, students will engage in collaborative theater writing exercises to free up their ability to express themselves fully and openly in writing, and present their work in written and oral form for feedback from professional theater artists. Each class runs from 5:30 pm - 7:30pm, one day per week.

title: Chinatown Youth Initiatives Summer Leadership Institute
description: “Summer Leadership Institute (SLI) is a summer program tailored to Asian and Pacific Islander American (APIA) New York City youth to engage in conversations centered around social identities, privilege and power. SLI consists of a series of in- person weekly workshops held on Saturdays over the summer, complete with free programming and free lunch every week. SLI aims to create a safe space for discussion about topics not typically explored in high school curriculum and to build a welcoming community for youth with similar curiosities and passions. The program is facilitated by college students in a by-youth, for-youth format that is at the core of CYI’s mission, culminating in a tight-knit youth led group inspired to take action.”
location: University Settlement (273 Bowery) in Chinatown, New York

title: Camp Invention Leadership Intern Program
description: “Leadership Interns work closely with Camp Invention and Invention Project participants to help them explore STEM concepts and become creative thinkers who can invent a better tomorrow.” Interns receive online leadership training from a professional coaching and training organization, build their communication skills when working with campers or directors, guide K-6th grade students through hands- on STEM challenges in the Camp Invention and Invention Project programs. They may also earn up to 40 volunteer hours.

title: The Garibaldi-Meucci Museum Summer Art Classes
description: “Have you ever dreamt of creating stunning artworks but felt you lacked the skill? The Garibaldi-Meucci Museum invites you to transform those dreams into reality with our exclusive art classes. Under the expert guidance of Professor William J. Castello, embark on a creative journey designed to awaken the artist within. This four-part workshop will train even the most novice of participants to see, think, and draw like an artist. ”
location: Garibaldi-Meucci Museum, 420 Tompkins Ave., Staten Island, NY 10305

title: AI Programming Bootcamps & Research Project Mentorship
description: “The New York State Department of Labor has partnered with Coursera, a leading online training provider, to offer unemployed New Yorkers access to nearly 4,000 programs in high-growth industries. These programs cover data science, business, and technology, leading to certifications and enhancing your career prospects. A team of New York State experts curates content based on industry demand to help job seekers acquire needed skills.”

title: Program Start Date Approaching:
description: NYU CREATE Coding for Game Design High School Program “In this two-week session, participants will learn about the principles of game design, and will be introduced to C# and Unity scripting, which they will use to create their own custom games! The program emphasizes team collaboration and close work with experienced CREATE game designers and developers. Students will work together and independently to create 3D Unity games based on design principles and development techniques used by professionals at NYU.”

title: Science and Engineering Apprenticeship Program (SEAP)
description: “The Science and Engineering Apprenticeship Program (SEAP) places high school students in Department of Navy (DoN) laboratories where they take part in real Naval research for eight weeks during the summer. SEAP gives academically talented sophomores, juniors, and seniors interested in STEM the opportunity to learn about naval research and technology while receiving first-class mentoring by top scientists and engineers.”
eligible: Sophomores, juniors, and seniors pursuing STEM

title: Dates Approaching:
description: TryEngineering Summer Institute Programs “The IEEE TryEngineering Summer Institute provides an ideal atmosphere for students to explore the exciting world of engineering while making new friends and preparing for college life. Learn firsthand from notable experts in the field, go on behind-the-scenes tours of innovative engineering environments, complete exciting hands-on engineering design challenges, form friendships with other future engineers from around the world, and experience life on a college campus!”
location: University of Pennsylvania, Rice University, University of San Diego

title: Cyber-AI Investigation Camp
description: “The Cyber-AI Investigation Camp will focus on increasing student interest in cybercrime investigation by teaching cybersecurity knowledge, safe online behavior, and cyber forensics investigation. Camp participants will engage in hands-on explorations of the many aspects of cybersecurity including foundations of cybersecurity, cyber law, ethical hacking, AI, and digital forensics investigation techniques. Camp participants will explore the world of cyber investigation with experts in the field through fun, real-world learning experiences enhanced by teacher- student interaction. Camp activities include hands-on exercises, interactive lectures, games, and career exploration.”

title: High School Terminal Coding Challenge
description: “This July, Citadel and Correlation One are partnering to bring you the biggest coding competition for high school students. Terminal is a games-based AI challenge, where players code strategies to automate gameplay. Top performing students have the opportunity to win prizes, as well as global recognition. All students are welcome to register, even entry-level students with little experience with coding just to have fun!”

title: Penguin Coding School Free Trials
description: Students can sign up for one-hour free trials in Python and Java/APCS prep. “Our online free trial course options include Minecraft, Web Design, Java, as well as other crucial coding languages. We cap each online free trial class at 4 students so that they are able to work directly with their teacher through zoom.” Students may also request a 1:1 free trial session.

title: Summer at SEM: Creative Arts Programs
description: “Our Creative Arts summer camp provides students an opportunity to develop new skills, methods, approaches, and experiences in their craft. Our faculty are leaders in their fields and bring experiences to create environments for our students to take risks and challenge themselves. Our Creative Arts community is proud of its dedication and commitment to the arts.”

title: New Group Theater College Writing
description: “Students will create “monologues” drawn from personal experience that can be used as Common Application essays. Finding compelling stories by practicing speaking and writing about themselves, students will engage in collaborative theater writing exercises to free up their ability to express themselves fully and openly in writing, and present their work in written and oral form for feedback from professional theater artists. Each class runs from 5:30 pm - 7:30pm, one day per week.

title: World Series of Innovation Entrepreneurial Challenge
description: “Explore the innovation challenges offered this season and see what grabs your interest. Set a timer and come up with as many ideas as you can in short order. Don't limit yourself! Go wild with the rapid ideation then look over your list and choose your best idea. Once you've signed up to compete you can access the online entry form by clicking Get Started and get to work building your entry. Just remember to submit your idea by December 10”

title: Ronald V. Dellums Memorial SMART Scholarship
description: “The Science, Mathematics, and Research for Transformation (SMART) Scholarship- for-Service Program is a combined educational and workforce development opportunity for science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) students funded by the DoD.” Scholarship includes: full tuition, $30,000 annual stipend, job in DoD, mentorship, summer internships.”
eligible: Seniors who plan to pursue a degree in STEM

title: Event Approaching: Columbia STEM QUEST Free Event
description: “STEM QUEST: Discover Your Future Career is a dynamic event to empower students to explore careers in Science, Technology, Engineering & Mathematics (STEM) and healthcare through themed workshops and panels.” Come and partipacte in CUIMC Programs Fair and get some free giveaways and free snacks!
location: Vagelos Education Center, 104 Haven Avenue, Manhattan

title: Event Approaching:
description: Ask Her Anything: An Honest Conversation About Women’s Health “Join us for an afternoon of support, learning, and empowerment at the Center for the Women of New York at Fort Totten. This special event is designed to create a safe and welcoming space for women to ask anonymous questions about their mental and physical health. We’re honored to welcome Nina Rondon of the National Alliance on Mental Illness (NAMI) as our first guest speaker. Nina will address your questions on mental health and share valuable insights and resources. Come as you are, bring your questions, and leave with knowledge and support. Light refreshments will be served. This event is co-sponsored by the Center for the Women of New York.”
location: The Center for the Women of New York (207 Totten Ave, Bayside)

title: Stonybrook University - Japanese Pop Culture: A Window into Society,
description: History, and Identity “Explore how anime, manga, and pop culture reveal Japan’s changing society, identity, and values. No Japanese knowledge needed, just curiosity and a love for powerful stories!” This course is asynchronous and offers 3 credits.

title: The Science of Well-Being for Teens Course @ Yale University
description: “This 6-week course aims to help adolescents by bringing together the best insights from Dr. Laurie Santos’ popular Yale course “Psychology and the Good Life.” In this course, you will explore what the field of psychology teaches us about how to be happier, how to feel less stressed, and how to thrive in high school and beyond. The lessons, along with short weekly ‘happiness homework’ assignments will prepare you to put these scientific findings into practice. The ultimate goal is for you to feel better and build healthier habits.”

title: Wharton Global High School Investment Competition
description: “The Wharton Global High School Investment Competition is a free, experiential investment challenge for high school students (9th to 12th grade) and teachers. Students work in teams of four to seven, guided by a teacher as their advisor, and have access to an online stock market simulator. Together, they learn about strategy- building, teamwork, communication, risk, diversification, company and industry analysis, and many other aspects of investing.”

title: South Street Seaport Museum Volunteering
description: “Volunteers work to support every aspect of the Museum but are most often seen working on the waterfront at Pier 16. Work includes cleaning and organizing, repairs, painting, polishing, varnishing, and general maintenance. In the spring, the operational vessels are fitted out and re-rigged for the coming season, and in the late fall they are downrigged for winter. Most labor can be unskilled. Training is provided.”
eligible: Students who are at least 16 years old

title: Harvey Mudd College’s Fall FAST Fly-In Program
description: “The Future Achievers in Science and Technology (FAST) is our all-expenses-paid (in other words, free for you!) overnight fly-in program for high-achieving, college- bound high school seniors who demonstrate strong potential to leave a meaningful impact within the fields of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM). During the program, you will have an opportunity to interact with current Harvey Mudd students, professors, and other high school seniors to envision a collaborative, interdisciplinary future in STEM.”
date: September 14 - 16 (FAST Part I) & October 26 – 28 (FAST Part II)

title: University of Massachusetts/Amherst College Prep Workshops
description: “College prep workshops at UMass Amherst offer high school students an essential toolkit for college preparedness: practical skills and knowledge to confidently navigate the college application process. Choose from two invaluable online workshops: learn SAT & ACT test prep strategies, or craft a true-to-life personal essay using techniques from UMass Amherst's award- winning Writing Program. Or, join us on campus for a weeklong summer intensive covering admissions strategy, essay writing, test prep and more.”
location: Virtual or at 300 Massachusetts Ave, Amherst, Masachusetts

title: The Voice of Democracy Audio-Essay Contest
description: The Voice of Democracy is a democratic and patriotic-themed essay contest. This year’s theme is “How Are You Showing Patriotism and Support for Our Country?” Students will draft an essay that treats the theme with imagination and human interest, record their reading of it to a CD/flash drive, and submit it to their local VFW post.

title: Parsons Summer Academy
