description: “Join us for two weeks at our Greenwich Village campus to explore art and design through hands-on projects that develop your creative thinking skills, techniques, and collaborative abilities. Students with prior art and design experience may take our portfolio development course to re-envision their current body of work as they create portfolio presentations for the college admissions process. Courses will count toward the Parsons Academy Certificate program.”

title: Discover Your City with Culture Pass
description: “Explore local museums and other City attractions with Culture Pass, New York City's free discovery program for City library cardholders. If you have a library card from either the Brooklyn Public Library, the Queens Public Library, or the New York Public Library, you can reserve a Culture Pass online for any of 100+ cultural institutions across the five boroughs.”

title: Hudson River Park Science Leadership Program: Fall Term
description: “Selected interns will work in a team of high school peers and Hudson River Park staff. Interns will conduct hands-on STEM research on the Hudson River, develop a scientific communication and research project and present their work at the end of the program at HRPK's annual Release of the Fishes event. Interns will attend workshops led by local practitioners on professional development, science identity and the diversity of pathways in the STEM field. SLP interns will develop proficiency in field research, data collection and interpretation with the goal of strengthening communication and leadership skills. High School interns will receive a stipend of $300 which will be paid at the close of the internship.”

title: Event Approaching: Columbia STEM QUEST Free Event
description: “STEM QUEST: Discover Your Future Career is a dynamic event to empower students to explore careers in Science, Technology, Engineering & Mathematics (STEM) and healthcare through themed workshops and panels.” Come and partipacte in CUIMC Programs Fair and get some free giveaways and free snacks!
location: Vagelos Education Center, 104 Haven Avenue, Manhattan

title: Clear Direction STEM Mentoring Program
description: “Through Clear Direction Mentoring, high school students who are interested in STEM careers can become Fellows and obtain mentors who are STEM professionals working for local City-based research institutions. Throughout the year, fellows and mentors stay in communication with one another while attending career panels, college open houses, tours of scientific laboratories, virtual reality centers, museums, tours of local tech companies, and more.”

title: Hudson River Park Science Leadership Program: Fall Term
description: “Selected interns will work in a team of high school peers and Hudson River Park staff. Interns will conduct hands-on STEM research on the Hudson River, develop a scientific communication and research project and present their work at the end of the program at HRPK's annual Release of the Fishes event. Interns will attend workshops led by local practitioners on professional development, science identity and the diversity of pathways in the STEM field. SLP interns will develop proficiency in field research, data collection and interpretation with the goal of strengthening communication and leadership skills. High School interns will receive a stipend of $300 which will be paid at the close of the internship.”

title: Congressional App Challenge 2025
description: “The annual Congressional App Challenge is an opportunity for young people to cultivate their skills in these STEM disciplines and to begin thinking about their futures in the many American industries that will rely on emerging technologies and STEM innovation in the coming years. Students may use any programming language they choose, including C, C++, JavaScript, Python, Ruby, “block code,” etc.

title: Youth Space Organization:
description: Aerospace Expert Feedback on Research Proposals Program and Competition “High school and undergraduate students are invited to submit a 1–5 page research proposal on any space-related topic to the Youth Space Organization’s Feedback Program. Every high-quality submission will receive personalized feedback from aerospace industry experts. If you choose to opt in, your proposal will also be entered into our global research proposal competition. The top three proposals will be selected for special recognition!”
eligible: All high school and undergraduate students
deadline: RSVP by July 1st, submission of research proposals due by

title: Capital One Coders Program
description: “Coders is a free, virtual, 2-day beginner web development program designed around 6th–8th grade curriculum content. However, the program is open to all students entering 6th–12th grade. This makes it a great opportunity for anyone looking to learn or refresh foundational web development skills. Students will be introduced to key web development concepts, including HTML and CSS, and will create their own website by the end of the program. Both AiC Community members and non-members may apply. Spots are limited—apply now.”

title: Program Dates Approaching:
description: Columbia Scholastic Press Association Summer Journalism Workshop “The Columbia Scholastic Press Association (CSPA) invites print and online publication staff to take part in its 44th Annual Summer Journalism Workshop, offered with both in-person and virtual options. CSPA offers a week-long, in-person workshop in June on the Columbia campus, as well as three distinct virtual sessions in July. The annual workshop is organized by CSPA and hosted by Columbia University. Each session offers sequences focused on either reporting and writing, editorial leadership, and design.”
location: In-person at Columbia University, or virtual
cost: $999 - $2,199 (depending on choice of virtual, commuter, or residential options)

title: Youth Onstage!
description: “Youth Onstage! (YO!) introduces young people, ages 14 to 21, to performance, improv, and the world of theatre, offering free training in the performing arts under the direction of volunteer theatre professionals. Training emphasizes ensemble building and offers experiential outings, workshops, and classes, all led by theatre professionals.”
location: All Stars Project, 543 W 42nd Street, Manhattan

title: Suffolk University Filmmaking Summer Program
description: “Dive into the world of moviemaking with our dynamic community of filmmakers, teachers, and VIP guest speakers and industry professionals. Here in downtown Boston—a city immortalized on the silver screen—you’ll develop your skills in directing, editing, screenwriting, sound design, camera work, and collaboration. You’ll also work with industry-standard equipment and software, see what it’s like to be part of a creative team, and have serious fun. You don’t need prior filmmaking experience to enjoy this program, just a desire to maximize every moment of this amazing experience.”

title: Gotham Writers' I'm Obsessed Contest
description: “Do you have what some people may consider a niche hobby or special interest? Perhaps you're REALLY into collecting 1990s-vintage wide-legged jeans, or maybe you know everything there is to know about handheld videogames? Or maybe it's a totally made-up obsession? Either way; Gotham Writers is looking for interesting stories about your hobbies as part of its I'm Obsessed Contest—and the contest's winner will receive a free Gotham Writers class of their choosing!”

title: Wharton Global High School Investment Competition
description: “The Wharton Global High School Investment Competition is a free, experiential investment challenge for high school students (9th to 12th grade) and teachers. Students work in teams of four to seven, guided by a teacher as their advisor, and have access to an online stock market simulator. Together, they learn about strategy- building, teamwork, communication, risk, diversification, company and industry analysis, and many other aspects of investing.”

Students may use any programming language they choose, including C, C++, JavaScript, Python, Ruby, “block code,” etc.

title: The Voice of Democracy Audio-Essay Contest
description: The Voice of Democracy is a democratic and patriotic-themed essay contest. This year’s theme is “How Are You Showing Patriotism and Support for Our Country?” Students will draft an essay that treats the theme with imagination and human interest, record their reading of it to a CD/flash drive, and submit it to their local VFW post.

title: Luna Hackathon
description: “Luna Hackathon, organized by Hack Club, a worldwide organization dedicated to supporting teens interested in computer science, is a day-long programming marathon where students team up to attend workshops, code new projects, learn basic programming skills, and have fun. Luna Hackathon invites all teenagers who identify as girls or gender-nonconforming youth to attend the event for 12 hours of creating, exploring, and sharing!”
eligible: All students who identify as a girl, non-binary, or gender-nonconforming

title: Macaulay Honors College Events
description: For students interested in learning more about the Macaulay experience, Macaulay hosts information sessions for prospective students about admission requirements, key dates, essay tips, the Macaulay application, information from Macaulay students, and more.

title: Virtual NACAC National College Fairs
description: “Free and open to the public, National College Fairs are the perfect place to kick off your college search. Admission representatives from schools across the country are all gathered in one place. Their goal: To encourage you to learn more about their institutions, and help you sort through the qualities you’re looking for in a college. Use your visit to explore your options, ask questions, and gather information.”

title: Open House New York (OHNY) Weekend
description: “OHNY Weekend is an annual festival that opens hundreds of noteworthy or significant places across the five boroughs for three days of in-person and virtual tours, talks, and special activities. It is a free celebration of “the power of place,” fostering discovery and delight for all New Yorkers and deepening the public’s understanding of how design can strengthen communities and improve quality of life.”

title: Columbia University Spring Academic Year Weekend Remote Courses
description: All students are invited to apply for weekend classes in a wide variety of fields, including Creative Writing, Psychology, Science, Medicine, and more.

title: Harvard Undergraduate Women in Business Oriented Leadership
description: Development (BOLD) Conference This is an event for high school women leaders who are pursuing empowerment and knowledge from inspirational businesswomen. The ‘Business Oriented Leadership Development’ (BOLD) conference is designed to help the next generation of women leaders obtain skills and guidance toward their future in business. Participants will learn about business and engage with current Harvard business majors and local business leaders.”
cost: $135.23 (in-person cost on the Harvard campus) & $44.52 (virtual cost)

title: Young Founders Lab Startup Bootcamp
description: “Young Founders Lab is a selective start-up bootcamp for ambitious high school students. In the program, you work under the guidance of mentors from places like Google, Microsoft, and Meta to build your own revenue generating start-ups. Young Founders Lab is a real-world start-up bootcamp based on incubators such as the Y- Combinator. You have the option to work individually or in groups.”

title: Robert Zur Company Fashion Internship
description: “The Robert Zur fall intern program is an opportunity for high school interns interested in the fashion industry. It offers a remarkable chance to dive headfirst into the world of fashion and gain invaluable hands-on experience in a professional environment. By participating in this program (unpaid), interns will have the opportunity to acquire knowledge and skills that are highly sought after in the industry. Different positions include Data Science Analytics, E-Commerce Interns, Digital Marketing Specialist, and Content Creator. Internships are unpaid - You will obtain a Certificate of Completion upon completion of internship.”

title: St. Jude Leadership Volunteer Opportunity
description: “Join a remarkable group of students in learning how to make meaningful connections with peers, mentors, and business leaders, all while supporting St. Jude patients and families. During a six-month period, members will have an opportunity to exercise their leadership skills while raising funds and awareness for the kids of St. Jude. Like- minded teens will follow a mentor, participate in leadership development, shared experiences, and transformational fundraising.”

title: Events Approaching : CACNY Senior Series Program
description: “Senior Series is a 3-month college access program intended to support high school seniors through various aspects of the college application process. Senior Series features both in-person and virtual workshops on topics including college choice, applications, admissions, and success. During our workshop sessions, we guide students through navigating the Common App, and SUNY and CUNY application portals. In addition, we offer office hours, which serve as advisory sessions where students receive one on one support for writing college essays and FAFSA completion. Participants who successfully complete all outlined milestones are eligible to receive up to a $500 stipend.”
location: Hybrid; In-Person at 185 Broadway 2nd Floor, Brooklyn 11211

title: First Event Approaching: Macaulay Honors College Events
description: For students interested in learning more about the Macaulay experience, Macaulay hosts information sessions for prospective students about admission requirements, key dates, essay tips, the Macaulay application, information from Macaulay students, and more.

title: Programs at Columbia's Double Discovery Center
description: “Established in 1965, DDC provides low-income and first-generation college-bound community youth and families with a comprehensive set of services to support young people’s college readiness. Our Academic Enrichment activities provide students with exciting project-based classes across the humanities, STEM, and the arts. Through our College & Career Success work, students are immersed in small group and individual sessions that increase their capacity for college access & persistence and that facilitates their career exploration & development. Consequently, our Healthy Minds & Bodies efforts are designed to develop students’ dispositions and skills for resilience and persistence as well as to build their capacity to nurture their physical and mental well-being so that they can overcome challenges in their quest to, through, and beyond college.”
eligible: Low-income, first generation students who live in Harlem and Washington
location: Double Discovery Center at Columbia University (2920 Broadway, MC

title: TurnUp Civic and Activism Remote Internship:
description: “TurnUp Activism is a progressive non-profit organization dedicated to making the world more just, fair, and equitable for all by increasing youth activism and civic engagement to strengthen our democracy. Interns work in remote teams of mission- driven young people and hear from expert speakers to help amplify youth civic engagement and participate in activism on many issues, including climate change, racial justice, reproductive rights, ending gun violence, and combating voter suppression. Students can count their participation for community service hours and TurnUp is authorized to give out awards and certificates, including The President’s Volunteer Service Award.”
date: Various: 5 hours and up a week

title: St. Jude Leadership Volunteer Opportunity
description: “Join a remarkable group of students in learning how to make meaningful connections with peers, mentors, and business leaders, all while supporting St. Jude patients and families. During a six-month period, members will have an opportunity to exercise their leadership skills while raising funds and awareness for the kids of St. Jude. Like- minded teens will follow a mentor, participate in leadership development, shared experiences, and transformational fundraising.”

title: The Bronfman International Fellowship
description: Current juniors who identify as Jewish are eligible for a free five-week summer travel fellowship in Israel. Participants also participate in follow-up events in the U.S such as a winter seminar and monthly Zoom sessions. There will be a virtual information sessions on October 10 at 9 pm and November 12 at 8 pm.
eligible: Current juniors who identify as Jewish & will be 16 by Summer 2024

title: Librarians of Tomorrow Internship at the Brooklyn Public Library
description: “Librarians of Tomorrow is an innovative, hands-on internship program for 10th-12th grade students from diverse backgrounds with an interest in library careers. We seek committed and enthusiastic individuals who are ready to learn, work, and help others! Interns will build their academic, college, and career readiness skills with support from a mentor, work behind the scenes on developing cutting-edge programming and projects and receive a stipend and volunteer service hours. Interns will complete 20-30 hours of training and field trips and 70-80 hours of hands-on work experience by creating a capstone project and assisting with a variety of library programs, events, and projects.”

title: AMIGOS Summer Study Abroad Service Project Program
description: “AMIGOS programs bring together young people from the U.S. and Latin America to collaborate on ethical service projects, learn from local experts, develop leadership skills, and build bridges across cultures. We ensure that AMIGOS students take part in the daily life of their host community, as well as in service projects that are community-led. Available programs for Summer 2025 include : ‘Service in the Heath of South America’ (Paraguay), ‘Sustainability in the Rural Highlands’ (Panama), ‘Eco-Tourism and Environmental Protection’ (Costa Rica), ‘Highlands Biodiversity’ (Costa Rica), ‘Marine and Mountain Exploration’ (Costa Rica), ‘Supporting Sea Turtle Habitats’ (Panama), and ‘Cross-Cultural Connection and Nature’ (Paraguay).”

title: Yale Splash Program
description: “Splash is a one-day program of classes taught by Yale students on a diverse range of subjects, such as Into the Future: How Spider-Verse Forced Animation to Evolve, Introduction to Improv Comedy, Elementary Particle Physics, Ethics Meets Self- Driving Cars: Philosophy, Technology and More, Kafka and Monty Python, The Syrian Refugee Crisis, Feminism in the Beyonce Era, and more.”
location: Yale Campus (451 College St, New Haven, CT)

title: Deadline Approaching: Swiss Institute Paid Teen Programs
description: Teen Classes: SI’s weekly after-school teen classes are a paid ($16/hr) program during the school year for teenagers 15-18 years old. Each of SI’s teen classes are centered around a theme related to contemporary art, with lectures and discussions, close looking activities, art making, and individual and collaborative projects inspired by the theme. Weekly classes will involve discussions, art making, and deep exploration into artistic practices. We will tour Swiss Institute’s current exhibitions, go on trips to other arts and culture spaces, and meet guest artists who will share their journey and process with us. Classes will meet on select Tuesdays, 4:30pm-6:30pm for 15 sessions between October 22, 2024 and April 8, 2025. A full schedule and application can be found here. Registration is now open! Applications will be accepted through Sunday, September 29. SI TEEN COUNCIL: Swiss Institute Teen Council (SITC) is a paid ($16/hr) opportunity for teens of all backgrounds (ages 16-21 years old) to share their ideas, explore leadership and collaboration, and create original content centered on a teen and young adult audience. SITC’s goals include: planning events and programs centered around a teen and young adult audience, fostering a creative environment and engage with the arts, including the visual and performing arts, design, and architecture, playing an advising role in future SI teen and young adult programs, and creating opportunities for SITC members to grow professional skills to help with future endeavors in various career paths. Students are welcome to apply to and participate in both Teen Class and Teen Council for the same season if accepted. SITC will meet on select Thursdays, 4:30pm-6:30pm for 15 sessions between October 17, 2024 and April 3, 2025. A full schedule and application can be found here. Registration is now open! Applications will be accepted through Sunday, September 29.
eligible: Teen Classes: Students 15 and older; Teen Council: Students 16 and older
cost: Free – students are paid for participation

title: The Metropolitan Museum of Art (MET) Internship
description: “The High School Internship Program allows you to connect one-on-one and in small cohorts with Museum professionals in a number of related fields, including editorial, marketing, social media, education, scientific research, conservation, and more. During your time at The Met, you will have the chance to find the intersection of your interests as you gain insights from peers and professionals.” Students will receive a $1,100 stipend upon successful completion.

title: Museum of Moving Image Teen Council 2024-25 Internship
description: “Teen Council is a job development program for NYC teens interested in the media arts who want a behind-the-scenes look at how a media museum works. As a part of the Teen Digital Media Innovators program, Teen Council members curate and program public events for youth, including film festivals, media workshops, and more. This paid opportunity includes mentorship from museum media educators, filmmakers, actors, and museum programmers. Council members receive hands-on learning to shape an active space for youth interested in curating, public programing, and the overall day-to-day operations of an arts and cultural organization, and they will gain real-world experience in the hybrid craft of organizing and project management while exploring the history and technology of the moving image. Teen Council is a job development program and provides a stipend upon completion.”
eligible: Students who are at least 15 years old

title: The James Alan Cox Foundation for Student Photojournalists Award
description: “The focus of the work and entries is photojournalism, and students whose work ‘tells a story’ will be awarded. Subject matter for your still photo submission should relate to current issues the world faces. Five (5) Digital SLR Cameras will be awarded to five (5) high school students, who should only submit still photographs.” Students will be required to submit an application, a brief essay, two letters of reference, a school transcript, financial data, a portfolio, and a parental release form (for high school students who are minors).
eligible: Current sophomores, juniors, and seniors who have taken at least one

title: Conrad Challenge
description: “High school teams from around the world develop and pitch real-world STEM solutions to aviation, health, cybersecurity, and other global problems in this prestigious entrepreneurial contest, named for astronaut Pete Conrad. You must register with at least one other team member, teams can consist of 2-5 students, with no limits on where you are collaborating (break the boundaries, it’s more fun that way!)”
eligible: All students who will be 18 years old anytime between August 2024 –

title: Luna Hackathon
description: “Luna Hackathon, organized by Hack Club, a worldwide organization dedicated to supporting teens interested in computer science, is a day-long programming marathon where students team up to attend workshops, code new projects, learn basic programming skills, and have fun. Luna Hackathon invites all teenagers who identify as girls or gender-nonconforming youth to attend the event for 12 hours of creating, exploring, and sharing!”
eligible: All students who identify as a girl, non-binary, or gender-nonconforming

title: Deadline Approaching:
description: Teaching the Brain: Healthcare Career Mentorship “This is a four-month mentorship program that connects high school students with mentors in undergraduate, graduate, or medical programs. It offers teens firsthand insights into careers in healthcare, neuroscience, and research through weekly meetings. Mentors provide guidance and support, helping to inspire the next generation of healthcare professionals!”

title: Vet Up! Champions: The National HCOP Academy for Veterinary
description: Medicine Program “The Vet Up! Champions program integrates face-to-face and interactive online learning to provide a 12-month structured curriculum to a cohort of 26 students, comprised of rising high school juniors & seniors, adult/nontraditional learners, and first or second-year undergraduate students. Champions will prepare for entry into veterinary college by receiving mentorship, financial and cultural competence training, and exposure to veterinary careers. Students are required to travel to West Lafayette, Indiana, and attend presentations at the Purdue University College of Veterinary Medicine on June 23-25, 2025”
eligible: Rising juniors and seniors with an educationally or economically
location: Virtual ; in-person conference at Purdue University in late June (travel

title: Tisch Spring Future Artists Program
description: “The Future Artists Program is a free, 14-week program that offers art workshops about dance, drama, recorded music, photography, filmmaking, dramatic writing, cinema studies, and game design with the mission of providing free arts education to qualifying students. Students should arrive ready to absorb, challenge, and internalize what is being offered in this collaborative, rigorous program.”

title: Local Letters for Global Change: A Pulitzer Center Writing Contest
description: “This contest invites students across the world to write a letter to a local elected representative that explains a global issue that matters to them, shows how it connects to their local community, and proposes a solution. Letters may be written in English and/or Spanish, and students will be judged in separate high school, middle school, and elementary categories. All finalists will have their letters, photos, and bios published on the Pulitzer Center website, and first-place winners will receive $300 to support global community engagement in their classroom.”

title: Sarah Lawrence College: Writing Courses
description: “Whether this is your first writing class or you’re finishing your next book, The Writing Institute at Sarah Lawrence College helps writers grow and connect with a community of passionate writers. Our classes and workshops range from generative experiences to revision-focused workshops, including one-day craft intensives and seminars on publishing. Virtual writing workshops and in-person classes at our Bronxville, NY campus are available. All writers are welcome! Questions about which class is best for you? Contact the Writing Institute at writinginstitute@sarahlawrence.edu.”
location: Virtual or in-person (1 Mead Way, Bronxville, NY)

title: Local Letters for Global Change: A Pulitzer Center Writing Contest
description: “This contest invites students across the world to write a letter to a local elected representative that explains a global issue that matters to them, shows how it connects to their local community, and proposes a solution. Letters may be written in English and/or Spanish, and students will be judged in separate high school, middle school, and elementary categories. All finalists will have their letters, photos, and bios published on the Pulitzer Center website, and first-place winners will receive $300 to support global community engagement in their classroom.”

title: Elk National Foundation Most Valuable Student Scholarship
description: “The Elks National Foundation will award 500 four-year scholarships to the highest- rated applicants in the 2025 competition. Male and female students compete separately. Ranging from $1,000 per year to $7,500 per year, these scholarships are for students pursuing a four-year degree, on a full-time basis (minimum of 12 semester hours), in a U.S. college or university. All scholarships are in the form of certificates of award, conditional upon the full-time enrollment of the winner in an accredited U.S. college or university.”
eligible: Current seniors who are U.S. citizens

title: Event Approaching: Luna Hackathon
description: “Luna Hackathon, organized by Hack Club, a worldwide organization dedicated to supporting teens interested in computer science, is a day-long programming marathon where students team up to attend workshops, code new projects, learn basic programming skills, and have fun. Luna Hackathon invites all teenagers who identify as girls or gender-nonconforming youth to attend the event for 12 hours of creating, exploring, and sharing!”
eligible: All students who identify as a girl, non-binary, or gender-nonconforming

title: Event Approaching: NYC STEM College Fair
description: “We are partnering with 20 colleges, universities, and other youth-serving organizations to bring high school and college-bound students a range of helpful resources! We'll have staffed tables with college and career readiness resources, as well as other educational and STEAM information in higher learning. Additionally, this is an exciting opportunity for students to learn more about FAFSA, and get tips on how to showcase their STEM experiences, achievements, and passions in the college application process.”

title: Event Approaching:
description: Kings Bay Brooklyn Public Library CRAFTIVISM: Teen Crafts and Activism for Period Action Day “Join authors Ali Terese and Rachel E. Gross for an afternoon of arts & crafts and conversations about menstrual equity. ● Create crafts, such as friendship bracelets, sculptures, and posters. ● Get your questions about periods, menstrual health, and puberty answered.”
location: Kings Bay Library, 3650 Nostrand Avenue, Brooklyn

title: NYU/Tandon Cybersecurity Games & Conference Event (CSAW’24)
description: CSAW, open to all students, is the most comprehensive student-run cyber security event in the world, featuring 7 cyber competitions, workshops, and industry events. Final events are hosted by 5 global academic centers.
location: NYU Tandon, Center for Cybersecurity, 370 Jay St, Brooklyn

title: YouthAsk Youth Census Survey
description: “Intergenerational Change Initiative (ICI) launched the Youth Ask Youth (YAY) Census, gathering responses from youth across five boroughs about their experiences related to learning, community, COVID-19, policing and more. We submit this data to major stakeholders like the Department of Youth and Community Development, the Department of Education, and the Deputy Mayor’s office. You can raise your voice, be heard... and earn a chance to win a $25 gift card, just by taking our survey!”

title: NYU SPS Career Pathways Bridge Program
description: “NYU SPS Division of Applied Undergraduate Studies (DAUS) offers low- or no- cost associate degree programs in Business, Information Systems Management, and Liberal Arts, that emphasize real-world learning experiences and equip students with the essential skills needed for today’s workforce. The Bridge Program provides a direct pathway into the NYU SPS associate degree program, a full scholarship, and academic assistance and career readiness during the fall semester. The Bridge Program and Bridge Scholarship also include paid internship opportunities, early college credit, academic advising, career coaching, and peer mentoring, along with cohort-style learning, career exploration, skill-building activities, meal plans, monthly Metrocards, and stipends for course materials and needs.”
eligible: Current Seniors who are eligible for Pell and TAP
location: Hybrid; In-Person at New York University

title: St. John’s Bread and Life
description: “Bread and Life works to ensure that communities have access to healthy, nutritious food. Tasks for volunteers include Pantry Bag Packer, Produce Packing, Maintenance volunteering, and Kitchen volunteering. Volunteering at Bread & Life allows individuals to directly combat food insecurity, a pressing societal issue, and make an immediate impact on the lives of those in need. All volunteers under 18 must be accompanied by an adult.
date: Mondays to Thursdays, 8:00am – 2:00pm (convenient for days with no school

title: First Event Today:
description: The Opportunity Hub - College Application Workshop Series “We invite your students and program participants to join us for a series of free virtual college admissions workshops. These workshops will provide valuable insights and strategies to help you navigate the college application process. The series will have workshops like Crafting Your College List, Navigating College Admissions, Unleashing Your College Essay, and Dollars & Degrees: Your Guide to Educational Finance.”

title: Thrive Scholars Programs
description: “Thrive Scholars is not just an academic program—it's a transformational experience. We provide high-achieving young people the opportunities they need to thrive at top colleges and in meaningful careers, all at no cost to the students. We’re looking for high-achieving, underrepresented students, including students of color from under- resourced communities, who excel academically, demonstrate leadership, and are passionate for attending a top university and pursuing a high-trajectory career. Thrive Scholars provides the OnRamp, 6-Year, and Thrive Academics programs.”
eligible: Sophomores and Juniors who identify as underrepresented students

title: Student Wellness Advocates
description: “The NYC Office of School Wellness Programs is launching Student Wellness Advocates, an opportunity for students in grades 9-12 to join a citywide youth leadership group. Student Wellness Advocates will implement NYCPS’ vision for student wellness, physical and health education, physical activity, school food, nutrition, and climate sustainability. Learn more at the links below; complete the Youth Leadership Council Online Application and be sure to check the NYC Public Schools/Students Wellness Advocates box to become a Student Wellness Advocate.
cost: Free –stipends will be given to participants

title: Council on International Exchange (CIEE) Study Abroad Programs Early
description: Birds Fly Free Raffle “CIEE offers a variety of programs for students to explore another culture and language in over 30 different countries. Through their Summer Abroad, High School Abroad, and Gap Year Abroad opportunities, students can “immerse themselves in a new language and culture”. Enter application by November 1 for a chance to fly free.

title: United States Senate Youth Program
description: “The United States Senate Youth Program, established in 1962 by U.S. Senate Resolution, is a unique educational experience for outstanding high school students interested in pursuing careers in public service. Two student leaders from each state, the District of Columbia and the Department of Defense Education Activity will spend a week in Washington experiencing their national government in action.” Recipients will also be granted a $10,000 scholarship.
eligible: Students in grades 11-12 who show demonstrated leadership by serving in

title: Congress Bundestag Youth Exchange Program (CBYX)
description: “CBYX is a full scholarship exchange program that offers young Americans the opportunity to live with a German host family and attend high school in Germany for a year. CBYX aims to foster cultural understanding and diplomacy while also promoting the German and English languages. Participants are also encouraged to learn about the political systems of their host country. Become fluent in German, learn about another culture, and expand your horizons.”
eligible: Students who are between the ages of 15 and 18.5 and U.S. citizens

title: TurnUp Civic Tech Challenge
description: “The TurnUp Civic Tech Challenge welcomes folks under age 26 to share their idea for a civic technology project that will promote youth voter registration, turnout, or activism. Enter for the chance to win up to $25,000 and TurnUp's support to help bring your vision to life. We welcome projects in any phase of execution, whether it's an idea or already in the works.”

title: Program Start Date Approaching:
description: Science Alliance: High School Program @ American Museum of Natural History “This course will revolve around the brand-new Susan and Peter J. Solomon Family Insectarium in the Richard Gilder Center for Science, Education, and Innovation. While in this course, students will explore entomology, insect biodiversity, human health, and the Museum scientists that have contributed research and specimens to the Insectarium. We will practice various insect collection methods in the field and preparation techniques back in the lab. Using the Museum’s insect collections and new technologies, students will explore a variety of digital tools that allow us to study these tiny creatures in new, more visible ways.”
location: American Museum of Natural History, 200 Central Park West, Manhattan

title: NYC STEM College Fair
description: “We are partnering with 20 colleges, universities, and other youth-serving organizations to bring high school and college-bound students a range of helpful resources! We'll have staffed tables with college and career readiness resources, as well as other educational and STEAM information in higher learning. Additionally, this is an exciting opportunity for students to learn more about FAFSA, and get tips on how to showcase their STEM experiences, achievements, and passions in the college application process.”
