description: “Luna Hackathon, organized by Hack Club, a worldwide organization dedicated to supporting teens interested in computer science, is a day-long programming marathon where students team up to attend workshops, code new projects, learn basic programming skills, and have fun. Luna Hackathon invites all teenagers who identify as girls or gender-nonconforming youth to attend the event for 12 hours of creating, exploring, and sharing!”
eligible: All students who identify as a girl, non-binary, or gender-nonconforming

title: Event Approaching: Teen Life AI Academy Bootcamp
description: “Interested in building AI projects from scratch? We invite current high school students interested in pursuing computer science and building a strong foundation in data science and machine learning to join us this fall to learn the fundamentals of Python, Data Science, and Artificial Intelligence. Start building your portfolio, including an AI capstone project you'll build from scratch, develop problem-solving skills to tackle complex challenges with AI, and more! No prior programming experience needed.”

title: NYU/Tandon Cybersecurity Games & Conference Event (CSAW’24)
description: CSAW, open to all students, is the most comprehensive student-run cyber security event in the world, featuring 7 cyber competitions, workshops, and industry events. Final events are hosted by 5 global academic centers.
location: NYU Tandon, Center for Cybersecurity, 370 Jay St, Brooklyn

title: Modeling the Future Challenge
description: “The Modeling the Future Challenge is a real-world competition for high school students interested in actuarial research. Teams conduct an actuarial research project in which they make recommendations to companies, organizations, government agencies, or other groups based on their own mathematical models, real-world data analysis, and risk management. The top research teams are brought to the national MTFC Symposium to present their work for a shot at being one of four teams who share an award of $60,000.”
eligible: High school students in the United States who are taking junior or senior

title: Modeling the Future Challenge
description: “The Modeling the Future Challenge is a real-world competition for high school students interested in actuarial research. Teams conduct an actuarial research project in which they make recommendations to companies, organizations, government agencies, or other groups based on their own mathematical models, real-world data analysis, and risk management. The top research teams are brought to the national MTFC Symposium to present their work for a shot at being one of four teams who share an award of $60,000.”
eligible: High school students in the United States who are taking junior or senior

title: Hispanic Heritage Foundation Youth Awards Scholarship
description: “The Youth Awards honors Latinx high school seniors who excel in the classroom and community and for their excellence in various categories including Business & Entrepreneurship, Community Service, Education, Engineering, Green Sustainability, Healthcare & Science, Media & Entertainment, Public Service & Social Justice, Sports & Fitness and Technology. Gold, Silver, and Bronze recipients are selected in each category and receive a one-time grant to fund their college education or community service effort that tackles a social issue.”
eligible: Current Seniors of Hispanic Heritage (including Spain, Brazil, &

title: Science Ambassador Scholarship
description: The Science Ambassador Scholarship offers 5 $20,000 tuition scholarship for a woman in science, technology, engineering, or math. Film a three–minute educational video of yourself explaining a STEM topic you're passionate about to be submitted.”
eligible: Current female or non-binary seniors interested in STEM majors Application

title: An Exploration of Algebraic Operations
description: “This series on different mathematical topics is appropriate for students in middle school and high school, but undergraduate and graduate students who are interested in the Mathematics Outreach Seminar and Training (MOST) program are welcome to attend to learn more. The MOST program provides early-career female mathematicians with professional development and speaking opportunities to advance and inspire others through math outreach. October 20th Session: Why is the order of operations in that order? Let’s take a peek behind the scenes of abstract algebra to better understand operations, how they work, and if they can be applied to objects other than numbers. Indulge in mathematical fun that extends into the evening! Participants will also explore the Museum’s dynamic exhibits, engage with a peer group that’s passionate about math, and enjoy decadent hot cocoa and chocolate chip cookies all night long.” This is a students-only drop-off program.

title: Event Approaching: Queens Borough Hall College Fair
description: “Borough President Donovan Richards is hosting a college fair at Queens Borough Hall, featuring representatives from dozens of public and private universities across the region and the New York State Higher Education Services Corporation. The fair will also feature workshops in multiple languages on securing financial aid to help you pay for college.”
location: Queens Borough Hall, 120-55 Queens Boulevard, Kew Gardens

title: Mentoring In Medicine (MIM) Virtual Biomedical Hackathon
description: “Mentoring In Medicine (MIM) is thrilled to announce our Virtual Biomedical Hackathon! This free, weekend-long event is designed to ignite a students' passion for science and empower them to make a real difference in public health. Teams of students will spend a weekend exploring a scientific paper, creating a public health campaign, or improving the design and marketing of a biomedical device. They will gain insights from leading scientists and healthcare professionals, connect with passionate students from across the country, and compete for exciting prizes.”

title: Events Approaching:
description: Lincoln Center Passport to the Arts for Students with Disabilities “Free concerts, opera, ballet, and other world-class performing arts -designed for children, teens and adults with disabilities and their families, Passport to the Arts provides a welcoming, accessible, and cost-free introduction to the performing arts at Lincoln Center. Families are invited to attend performances, interactive workshops, and virtual events with Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, New York City Ballet, The Metropolitan Opera, the New York Philharmonic, Jazz at Lincoln Center, Chamber Music Society, and more.”

title: First Event Approaching Museum of Finance Academy
description: “The Museum Finance Academy (MFA) is a FREE five-session personal finance certificate course for 11th and 12th graders with the goal of teaching students to aspire to financial independence through developing an appreciation for savings, establishing financial goals, and learning to avoid scams. This course requires NO prior knowledge of finance, business, or economics. The top students will be awarded college scholarships ranging from $500 to $1,000.”

title: Program Start Date Approaching:
description: Rock the Street Wall Street Finance Program Rock the Street Wall Street invites female students to apply for this series of six in- person sessions for Stuyvesant students, taking place after-school at Stuyvesant. Participants meet with female finance industry professionals and learn about personal finance, financial businesses, and more. Participants also receive help in finding summer internships in this business field. “We are excited to be starting another year of Rock the Street, Wall Street programming at Stuyvesant this year! We have a group of women from Invesco Corporation excited to meet the great group of students at Stuyvesant and share their time and knowledge with you all! Here are the details:” Fall Workshops @ Stuyvesant & Field Trip to Invesco Headquarters (near Stuy): Tuesdays, 4:00 - 5:00 PM from October 15 – November 19 Please register on our NEW RTSWS App to participate. The app can be accessed via the link below to access the registration form . Or scan the QR code in the link below for instructions. Contact Harvey Blumm at: hblumm@stuy.edu with any questions
date: October 15 – November 19; Tuesdays at Stuy in Room 411(4:00-5:00)

title: First Event Approaching: What Is Next (WIN) Career Development Series
description: “We connect high school students with professionals in STEM, finance, and entrepreneurship to help them explore career paths and build valuable networks. WIN provides students with: 1. Professional networking opportunities 2. Curated workshops with industry experts 3. A supportive community of peers and recent graduates 4. Life skills activities, from personal finance to pitching themselves”

title: Emma Bowen Foundation Internship (EBF) for Seniors
description: “EBF offers paid summer media-industry internships (with an affiliated scholarship) “for students from ethnic groups which are under-represented in media corporations” (including, among others, Latinos, Asian & African Americans). These spots are available at leading local media companies via the Emma Bowen Foundation. Eligible students who are interested in technical/engineering or news, broadcast, studio, and other non-technical aspects of this industry are invited to apply. There will be conferences, info sessions, workshops, panels, and dedicated team member to support interns.”
eligible: Current seniors from under-represented groups with a minimum GPA of 3.0

title: What It Takes Business/Leadership Programs
description: “WIT provides college credit social entrepreneur and leadership programs for students around the world in partnership with U.C.S.D.” A variety of classes are offered virtually and students can take a WIT quiz to find the program that fits them best, whether they’re getting started with entrepreneurship, digging deeper with a business, or looking into small business management.
date: Varying from four week courses to three months

title: Deadline Approaching:
description: Sparks Within Reach Fall Term Education Internship “We are currently seeking high school students to become volunteer tutors at P.S. 188 (The Island School), a K-8 public school on the Lower East Side of Manhattan. Many of the students at P.S. 188 are low-income, facing housing insecurity, or otherwise at- risk. Tutors will have the opportunity to make a real impact with these students by providing them with one-on-one academic and social-emotional support during the P.S. 188 afterschool program. We are looking for compassionate, dedicated 9th-12th grade students to join our team at P.S. 188 and help us make a difference in students' lives! Please note that no experience is required, as all instructors will be trained in tutoring methods, social-emotional learning, and trauma-informed teaching. Interested students may reach out to contact@sparkswithinreach.org with any questions.”

title: STEMpathize Volunteer Internship Opportunity
description: “STEMpathize is a youth-led organization based that collaborates with high school students to make STEM as approachable and accessible as possible through hands-on engaging workshops for students of grades 3-8. They are hosting virtual STEM workshops for their Fall 2024 Series and are seeking volunteers. Internship positions include Workshop Facilitators, Curriculum Designers, Outreach Team Members, Content Creators, Blog Writers, Social Media Managers, and Website Designers. Expect to hear from them within a week of application submission.”

title: Event Approaching: Virtual College Fair
description: All students are welcome to ‘attend’ this virtual fair, which will include represebtatives from 50+ colleges, plus workshops on financial aid and other relevant topics.

title: ArtsConnection Student Art Program (SAP) Contest
description: “Submit your artwork for a chance to have your work framed and exhibited in one of our corporate partners’ office spaces and receive a $100 Blick gift card!”

title: New York Public Library National Teen Art Contest: Freedom to Read
description: “Make your voice heard in the conversation about book bans and censorship for a chance to win $500, get published in Teen Voices magazine, and see your work exhibited in one of the Library's midtown locations! NYPL invites teens across the U.S. to submit original art to our contest on the theme of books, reading, censorship, or intellectual freedom.”

title: An Exploration of Algebraic Operations @ Museum of Mathematics
description: “This series on different mathematical topics welcomes Stuy students who are interested in the Mathematics Outreach Seminar and Training (MOST) program. The MOST program provides early-career female mathematicians with professional development and speaking opportunities to advance and inspire others through math outreach.We are delighted to offer students from Stuyvesant High School the opportunity to attend each event at a discounted rate of $5 by registering at momath.org/mostplus and using the discount code FIVEMOST. October 20th Session: Why is the order of operations in that order? Let’s take a peek behind the scenes of abstract algebra to better understand operations, how they work, and if they can be applied to objects other than numbers. Indulge in mathematical fun that extends into the evening! Participants will also explore the Museum’s dynamic exhibits, engage with a peer group that’s passionate about math, and enjoy decadent hot cocoa and chocolate chip cookies all night long.” This is a students-only drop-off program.

title: Code to Cure: AI and the Future of Health Instructional Video Event
description: “As part of the World Science Festival, Bryan Greene, professor of physics and mathematics at Columbia University (and a Stuy alumnus) joins scientist and Coursera co-founder Daphne Koller to discuss her new venture in using machine learning for drug discovery and development for

title: STEMpathize Internship Opportunity
description: “STEMpathize is a youth-led organization based that collaborates with high school students to make STEM as approachable and accessible as possible through hands-on engaging workshops for students of grades 3-8. They are hosting virtual STEM workshops for their Fall 2024 Series and are seeking volunteers. Internship positions include Workshop Facilitators, Curriculum Designers, Outreach Team Members, Content Creators, Blog Writers, Social Media Managers, and Website Designers. Expect to hear from them within a week of application submission.”

title: The Maysles Documentary Center Teen DocMakers Program
description: “The Teen DocMakers Lab (TDM) is a free award-winning, year-round, after school and summer intensive film program where high school students work in small teams to make a short documentary. TDM’s curriculum is founded in the cinematic tradition of the Maysles brothers, direct cinema/cinema verité, and encourages exploration of new approaches to filmmaking grounded in the innovative films/makers of today. We are looking for youth who have a story to tell, and want to make moving and honest films about subjects important to them.”
eligible: All students (priority to students from Upper Manhattan, Harlem, and the

title: The Bell Newsroom Internship
description: “Join ‘The Bell’s’ student newsroom to report on the latest education issues in New York City and beyond with a focus on equity. We are recruiting for multiple roles across both the ‘Miseducation’ and the ‘P.S. Weekly’ podcasts. Students will learn audio journalism skills, including interviewing, script writing, recording, audio editing, and marketing, meet professionals in the industry, go on field trips, and explore potential career paths. They will receive a $1,000 stipend and mentorship from professional reporters, producers, and editors.”
location: Bell Voices, Inc. @ 25 Broadway, 12th floor, Manhattan

title: The Lucille Lortel Theater High School Playwriting Fellowship
description: “The Lucille Lortel High School Playwriting Fellowship is an exciting eleven-week playwriting mentorship program focused on sparking and showcasing young creative voices. In this program, students must submit an original one-act play, approximately 10 minutes in length, with no more than ten pages of dialogue, two scenes, two locations, and four characters. Each of the seven selected Fellows will receive a $500 honorarium, a professional staged reading of the Fellow’s play, mentoring from theater professionals, a publication of the Fellow’s play, a certificate of recognition, dinner and tickets to a Broadway show, and publication of the Fellow’s play.
location: Lucille Lortel Theatre, 121 Christopher Street, Manhattan

title: Virginia B. Ball Creative Writing Scholarship Competition
description: “Students who submit their portfolio are considered for a chance to win a full-tuition scholarship to study Creative Writing at Interlochen Arts Academy. Previous recipients of the Virginia B. Ball Creative Writing Competition Scholarship have gone on to win or to be shortlisted for numerous awards including the Norman Mailer Award for Fiction, the PEN/Robert J. Dau Short Story Prize, Juxtaprose's Short Fiction Contest, and the Pushcart Prize.”

title: Kenyon Review Patricia Grodd Poetry Prize for Young Writers
description: Kenyon College in Ohio invites all current 10th & 11th-graders to enter their student poetry contest. The contest winner receives a full scholarship to their Kenyon Review Young Writers workshop. In addition, the winning poem and the poems of the two runners-up will be published in the Kenyon Review.

title: Youth Communication Writing Contest
description: “Youth Communication is sponsoring a writing contest for young people. Every three months, we will highlight five recent articles and ask readers to write a response to the author of a story. Tell them how you related to their story, what lessons you learned, or other ways the story impacted you. We will choose three winners with prizes of $150 (1st prize), $75 (2nd prize), and $50 (3rd prize.)”
eligible: All students who are at least 14 years old

title: ArtsConnection Student Art Program (SAP) Contest
description: “Submit your artwork for a chance to have your work framed and exhibited in one of our corporate partners’ office spaces and receive a $100 Blick gift card!”

title: Youth Communication Writing Contest
description: “Youth Communication is sponsoring a writing contest for young people. Every three months, we will highlight five recent articles and ask readers to write a response to the author of a story. Tell them how you related to their story, what lessons you learned, or other ways the story impacted you. We will choose three winners with prizes of $150 (1st prize), $75 (2nd prize), and $50 (3rd prize.)”
eligible: All students who are at least 14 years old

title: Virginia B. Ball Creative Writing Scholarship Competition
description: “Students who submit their portfolio are considered for a chance to win a full-tuition scholarship to study Creative Writing at Interlochen Arts Academy. Previous recipients of the Virginia B. Ball Creative Writing Competition Scholarship have gone on to win or to be shortlisted for numerous awards including the Norman Mailer Award for Fiction, the PEN/Robert J. Dau Short Story Prize, Juxtaprose's Short Fiction Contest, and the Pushcart Prize.”

title: New York Public Library National Teen Art Contest: ‘Freedom to Read’
description: “Make your voice heard in the conversation about book bans and censorship for a chance to win $500, get published in Teen Voices magazine, and see your work exhibited in one of the Library's midtown locations! NYPL invites teens across the U.S. to submit original art to our contest on the theme of books, reading, censorship, or intellectual freedom.”

title: Jack Kent Cooke Scholarship
description: The Cooke College Scholarship Program is awarded to high-achieving high school seniors with financial need who seek to attend and graduate from highly competitive four-year colleges and universities in the US. Each award is intended to cover a significant share of the student’s educational experience – including tuition, living expenses, books and required fees. Awards vary by individual. Scholarship applications are submitted through the Common App. Students will have to submit two academic recommendations and a counselor recommendation.

title: The Elevate Mental Health Awareness Scholarship
description: The goal of the Elevate Mental Health Awareness Scholarship is to inspire greater awareness about mental health and to fuel innovative solutions that help millions of people. Students applying for the scholarship will be required to write an essay about how their experience with mental health has influenced their beliefs, relationships, and career aspirations. The winner receives $500.

title: The Herblock Award For Editorial Cartoons
description: The Herblock Award for Editorial Cartoons offers $2,000 scholarships for three students whose visual art offers commentary or criticism on current events, social events, or political topics. Sample topics include, but are not limited to, breaking news, politics, elections, civics, domestic affairs, foreign policy, economics, the U.S. Constitution, and the U.S. Supreme Court.

title: Event Approaching: Chat with a Scientist: Defining Inclusion in STEM
description: “Inclusion, in its broadest sense, refers to the practice of ensuring that all individuals are respected, valued, and supported within a community or society, regardless of their differences. But what does inclusion look like in the context of STEM fields? What are some barriers to inclusion in STEM? Explore the answers to these questions and learn more at the first session of our ‘Inclusion in STEM’ series, featuring Alfred M. Mays, Chief Diversity Officer and Senior Program Officer for Diversity and Education at the Burroughs Wellcome Fund.”

title: Event Approaching: MoMath ‘Ask a Mathmatician’
description: “Ever wanted to ask a mathematician something, maybe about a curious new idea you have, or a concept you'd like to understand better? Don't know whom to ask? Here's your chance! Join David Reimann, MoMath's 2024–2025 Visiting Professor for Public Outreach, for this one-hour, interactive session. Come with your own questions for David, or just join to listen in. All are welcome, and no question is too basic — although plenty may be too hard!”

title: Deadline Approaching: NYU Weekend Workshops
description: “As a college prep program, the NYU SPS High School Academy offers a range of professional and college geared courses. Explore topics and get a feel for majors or careers you may be considering all while preparing for the college admissions and college application process.”

title: College Now Spring Programs & Courses
description: The CUNY College Now Program at campuses throughout the city offers free college-level science, math, & humanities classes to current juniors & seniors (sophomores may be eligible for some programs depending on requirements). The application deadlines and course times vary for each individual campus - students should explore their options and apply ASAP. See the links below for more detailed information about programs and courses. 1- Baruch College

title: Deadline Approaching: NYU Weekend Workshops
description: “As a college prep program, the NYU SPS High School Academy offers a range of professional and college geared courses. Explore topics and get a feel for majors or careers you may be considering all while preparing for the college admissions and college application process.”

title: Community Swap Volunteer Event
description: “Join this sustainable community event with popupswapX as a volunteer to weigh, sort, and fold donations for the biggest free yard sale you've ever seen. Thousands of New Yorkers will give and take for free. If you'd like to flex your social skills, be a greeter for incoming visitors, or if you like to learn about zero waste and recycling, sign up to volunteer for the clean-up crew.”
location: West 68th Street & Central Park West, Manhattan

title: Friendship Circle Volunteering Opportunities
description: The Friendship Circle invites Stuyvesant student volunteers to join their programs to help special needs youngsters. At Friendship Circle/Upper East Side, we are dedicated to bringing happiness and companionship to children, teens and young adults with special needs, as well as bringing energy, support and peace of mind to their families. The opportunity to connect with a special friend in a meaningful way has a profound impact on everyone involved. Learn more at the links below:
eligible: All students (different programs for volunteers of different ages.)

title: Stuyvesant Alumni Mentoring Program
description: The Mentoring program offers advice and mentorship from Stuyvesant’s accomplished alumni. We all stress about the college process and beyond, but by joining the Mentoring Program, you are setting yourself up for success. You will gain vital knowledge and important skills, such as:     College essay writing     Life Skills     Career Exploration    Resume Crafting    Interviewing    Public Speaking    And much, much more! The program will offer both in-person and virtual options.

title: Columbia Writing Academy: Writing for College Success
description: “The Columbia Writing Academy is designed for high school students who know that writing is the key to college success and want to develop their own personal voice and expand their writing skills before starting college. Through a combination of workshops and tutorials, exercises and assignments, students will practice the fundamental skills for writing successful college essays—developing a position to argue, persuading readers, anticipating counterarguments, and crafting strong sentences. Students will explore each stage in the writing process— brainstorming, drafting, revising—and will receive in-depth feedback at each stage of the process. By the end of the course, students will have practiced the major skills of successful college writing and have written a college-level essay.”

title: Latinas On the Verge of Excellence (L.O.V.E.) Mentoring Program
description: “L.O.V.E. is implemented as a class for girls only with a specific curriculum that covers social-emotional content and addresses health standards. During the academic year, mentors and mentees participate in weekly, hour-long sessions guided by a curriculum that consists of four core components: mental health, reproductive health, and college and career readiness. Through a series of structured mentoring and group activities that concentrate on personal empowerment, boosting academic performance, and college and career access, L.O.V.E. serves as a platform where young women can actually believe that they are capable of achieving their dreams.”
eligible: All students who identify as women

title: Angelo Del Toro Puerto Rican/Hispanic Youth Leadership Institute
description: (PR/HYLI) “The Angelo Del Toro Puerto Rican/Hispanic Youth Leadership Institute is a transformative civic engagement program that empowers Hispanic students to become leaders in their communities. Through PR/HYLI, students learn the intricacies of the legislative process through research, empowering them to advocate for the issues that matter most. This program fosters confidence and leadership skills and provides a nurturing environment where youth can express themselves in English and Spanish authentically and professionally, surrounded by educators and leaders who share their background and language, ensuring a safe and empowering space for their growth.”
eligible: All students of Puerto Rican/Hispanic ethnicity

title: Bill of Rights Institute (BRI) Student Fellowship
description: “The Bill of Rights Institute's Student Fellowship program is a leadership development program. The fellowship will focus on questions about civil society, the role of government, civic leadership, and more. Fellows participate in robust programming during the school year and participate in a culminating week of programming in and around Philadelphia, PA, and Washington, DC. They will meet twice a month and each session will have a short reading, discussion, and writing assignment. Participants will also design and lead public virtual events. The Fellowship concludes with a week-long capstone experience.”
location: Hybrid (In-Person at Washington, DC during June 22 - 27)

title: Kennedy-Lugar Youth Exchange and Study (YES) Abroad Program
description: “Living with a host family and attending a local school, YES Abroad students promote mutual understanding between the United States and their host country by forming lasting relationships with the local community. Participants live with a host family, attend a local high school, acquire leadership skills, and engage in activities to learn about the host country’s society and values; they also help educate others about American society and values. Participating countries include Jordan, India, Indonesia, Malaysia, Morocco, Thailand, and more. All expenses are covered.” No prior language skills are necessary.
eligible: Students who are between the ages of 15 and 18.5

title: Stuyvesant Alumni Mentoring Program
description: The Mentoring program offers advice and experience from Stuy’s accomplished alumni. We all stress about the college process and beyond, but by joining the Mentoring Program, you are setting yourself up for success. You will learn many important soft and hard skills, including:     College essay writing     Life Skills     Career Exploration     Resume Crafting     Interviewing     Public Speaking     And much, much more! The program will offer both in-person and virtual options.

title: Angelo Del Toro Puerto Rican Hispanic Youth Leadership Program
description: “The Angelo Del Toro Puerto Rican/Hispanic Youth Leadership is a nationally acclaimed civic engagement program for Hispanic high school students in NYC. This program is for high school students interested in politics, debate, and advocacy, who wish to develop leadership and public speaking skills, and who want to meet Latinx professional leaders and peers. Participants meet & work for six months with a team of their peers, followed by a three-day conference in Albany. Students will have the opportunity to attend college trips and workshops and earn a scholarship. Metro cards will be provided.”

title: TeenLife LIVE Performing & Visual Arts Virtual Fair
description: “Experience the TeenLife Performing & Visual Arts Virtual Fair! Designed to mirror a traditional fair, we have various speakers ready to interact with students, parents, and educators. Our line-up of speakers is set to enlighten students, parents, and educators about top schools and programs. Schools include Alfred University, Drexel University, Global Fashion Mentorship, Baldwin Wallace University: Conservatory of Music, Atlantic Acting School, and more. All registrants will receive a recording after the event wraps up.”

title: GuggTeens Sundays and Tuesdays @ the Guggenheim Museum
description: “During these free, weekly programs, teens can expand their art-making skills and connect with other teen artists! Located in the galleries, the program includes sketching, upcycling, and other creative projects, with Educator guidance and inspiration from the current exhibitions. Join us to build your art portfolio, meet other teen artists, or hangout with your friends. Teens of all levels of experience are encouraged to join, including those who are new to artmaking. Free museum admission, MetroCards, and materials will be provided.”
location: In-person at Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 5th Ave

title: Arts Connection Teen Reviewers and Critics Program (TRaC)
description: “In this FREE ten-week, afterschool program, you will see performances, concerts, and galleries, meet artists and learn about the industry from professionals. Fall TRaC options are Theater, Film, Multi-Arts, and Music!”

title: Arts Connection Art-Making Program
description: “In this in-depth program, you will explore and create art across multiple art forms with other creative NYC teens and a professional artist. Upon completion of the program, you will receive a $140 stipend.”

title: Brooklyn Botanic Garden Apprentice Program (GAP)
description: “The Garden Apprentice Program (GAP) at Brooklyn Botanic Garden is a great way for teens to learn about urban agriculture and the environment while working in one of the most exciting public gardens in the world! Apprentices can work their way up the four-tier program. BBG Garden Apprentices: - Earn a monetary award at the end of the apprenticeship (Tier 1: $600, Tier 2: $700, Tier 3: $800). - Work their way up the program to become paid staff as a Tier 4. - Learn about botany and environmentalism through hands-on lessons. - Grow and harvest fruits, vegetables, and herbs in the Children’s Garden. - Facilitate lessons to teach children about plants. - Explore Brooklyn Botanic Garden’s amazing plant collections. - Develop job skills, including teamwork, communication, and leadership.” There is an upcoming information session on October 26 from 3:00 to 5:00 pm.
date: March – November 2025 (spring training, summer programming, and a weekly

title: Cooper Union STEM Saturdays Inventor Lab Classes
description: “In each class, students learn design thinking and skills needed to complete projects. In the Data Visualization course, storytelling meets engineering. You will learn how to read, clean, and use data sets to design engaging visuals. In the Mechanics & Electronics Unleashed course, if you are eager to build and tinker, this workshop will help you bring your ideas to life. From modeling prototypes with 3D printers to designing circuits to making your creations move, your inner creator will have the opportunity to build a solid inventor’s toolkit.”
eligible: All students who are low or moderate income
cost: $720 (waived for students whose families earn less than $112,961)

title: International Young Researchers Conference STEM Winter Program
description: “This virtual program, in collaboration with Stanford University, is designed to equip students with the tools and knowledge they need to tackle advanced scientific topics and gain exposure to various research fields. Through a combination of live sessions, project work, and mentorship, students will explore core subjects such as Biology, Chemistry, Environmental Science, Computer Science, and Aerospace. Students will also engage in discussions on how these fields intersect and drive innovation today, guided by faculty, students, and researchers from Stanford University.”

title: Event Approaching: MoMath ‘Ask a Mathmatician’
description: “Ever wanted to ask a mathematician something, maybe about a curious new idea you have, or a concept you'd like to understand better? Don't know whom to ask? Here's your chance! Join David Reimann, MoMath's 2024–2025 Visiting Professor for Public Outreach, for this one-hour, interactive session. Come with your own questions for David, or just join to listen in. All are welcome, and no question is too basic — although plenty may be too hard!”

title: Museum of Mathematics Expansions Gifted Math Classes
description: “Do you know a gifted high schooler who loves math and mathematical explorations? Expansions, MoMath's after-school gifted program, is pleased to offer the Icosahedron track for students in grades nine through twelve. As a track in the Expansions program, Icosahedron is designed to challenge and inspire mathematically-talented students throughout New York City, and beyond. Classes will be held (in person) at MoMath on select Sundays, from 3:30 pm to 5:00 pm. Limited seats are available and spots are expected to fill fast, so register soon! Learn more and apply at icosahedron.momath.org.”
date: October – January 26 or February 2 – May 18 (select Sundays from 3:30 –

title: Walt Whitman Library Robotics Club @ Bklyn. Public Library
description: “Are you interested in robotics, programming, and having fun with your friends? Need something to add to your resume? Join the robotics club at the Walt Whitman branch of the Brooklyn Public Library! Members of the club will build robots and program them to move by coding with Python. There will also be a potential opportunity to join the BPL's robotics league in which you can compete against other teams from different library branches with your robot! No prior experience in programming or robotics is required. There will be an information session Thursday Nov. 2, 4:00pm - 4:30pm, at Walt Whitman Library.”
location: Brooklyn Public Library Walt Whitman Branch, 93 St Edwards St

title: Deadline Approaching:
description: Barbie + Girls Write Now: The Inspiring Women Writing Contest “Barbie and Girls Write Now are teaming up for a writing contest in celebration of Isabel Allende. Write a story about a girl, woman, or gender expansive individual who discovers their power(s)—whether real, fictional, or even magical. One Grand Prize Winner will receive a cash prize of $500.”

title: Princeton University's Leonard L. Milberg ’53 High School Poetry Prize
description: “The Leonard L. Milberg ’53 High School Poetry Prize recognizes outstanding work by student writers in the 11th grade in the U.S. or abroad. Applicants may submit up to 3 poems.” First place will receive a prize of $1,500.

title: The Scholastic Art & Writing Awards Program
description: “The Scholastic Awards are the longest-running, most prestigious recognition program for creative teens, and the largest source of scholarships for young artists and writers in the United States. Students are eligible to enter their original Art and/or Writing work for a chance at recognition, publication, exhibition, prize money, and more.”

title: The Scholastic Art & Writing Awards Program
description: “The Scholastic Awards are the longest-running, most prestigious recognition program for creative teens, and the largest source of scholarships for young artists and writers in the United States. Students are eligible to enter their original Art and/or Writing work for a chance at recognition, publication, exhibition, prize money, and more.”

title: Science Ambassador Scholarship
description: The Science Ambassador Scholarship offers 5 $20,000 tuition scholarship for a woman in science, technology, engineering, or math. Film a three–minute educational video of yourself explaining a STEM topic you're passionate about to be submitted.”
eligible: Current female or non-binary seniors interested in STEM majors Application

title: Event Approaching: Girls Write Now Introduction to Pantoum Poems
description: “In this engaging workshop, participants will explore the power of poetic forms to shape and express personal stories. Led by Teaching Artist Janine Simon, this session delves into the pantoum, a poetic form known for its repeating lines.”

title: Event Approaching: Technica Hackathon 2024
description: “Technica is the world’s largest hackathon for underrepresented genders, organized by students at the University of Maryland. Whether you’re a seasoned hacker or completely new to coding, this event is for you! Network with corporate sponsors from top tech companies, learn from workshops, tech talks, and inspiring keynote speakers, have fun at mini-events and win exciting prizes for your projects, get Swag, and connect with a vibrant, inclusive community in STEM. No prior coding experience is required!”
eligible: All students who identify as an underrepresented gender in STEM
location: Virtual or In-Person at the University of Maryland

title: Event Approaching:
description: Girls Write Now Polished Prose - Perfecting Personal Statements “Girls Write Now veteran Teaching Artist Susanna Horng, along with HarperCollins employees, will guide mentees through a concise lesson on crafting personal statements, followed by dedicated time to draft their essays. Then, our “Mentors for the Day” will work with mentees in small group breakout sessions to refine their drafts.”

title: The STEM Institute @ City College
description: The STEM Institute offers a variety of STEM and Humanities courses to all students for the spring term.
location: City College of New York (60 Convent Avenue, Manhattan)

title: Invest in Girls Online Programs
description: “With Invest in Girls, you’ll learn skills you need to make important life decisions– and gain confidence about managing your money. Learning about student loans, credit cards, budgeting–and more–is key to your success as you move into adulthood. We are here to start you off with free online and in-person opportunities for awesome girls like you.” These include “Be the Chief Financial Officer of Your Life”, “Be the Chief Investment Officer of Your Life”, “Be the Chief Executive Officer of Your Future”, and a mentorship program.

title: NYC Reading Partners Volunteers
description: “Give back to your community in as little as one hour per week! Build a lasting relationship and serve as a role model to a struggling early reader. You must complete a tutor orientation and background check before beginning. You should also have access to a computer and wifi. This can build your resume for college and careers.”

title: Event Approaching:
description: Girls Write Now Polished Prose - Perfecting Personal Statements “Girls Write Now veteran Teaching Artist Susanna Horng, along with HarperCollins employees, will guide mentees through a concise lesson on crafting personal statements, followed by dedicated time to draft their essays. Then, our “Mentors for the Day” will work with mentees in small group breakout sessions to refine their drafts.”

title: SEO Scholars Program
description: “SEO Scholars is a FREE, eight-year college access program that supports New York City public high school students to and through college. We currently serve 7,500 motivated young people and, we are committed to our student's personal growth, building successful futures, and creating a more equitable society for generations to come. SEO provides Metro Cards for all students every week. The program includes academic instruction in ELA and math, mentorship, tutoring, college tours, enrichment programs (Study Abroad, College-level Courses, Internships), college advising, career exploration, and more.”
date: Once a week during the school year (either Tuesday, Wednesday, or Thursday

title: Event Approaching: Saturday Sketching at The Met Fifth Avenue
description: “Sketch from works of art in The Met Fifth Avenue’s galleries and experiment with different drawing approaches. Build your skills with a teaching artist and share your works of art with other teens. Thinking of applying to an art high school or college? These classes are a great way to build a portfolio. All experience levels are welcome and all materials are provided.”
location: The Met Cloisters (99 Margaret Corbin Drive, Fort Tryon Park) or other

title: Harvey Mudd College Women’s Inclusion in Science, Technology,
description: Engineering and Mathematics (WISTEM) “WISTEM is a six-month long program that allows participants to engage in with interactive online (and one February break in-person )sessions. Through the virtual program and visit to campus, WISTEM will connect participating students with a cohort of like-minded peers, help participants learn more about admission, and strengthen their understanding of women’s experiences in STEM.”
eligible: Juniors committed to the inclusion of women in STEM
date: Virtual sessions from December to May, in-person fly in program from

title: Event Approaching: Technica Hackathon 2024
description: “Technica is the world’s largest hackathon for underrepresented genders, organized by students at the University of Maryland. Whether you’re a seasoned hacker or completely new to coding, this event is for you! Network with corporate sponsors from top tech companies, learn from workshops, tech talks, and inspiring keynote speakers, have fun at mini-events and win exciting prizes for your projects, get Swag, and connect with a vibrant, inclusive community in STEM. No prior coding experience is required!”
eligible: All students who identify as an underrepresented gender in STEM
location: Virtual or In-Person at the University of Maryland

title: Perry Outreach Program (POP) Event
description: “We will be holding our POP event for high school students in the NYC area. Students, of all gender identities, in grades 10 and up who are interested in orthopaedics or engineering and the advancement of women in STEM are encouraged to apply. In addition to six hands-on mock surgical exercises, participants will hear lectures from local women surgeons and engineers.”

title: Sophie Davis Health Professions Recruitment and Exposure Program
description: (HPREP) HPREP is a pre-college enrichment program offered by the Sophie Davis School of Biomedical Education at CCNY to help high school students by introducing them to different careers in healthcare. Their enriched curriculum includes lectures delivered by medical students and faculty, mentorship opportunities, a healthcare student and professional panel, and various clinical activities. Activities include visits to the Gross Anatomy lab and examining cadavers, problem-based learning workshops, and clinical training skills. Registration opens October 18th, and the program will be held for 6-8 weeks during the spring semester of the 2024-2025 academic year.
eligible: Sophomores, juniors, and seniors from under-represented groups

title: Event Approaching: Girls Write Now Introduction to Pantoum Poems
description: “In this engaging workshop, participants will explore the power of poetic forms to shape and express personal stories. Led by Teaching Artist Janine Simon, this session delves into the pantoum, a poetic form known for its repeating lines.”

title: Event Approaching:
description: Girls Write Now Polished Prose - Perfecting Personal Statements “Girls Write Now veteran Teaching Artist Susanna Horng, along with HarperCollins employees, will guide mentees through a concise lesson on crafting personal statements, followed by dedicated time to draft their essays. Then, our “Mentors for the Day” will work with mentees in small group breakout sessions to refine their drafts.”

title: Kemper Human Rights Education Foundation (KHREF) Essay Contest
description: “Is hate speech a threat to human rights? How does this affect free speech?” The essay contest offers high school students an exciting opportunity to display their research and writing skills while grappling with current human rights issues. The winners receive $4,000, $2,000, and $1,000 awards.”

title: NYC Exploring Careers Program
description: “Students interested in learning about different career paths can join the NYC Exploring program. It uses in-person & virtual weekly or bi-weekly after-school sessions to introduce students to a wide variety of careers. List of programs scheduled for Fall 2025:    Structuretone and Gensler (Architecture/Engineering/Construction) Wednesdays at 4:30-6:30pm 10/2, 10/9, 10/16, 10/23, 10/30, 11/6, 11/13, 11/20    M&T Bank (Finance/Accounting/Business) Tuesdays at 4:30-6:00pm 10/8, 10/15, 10/22    Gilbane (Architecture/Engineering/Construction) Tuesdays at 4:30-6:30pm 10/8, 10/15, 10/22, 10/29, 11/12, 11/19    Kings County District Attorney’s Office (Law & Government) Thursdays at 4:30-6:00pm 10/10, 10/24, 11/7, 11/21, 12/5, 12/19    Queens County District Attorney’s Office (Law & Government) Tuesdays at 4:30-6:00pm 10/15, 10/29, 11/12, 11/26, 12/10    LaGuardia Airport (Aviation) Thursdays at 4:30-6:00pm 10/17, 11/21, 12/19, 1/16, 2/20, 3/20, 4/17, 5/15    Lenox Health Greenwich Village (Medicine/Nursing) Thursdays at 4:30- 6:00pm 10/17, 11/21, 12/19, 1/16, 2/20, 3/20, 4/17, 5/15     Carver Federal Savings Bank (Finance/Accounting/Business) Wednesdays at 4:30-6:00pm 11/6, 11/13     Bellevue Hospital (Medicine/Nursing) Thursdays at 4:30-6:00pm 11/7, 11/14, 11/21, 12/5

title: YWIB-Metro New York & Columbia University: Inside Engineering
description: “Young Women In Biology/ Metro New York, in collaboration with the Columbia University School of Engineering, is offering an exciting opportunity to learn about careers in engineering. Participants will enjoy exclusive tours of Columbia's prestigious laboratories, including the Zuckerman Institute, where they will gain insights into MRI technology and research, as well as explore the Biomedical Engineering Lab and Makerspace to understand the innovation and creativity behind engineering solutions. This program is perfect for high school girls (grades 10 and up) who are curious about the fields of biomedical, mechanical, or electrical engineering. It offers them a close- up view of what it's like to work in these areas. Spaces are limited, so it's a unique chance to get an inside look at the world of engineering.”
eligible: All Sophomores, Juniors, and Seniors who identify as a woman
